19480.post_title: G331 - Guided tour among the Baltic capitals: Vilnius and Riga

pods_fields.titolo: G331 - Guided tour among the Baltic capitals: Vilnius and Riga
pods_fields.desc_min: The Baltic coast and National Parks of Lithuania and Latvia explored on highly scenic routes, including the two capital cities –Vilnius and Riga – with their old towns designated by UNESCO as the World Heritage Sites; and featuring the previously-closed Curonian Spit. Start your tour in Vilnius, travel to the Baltic Sea Coast in the West and further on to Latvia in the north, enjoy a great variety of towns, villages and landscapes, and get an excellent feel for the different characters of these distinctive sister countries.
pods_fields.prog:
ITINERARY (cycling ~210 km/131 miles)

Day 1 Sunday (Lithuania): VILNIUS

Arrive in Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania for more than 600 years. Individual transfer to the hotel (not included). Check-in at the hotel. 7:00 p.m. (19:00) welcome meeting at the hotel with tour guide. Optional dinner at the hotel. OVERNIGHT: Vilnius

Day 2 Monday (Lithuania): VILNIUS-TRAKAI Insular Castle-KAUNAS (cycling ~26 km, by coach ~95 km)

After breakfast a guided tour of Vilnius Old Town. Afternoon trip to Trakai, the former capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. After visit to the 14thC island castle built on a small island in Lake Galvė start your first cycle ride through picturesque countryside on gentle hills, then transfer by coach to Kaunas. Arrive in Kaunas, check-in and optional dinner at the hotel. OVERNIGHT: Kaunas Day 3 Tuesday (Lithuania): KAUNAS-VENTĖ Horn- KLAIPĖDA (cycling ~25 km, by coach ~240 km,) Morning transfer along the Nemunas River to the coast. En route passing 17thC castle of Panemunė. In the afternoon have a picnic lunch (included) followed by a cycle ride to Ventė Horn famous for its bird observatory and the 19thC lighthouse which was used for more than 100 years. After a short bus transfer arrive in Klaipeda, the main seaport of Lithuania, check-in and optional dinner at the hotel. OVERNIGHT: Klaipėda Day 4 Wednesday (Lithuania): CURONIAN SPIT NATIONAL PARK (cycling ~55 km, by boat or coach ~50 km) Transfer by coach or take a morning boat across the Curonian Lagoon to Nida. En-route enjoying the beautiful view of the Curonian Spit which separate the Baltic Sea from the Curonian Lagoon. Sightseeing around Nida, one of the most beautiful resorts in Lithuania. In the afternoon cycling back to Klaipėda on the Seaside Cycle Route along the Curonian Spit famous for its amber and fine sand beaches. Arrive in Klaipėda, optional dinner at the hotel. Day 5 Thursday (Lithuania-Latvia): KLAIPĖDA-PALANGA Resort-Hill of Crosses-RIGA (cycling ~35 km, by coach ~290 km) Early morning ride to Palanga through the Seaside Regional Park, a former soviet military training area. Arrive in Palanga, the biggest Lithuanian seaside resort for a tour which includes a visit to the Botanical Garden and the Amber Museum in the Palace of Count Tyszkiewicz, with over 25000 pieces of amber and 15000 insects on display. Afternoon transfer to Riga (Latvia). En-route stop at the Hill of Crosses, the unforgettable sight of thousands of crosses on two small hills. Continue to Riga, the capital city of Latvia. Arrive in Riga, check-in and dinner at the hotel (included). OVERNIGHT: Riga Day 6 Friday (Latvia): RIGA & JURMALA Seaside Resort (cycling ~30 km, by coach ~20 km) After breakfast a guided tour of Riga Old Town, a medieval Hanseatic town famous for its Art Nouveau buildings. In the afternoon free time in Riga or cycling to Jurmala, the largest resort in the Baltic States well known for its long, white, sand beaches, mineral waters and mud with healing properties. Transfer back by coach to the hotel in Riga. Optional dinner at the hotel. OVERNIGHT: Riga Day 7 Saturday (Latvia): GAUJA National Park & Bicycle Museum (cycling ~40 km, by coach ~100 km) Morning transfer to Sigulda, the most popular resort in Latvia, in the Gauja River Valley. Cycling through Gauja National Park to Saulkrasti, en route enjoy spectacular views of Gauja River valley with Gutmana Cave, visit Turaida Castle and the oldest Latvian Church, Krimulda, built in 1205. Finish the ride with a visit to the Latvian bicycle museum followed by a transfer to Riga. Optional dinner at the hotel. OVERNIGHT: Riga Day 8 Sunday (Latvia): RIGA Breakfast at the hotel. End of the tour.

19256.post_title: G207 - Amsterdam to Bremen Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Amsterdam to Bremen Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: The Discovery Tour 2019 will take us cycling from the Netherlands to Germany, along the coasts of the North Sea and through Frisian and Saxon countryside.
pods_fields.note: Guided Cycling Trip in International Group
pods_fields.desc:
• Share with other cycle travellers the thrill of discovering a new route, yet to be explored.
  • Enjoy a canal cruise in Amsterdam before leaving and the fairytale atmosphere of Bremen at your arrival.
  • Cycle along the unique coasts of the Wadden Sea, a UNESCO heritage site.
  • Immerse yourself in the bucolic landscapes of East Friesland.
  • Break away from the usual routines, beating the less touristy tracks and enjoying a pioneering week.
  • Indulge in a unique trip at a special price.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: about 379 km 17/08: Amsterdam Individual arrival in Amsterdam. Meeting at the hotel at 6pm with the guide and the rest of the group, for the initial briefing and the delivery of the bicycles (if booked). Overnight at the hotel in Amsterdam. 18/08: Amsterdam – Lelystad (65 km) After barely 20 km on the flawless cycle paths of the Dutch capital, we will encounter the first jewel of our trip: the town of Muiden with the Muiderslot, the most beautiful and best kept medieval castle in the Netherlands. Another stretch of bike path through the polders will lead us to the Hollandse Brug, the bridge connecting IJmeer and Gooimeer lakes. From here we will enter the Almere Buiten wetlands, where we will evaluate whether to opt for a path inland or along the coast. Final destination of the day: Lelystad, a city steeped in history, known for its history museums and shopping. To take a dip in the history of the Netherlands, just pass by the Batavialand area, in particular by the shipyard, where you can admire and board the replicas of the famous ships of the Dutch East India Company. Overnight at the hotel in Lelystad. 19/08: Lelystad – Wolvega (69 km) We will leave Lelystad cycling along the IJsselmeer coast, one of Europe’s largest artificial lakes, separated from the North Sea by the Northern Dam. We will then reach the picturesque fishing village of Urk, with its unique history and culture. Here the local dialect is still spoken and surely among the must-have experiences is a walk through the old alleys called ginkiese and a taste of IJsselmeer smoked eel. We will then head for the interior, passing through the famous Emmeloord, the largest tulip field area in the Netherlands and entering the Friesland region, land of lakes and canals, but also of ancient villages and vast pastures, ideal for cycling. Cycling across this rural landscape, we will finally arrive in Wolvega, final destination of the day. Overnight at the hotel in Wolvega. 20/08: Wolvega – Leeuwarden (56 km) Cycling mostly on bike paths, through cultivated fields, endless pastures and woods, we will reach Leeuwarden, the capital of Friesland and the European Capital of Culture 2018. A quiet and dynamic city at the same time, it was an important commercial and trading center where the excellent cheese and butter produced on the Friesland farms was sold and distributed to the rest of the Netherlands via the waterways. The most enjoyable activity to do here is to take a walk along the canals that cross the city, browsing the art stores and seeking bric-à-brac bargains, or among the art installations scattered around the city center. To end the day in fine style, we will all say a toast with a glass of Boomsma, the local gin produced in the city for over 125 years. Overnight at the hotel in Leeuwarden. 21/08: Leeuwarden – Holwerd (by bus) | Holwerd – Groningen (65 km) After breakfast, a bus transfer of about 40 minutes will take us directly to the Wadden Sea Coast, a UNESCO worldwide heritage site. Among the many magnificent sceneries of the Dutch coast, this is definitely one of the most extraordinary, not only for the huge variety of flora and fauna which grow and inhabit the area, but above all for the sheer spectacle it offers. It is indeed a unique place that changes appearance depending on the rhythm of the tides; twice a day, corresponding with the low tide, the sandy bottom emerges from the water creating long slushy walks (Wadden means muddy) where mudflat hiking is practiced, whose effects we could evaluate together. A piece of route through the National Park of Lauwersmeer and along the inland bike paths, and we finally reach Groningen, one of the most bike friendly cities in Europe. Nestled between long canals and antique churches, small squares and picturesque alleys, but also modern design buildings, like the very colorful City Museum, Groningen is still a little pearl unknown to mass tourism, a place where you can walk in tranquillity to discover the jewels of the historic center, immersed in a academic atmosphere. Overnight at the hotel in Groningen. 22/08: Groningen – Leer (78km) After leaving the city, we will immerse ourselves in the East Friesland countryside, among lakes, villages, canals and bike paths, to finally enter Germany. We will then reach Leer, situated on the banks of the river Ems, which we will cross just before entering the city, known especially for its Market Square and the recently renovated Evennurg Castle. Overnight at the hotel in Leer. 23/08: Leer – Oldenburg by train | Oldenburg – Bremen (46km) After breakfast, a train transfer of about an hour, will take us quickly to Oldenburg, picturesque city of Lower Saxony, also known as the City of Parks thanks to its numerous green areas. From the station we will head towards the river Hunte which we will cross to then continue through Lower Saxony, a region fortunately still off the mass tourism track. Awaiting for us, at the end of our adventure, is the city of Bremen, hospitable and open-minded where, like in the best Northern Europe tradition, ancient and modern coexist in perfect harmony. Among the historic jewels of the city, which preserves antique monuments up to 1200 years old, there is the Market Square, where you can find the statue dedicated to the Town Musicians of Bremen (apparently touching the donkey’s legs with both hands brings good luck), the main characters of the famous fairytale by Brothers Grimm, and the Bremen Roland (the statue dedicated to the paladin of Holy Roman Emperor Charlemagne), both UNESCO heritage. The industrial history of the city is perfectly preserved in Weserburg, the Museum of Modern Art, while all you need to do to immerse yourself in a bohemian dimension, is taking a walk in the colorful Viertel district. Would you rather take an excursion in the future? Well go straight to the futuristic Universum, where the over 300 exhibitions allow you to immerse with all your senses in the main scientific phenomena. Overnight at the hotel in Bremen.  24/08: Bremen After breakfast, end of services. Being this one a Discovery Tour, the stages are only indicative; mileage and points of interest may vary according to the situation found on-site.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: Terrain: mostly flat. Average length of each stage goes from 46 to 78 km per day, which at an average of 14km/hour means cycling between 4 to 6 hours during the whole day. Tour for those that have a minimum cycling training. Streets: 90% asphalt, 10% unpaved country roads, mostly bike paths, especially in the Netherlands. Luggage transport: yes, one item per person, maximum 20kg. This tour also includes Support Service Plus. Number of participants: minimum 10. Recommended for children: no. Animals: not allowed. Bike rental: aluminum frame unisex city bike with 24 Shimano gears, one waterproof side bag and one front bag, reinforced wheels, anti-puncture tires (90% guaranteed). Upon request, we can also provide unisex e-bikes. A helmet is not mandatory but is highly recommended. Upon request you can rent one for €15 per helmet (pre-booking is necessary, to be paid on-site). Rental agreement to be signed on-site. Deposit required for the e-bikes. Possibility to request a Bicycle Coverage for Damage and Theft for the rented bikes. Starting point of the tour: Amsterdam, Saturday afternoon. On day 1 no cycling itinerary is scheduled. Finishing point of the tour: Bremen, Saturday morning. Travel documents: technical fact sheets in Italian, handed out before setting off. Language spoken by the guide: English and Italian; the tour will normally be held in English. Meals and special diets: the tour includes only buffet breakfasts. In case of food allergies, intolerance or need to follow a special diet, please advise us when booking. We suggest people who need a gluten-free diet to bring some usual food with them. We cannot guaranty an appropriate diet for vegans.
pods_fields.part_pr:
Price to the public per person €
Individual basic price 1.250
Supplement single room on request
Supplement bike rental 90
Price includes: accommodation 7 nights in en-suite double room in 4* hotels; 7 breakfasts; English-speaking Tour Leader; luggage transfer (1 piece/person, 20kg max); Support Service Plus; Europ Assistance health/luggage insurance 24/24. Price does not include: trip to Amsterdam and from Bremen; lunches and dinners; entry fees; bike rental, train and bus transfers, extras in general and anything not mentioned in section Price includes.
pods_fields.come_arrivare: Amsterdam By plane: the closest airport is Amsterdam Schiphol. Scheduled flights with KLM and all international airlines; low-cost airlines: Transavia, Easyjet. By car: your itinerary can be planned on Google Maps. Private parking at the hotel (approx. €30/day). By train: your itinerary can be planned on Dbahn. Return from Bremen By plane: the closest airport is Flughafen Bremen. Scheduled flights with Lufthansa and international airlines. By train: your itinerary can be planned on Dbahn.

18229.post_title: LW097 - Emilia Romagna for Foodies: Custom Bike Tour

pods_fields.titolo: Emilia Romagna for Foodies: Custom Bike Tour
pods_fields.desc_min: A modular cycling tour offering you the chance to create your ideal experience across the flatlands between Parma and Bologna and Italy’s finest gastronomy.
pods_fields.desc:
• Cycling across Emilia Romagna's flatlands.
  • Discover Parma's artistic treasures and local products such as Prosciutto, culatello and Parmigiano Reggiano.
  • Learning how precious Traditional Balsamic Vinegar of Modena has been produced for centuries directly in a typical and beautiful Acetaia.
  • Tasting what is considered the finest Italian gastronomy.
  • Experience the warm hospitality of people from Emilia.
  • Walking under Bologna colonnaded medieval grid and attend a cooking class where you will learn the secrets of local dishes.
pods_fields.prog: The Stages: We suggest 5 possible daily cycling itineraries that you can choose according to your needs and interests, to plan your ideal tour. For the first day, you are free to choose whether arriving the night before the beginning of your bike tour, or the same day to start off directly by bike. The last day, whether to finish cycling in the afternoon and leave straight after, or stay an extra night. We also offer you the possibility to decide whether to use or not luggage transportation service from one hotel to another. Please remind that in some cases, like the round tours where the change of hotels is not planned, luggage transport is unnecessary. Stage n. 1: round tour Parma – Fontanellato – Parma (57 km) Departure by bike for a pleasant itinerary through the countryside. After a stop at the Cistercian Abbey of Valserena, which inspired French writer Stendhal for his novel The Charthouse of Parma, you will arrive in the village of San Secondo where you will have the chance to visit a caseificio (cheese factory) where authentic Parmigiano Reggiano is being produced. You will then reach Fontanellato and its mighty fortress of Sanvitale, dating back to the 12th century, guardian of a real treasure, the room of Diana and Atteone with paintings of Parmigianino. If you have time, don't miss Franco Maria Ricci Foundation, with art collections and the largest bamboo maze to explore. Dinner in atypical Trattoria and overnight at the hotel in Parma. Stage n. 2: Parma – Reggio Emilia (59 km) Departure by bike across the land of Parmigiano Reggiano and the famous Prosciutto di Parma (Parma ham) and towards Torrechiara to stop and admire the perfectly well-preserved 15th century castle. A beautiful itinerary amidst cultivated fields will bring you to the mighty Montechiarugolo Castle, a fortress overlooking the Enza river, and the Castle of Montecchio, this too part of the defensive system of the Duchy of Matilde di Canossa. The tour ends in Reggio Emilia, where you can enjoy a ride through the historic center with its beautiful buildings and churches. Overnight at the hotel in Reggio Emilia. Stage n. 3: Reggio Emilia – Carpi – Modena (57 km) A few kilometers in the typical Pianura Padana (Po Valley) countryside will bring you to Correggio, the birthplace of the famous painter named after the town. You will then continue through the vineyards of Lambrusco di Santa Croce Dop and arrive in Carpi, pearl of the Renaissance. Here you can visit Piazza Martiri, the third largest square in Italy, with the castle, the theatre and the adjacent parish church of Sagra. You will then cycle up to the town of Modena to visit the graceful historic center: the Cathedral (Duomo), Romanesque masterpiece, Piazza Grande and the Ghirlandina Tower, have all been designated as World Heritage Site by UNESCO. Dinner in a typical Trattoria and overnight at the hotel in Modena. Stage n. 4: round tour Modena – Vignola – Castelvetro – Modena (65 km) The cycle path built on the old railway line will lead you first to Spilamberto, where you will have the possibility (highly recommended) to visit a typical Acetaia, the place where the Traditional Balsamic Vinegar of Modena is produced and to taste the result of different aging. Starting following the cycle path again, you will reach Vignola, the city of cherries and the famous Torta Barozzi, a local chocolate cake made with a secret recipe, closely guarded at the Caffè-Pasticceria Gollini, a traditional pastry shop located in the city center. After a short visit at the castle, offering a breathtaking view from its walkways and towers, you will then continue cycling on secondary roads up to the beautiful castle-village of Castelvetro, home to the renowned Lambrusco Grasparossa wine. In Castelvetro you will also have the possibility to stop at a local winery for some wine tasting. On the way back to Modena, possible stop at the Casa Museo of Luciano Pavarotti for a visit. Overnight at the hotel in Modena. Stage n. 5: Modena – Nonantola – Bologna (55 km) In the morning, you will leave Modena via the cycle path that follows another old railway track, running between the fields and the vineyards. The first possible stop of the day will be in Nonantola to visit the beautiful Abbey, an important masterpiece of Romanesque style, founded in 752 by Saint Anselmo, and recently restored. The Abbey is located along the Via Romea Nonantolana, the route followed by pilgrims around the year 1000 to reach Rome. You will finally enter Bologna via the Navile cycle path. Once in Bologna, don't miss a stroll under the the wonderful colonnaded medieval grid and a visit to the beautiful historic centre with its towers, the Duomo and the market. In the evening, possibility to attend a cooking class (not included) and learn how to prepare traditional local dishes. Dinner in a typical Trattoria or at the Cooking School and overnight at the hotel in Bologna.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica:
Terrain: flat to slightly hilly with some gentle climbs and descents. Average length of the stages: 57 to 74 km per day. Roads: 80% roads (tarmac, cycle ways, paved roads), 20% unsurfaced roads (dirt roads, unpaved roads).
Stage 1 Stage 2 Stage3 Stage 4 Stage 5

Difference in height, in descent - 450 - 350 -

Bike rental: aluminum frame city bike (man and woman), with 24 gears, handlebar brakes, one side bag and a front bag with a waterproof map pocket. Number of participants: 2 minimum. Luggage transport: yes, upon request. Recommended for children: from 12 years upwards. Back to starting point: you can go back to the starting point by train at the end of the tour. For those that have their own bikes, all regional trains also transport bikes for a small supplementary charge.

*Cooking class in Bologna: you will enjoy a private cooking class together with an English speaking chef. The cooking class is in Bologna and lasts about 3 hours: from 7 to 10 p.m. You will prepare 3 typical local dishes: stuffed pasta, tagliatelle and a dessert. After the cooking class, you will have dinner with the dishes you have prepared, with paired wine. Price includes: accommodation in double room with private bathroom in 3* hotels, breakfasts, typical dinners in Trattorias as indicated in the price list, luggage transport (if requested); Travel App MyEasyRoute including: track of your bike route, map, points of interest, services and your GPS geolocation, functioning offline, on your smartphone. Price does not include: trip to/from your departure/arrival location, lunches, dinners not planned, drinks, bike rental, possible train transfers; luggage transport (if not requested), insurance, entrance fees to castles, monuments, tastings and anything not mentioned at the section Price includes. Roadbooks of the tour are available at a cost of €15 (to be booked at the moment of the reservation).
pods_fields.come_arrivare: By plane: nearby airports are Milan, Parma and Bologna; each of these airports offer shuttle service to the railway station. Many trains with bike transport connect Milan, Parma and Bologna. By car: itineraries available at www.google.com/maps. By train: railway station of Parma/Reggio Emilia/Modena/Bologna. Timetables and reservation at www.trenitalia.com.

17851.post_title: G291 - LUNGO LA SENNA TRA PARIGI E MONTARGIS

17538.post_title: G274 - Europe Escape: from Paris to London and Amsterdam Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Europe Escape: from Paris to London and Amsterdam Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min:
Explore Europe cycling and leave for the ultimate Escape Trip. 
Our expert Tour Leaders will guide you from Paris to Amsterdam via London, across France, England, Belgium and the Netherlands.
You can't miss the experience!
pods_fields.note: Guided cycling trip in international group with English-speaking Tour Leader
pods_fields.desc: An Escape Cycling Trip covering 4 European countries, leaving from Paris, the Ville Lumière and getting to London and Amsterdam. The first stretch of your itinerary corresponds to the Greenway, a picturesque route inaugurated in 2012, connecting Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris to Westminster Abbey in the heart of London. Along the way, you will have the chance to take in a mosaic of landscapes scattered with castles, cathedrals and charming villages immersed in green surroundings. A 4-hour ferry crossing will take you from Diepe, France to Newhaven, in the UK. From here, a cycling itinerary along the white cliffs of South Downs National Park will drive you first to the vibrating city of Brighton and then across the rolling hills of Sussex. Parks and bike paths immersed in the beautiful English countryside will mark the stage to the cosmopolitan heart of London. After a mid-way day-off in London you will continue cycling from Greenwich, a charming London neighborhood along Thames River, across the beautiful County of Kent, also known as the Garden of England. Crossing the Channel again you will get to the coastal city of Dunkirk in France. You will leave the coast of the North Sea to start exploring Belgian Flanders, a land rich in fields and meadows mingled with waterways, sandy beaches and seaside promenades. Here you will have the chance to discover firsthand why Belgium is renowned for chocolate, waffles, lace and beer. Explore the unforgettable sites of elegant Ostend and romantic Bruges. Finally, you will find out that the Netherland is not only windmills. After cycling along the canals and peaceful countryside, you will enter Amsterdam, to discoverthe city's ancient history and contemporary open-minded atmosphere. Cycling here is surely the best way to feel like a local. During the whole trip our expert Tour Leaders will be pleased to guide you along this amazing itinerary and across the secrets of this part of Europe. Don't miss the experience!
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 684 km/ 427 mi. Day 1: Paris Individual arrival in Paris and hotel check in. At 6 p.m. welcome meeting with your Tour Leader and the rest of the group. Dinner on your and night at the hotel in Paris. Day 2: Paris – Maisons Laffitte  (52 km/ 32 mi.) Your trip will start on Parisian cycle paths taking in the beautiful and historic sites of the city, starting from Notre-Dame Cathedral and through Place de la Bastille, Canal Saint Martin and La Villette. A canal will lead us to the banks of the Seine River and to the stunning Parc des Impressionistes in Rueil-Malmaison a faithful reproduction of Monet's garden in Giverny. The day ends in Maisons Laffitte, a few steps from the castle, a fine example of French Baroque style built to host King Louis XIV. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Maisons Laffitte. Day 3: Maisons Laffitte – Chars (46 km/ 29 mi.) | train from Chars to Gisors Our day starts in the shade of oaks and beeches as we ride through the St. Germain-en-Laye Forest and into the Oise Valley. With its vibrant landscapes, this valley was a source of inspiration for many Impressionist painters, in particular for Vincent Van Gogh (don't forget to visit the Van Gogh Museum once you will be in Amsterdam), who painted here his Wheatfield with Crows. We will continue cycling across Vexin Français Regional Nature Park, an area rich in history, nature, and architecture. Our ride will take us then on to Chars where we will board a train for a short (approximately 30 minutes) journey to Gisors, our destination for the day, an ancient medieval town wrapped in mystery of the legend of Templar Knights. Dinner at the restaurant and overnight at the hotel in Gisors. Day 4:  Gisors – Forges-les-Eaux (60 Km/ 37 mi.) In the morning we will continue our ride through the rich countryside and quaint villages of Normandy and the Epte Valley. See the beautiful Abbey in Saint-Germer-de-Fly, stop for lunch in a typical French village, cool off as you dip your toes in the crisp clean natural spring waters of Haussez. The historic Forges-les-Eaux is our destination today. Enjoy an evening stroll on the path around the lake or test your luck at the casino. Dinner at the restaurant and overnight at the hotel. Day 5: Forges-les-Eaux - Dieppe (50 Km/ 31 mi.) | ferry from Dieppe to Newhaven A converted rails-to-trails bike path is our stress-free route to Dieppe. The landscape along this 48 km stage is dotted with thriving farms and castles. These farms supply the modern-day markets of Normandy and Paris. The castles, such as Mesnières-en-Bray and Arques-la-Bataille, serve as a reminder of the France’s rich history. Along the way we will pass through the village of Neufchatel-en-Bray, famous for heart shaped soft cheese. Once in Dieppe, park your bike, relax on the beach, or savor local oysters before boarding the ferry to cross the Channel to Newhaven, England. Dinner on the ferry and overnight at the hotel in Newhaven. Day 6: Newhaven – Crawley (62 km/ 39 mi.) Our first day in England begins with a ride along the Newhaven marina toward the stunning cliffs of South Downs. A bit of climbing takes us to breathtaking views as we ride along the top before riding down to a seaside path. For 10km we will enjoy the scenic pathway with immaculate cliffs on one side and the English Channel on the other. Soon we will arrive in Brighton, a lively destination popular for its pier attractions, cafes, and charming old town called The Lanes. Next we head inland through the rolling hills of Devil's Dyke, a legendary valley in the County of Sussex that is said to have been dug by the Devil. We will continue to Crawley, belonging to what is called The Greater London. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Crawley. Day 7: Crawley – London (67 km/ 42 mi.) The last cycling day marks the return to urban life, although our re-entry is gradual. We will start our day cycling across in English countryside, exploring the County of Surrey and into the outskirts of London. Our route crosses city parks filled with runners, cyclists, and dog walkers as we will make our way to the city center. River Wandle will lead us to River Thames and to the heart of London. Westminster Abbey will appear like a vision; our first goal is reached! Dinner on your own and overnight at the hotel in London. Day 8: day off in London | transfer to Greenwich in public transport (luggage and bike transport provided) You will have a full day to enjoy London and in the afternoon you can decide the best time for you to reach your hotel in Greenwich, ancient village overlooking the south bank River Thames, located only a few kilometers from the center of London. The Royal Observatory stands on the hill overlooking the village. The historic astronomical observatory is the location of Greenwich Prime Meridian for which the village is worldwide known. Dinner on your own and overnight at the hotel in Greenwich. Day 9: Greenwich – Canterbury (42 Km/ 26 mi.) After breakfast, we will start cycling along the south bank of the River Thames up to Dartford (31 km). Here we will board a train and travel across the County of Kent to Whitstable (1h20 approximately). Kent is also known as the Garden of England for its green landscapes dotted with some of the most beautiful and famous gardens of the UK. Once in Whitstable, we will ride the last 10km to our day’s destination, Canterbury. This beautiful town is located between Dover and London and it is the starting point of Via Francigena, an ancient pilgrim route running from here to Rome. Despite its medieval past, the city is now lively with students arriving here from all over Europe to attend its important university. The city was the first capital of the Saxon Kingdom of Kent and the seat of the first Christian diocese of England, founded by St. Augustine. The magnificent Christ Church Cathedral dominates the narrow alleys and half-timbered houses of the old medieval city center. Today, after several renovations, the Cathedral is one of the best examples of English Gothic architecture. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Canterbury. Day 10: Canterbury – Dover (50 km/ 32 mi.)| ferry to Dunkirk In the morning we will cycle the 34 km to Dover, famous for its white cliffs and one of the main ports of Great Britain. Here, we will board the ferry to Dunkirk, France (about 2 hours + 1 Time Zone). Once in France, we will ride the 18 km separating the port to the city center, where our hotel is located. Dunkirk is the third most important port in France. It is located in the Nord-Pas de Calais region, 10 km from the border with Belgium. At first glance, Dunkirk is an industrial town focused on maritime trade; however, when you look deeper, the unusual beauty of this place sets in with its dunes and long sandy beaches flourishing in flora and fauna. Kite-surfing and the famous surf on the sand are popular activities here. The city center is characterized by low buildings, mainly of the last century, and Flemish influences. The Church of St. Eloi and the two bell towers are included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites and are well worth a visit. Dinner at the restaurant and overnight at the hotel in Dunkirk. Day 11: Dunkirk – Bruges (79 km/ 49 mi.) The main part of this stage occurs in Belgium. Several World War II battles took place here along the coast as French and British troops tried to block the German invasion. Once across the France-Belgium border, we will ride across the Flemish green countryside. Cycling along the coast of the North Sea, we will reach Ostend, a popular tourist destination on the Flemish coast characterized by its wide promenade bordered by shops, hotels and restaurants where you can taste excellent mussels, oysters and drink local beers. Our bike tour continues then through the Flanders  and towards the romantic city of Bruges, where time seems to have stopped and everything runs slowly. Thanks to its myriad of canals, it is often referred to as The Venice of the North. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Bruges. Day 12: Bruges – Breskens (45 km/ 28 mi.) | ferry to Vlissingen After breakfast, take some time to visit Bruges. Walking the narrow streets along the canals of the city centre, you will discover historic buildings, pubs serving local craft beers, and chocolate shops. A boat tour through the waterway network could be also a unique and interesting way to discover the city. In the afternoon, we will continue our journey across the countryside Belgian-Dutch border. In Breskens short ferry transfer will allow us to cross quickly (in about 15 minutes) Scheldt River and reach Vlissingen, our final destination for the day. The promenade on the seafront, called Boulevard, is a long and beautiful walkway where a monumental prison tower dating from the fifteenth century is located. Dinner and overnight in Vlissingen. Day 13: Vlissingen – Dordrecht by train | Dordrecht - Vianen (66 km/ 41 mi.) After breakfast, a train transfer (1h30 approximately) will take us to Dordrecht, an elegant river town rich in art, theater life and architecture that gave birth to several accomplished artists including some students Rembrandt's pupils. Our journey continues towards Kinderdijk, a Unesco World Heritage Site and probably the most famous polder of the Netherlands, thanks to the 19 monumental windmills dating back to the 18th  century. Some of the windmills are still functioning and it is possible to visit them. After the visit, we will keep cycling across Dutch countryside until we reach the city of Vianen, in the Province of Utrecht. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Vianen. Day 14: Vianen – Amsterdam (65 km/ 40 mi.) The first break of the day will be in the picturesque and offbeat Utrecht, one of the oldest cities of the Netherlands hosting today a vibrant university life. The old city centre is full of historic mansions now turned into boutiques and cafes overlooking the canals. The last part of the ride will be the introduction to our arrival in Amsterdam, well known for its canals and lined tilting buildings, for the open-minded atmosphere and of course the bicycles! Riding a bike is surely the best way to explore the city and mix up with the locals, but also a canal cruise at sunset is highly recommended. While exploring the city, don't forget to visit Dam Square  and the many museums of art and history like the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum, or Anne Frank House. Dinner on your own and overnight at the hotel in Amsterdam. Day 15: Amsterdam After breakfast, end of services.

From London to Amsterdam primarily flat; hilly terrain between Canterbury and Dover (34 km). Basic cycling experience is required for this tour. Moderate cycling training is recommended. Streets: 70% asphalted, 30% unpaved country roads Bikes: city bike. Participants: min. 12 pax. Suggested for kids: from 13 years on (bike rental possible starting from the height of 150 cm).

17500.post_title: L274 - Europe Escape: from Paris to London and Amsterdam Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Europe Escape: from Paris to London and Amsterdam Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min:
Explore Europe cycling and leave for the ultimate Escape Trip. 
You will cycle self-guided from Paris to Amsterdam via London, across France, England, Belgium and the Netherlands.
You can't miss the experience!
pods_fields.desc: An Escape Cycling Trip covering 4 European countries, leaving from Paris, the Ville Lumière and getting to London and Amsterdam. The first stretch of your itinerary corresponds to the Greenway, a picturesque route inaugurated in 2012, connecting Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris to Westminster Abbey in the heart of London. Along the way, you will have the chance to take in a mosaic of landscapes scattered with castles, cathedrals and charming villages immersed in green surroundings. A 4-hour ferry crossing will take you from Diepe, France to Newhaven, in the UK. From here, a cycling itinerary along the white cliffs of South Downs National Park will drive you first to the vibrating city of Brighton and then across the rolling hills of Sussex. Parks and bike paths immersed in the beautiful English countryside will mark the stage to the cosmopolitan heart of London. After a mid-way day-off in London you will continue cycling from Greenwich, a charming London neighborhood along Thames River, across the beautiful County of Kent, also known as the Garden of England. Crossing the Channel again you will get to the coastal city of Dunkirk in France. You will leave the coast of the North Sea to start exploring Belgian Flanders, a land rich in fields and meadows mingled with waterways, sandy beaches and seaside promenades. Here you will have the chance to discover firsthand why Belgium is renowned for chocolate, waffles, lace and beer. Explore the unforgettable sites of elegant Ostend and romantic Bruges. Finally, you will find out that the Netherland is not only windmills. After cycling along the canals and peaceful countryside, you will enter Amsterdam, to discoverthe city's ancient history and contemporary open-minded atmosphere. Cycling here is surely the best way to feel like a local. To guide and support you along the journey, our App MyEasyRoute. Don't miss the experience!
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 684 km/ 427 mi. Day 1: Paris Individual arrival in Paris and hotel check in. At 6 p.m. welcome meeting with our staff. Overnight at the hotel in Paris. Day 2: Paris – Maisons Laffitte  (52 km/ 32 mi.) Your trip will start on Parisian cycle paths taking in the beautiful and historic sites of the city, starting from Notre-Dame Cathedral and through Place de la Bastille, Canal Saint Martin and La Villette. A canal will lead us to the banks of the Seine River and to the stunning Parc des Impressionistes in Rueil-Malmaison a faithful reproduction of Monet's garden in Giverny. The day ends in Maisons Laffitte, a few steps from the castle, a fine example of French Baroque style built to host King Louis XIV. Overnight at the hotel in Maisons Laffitte. Day 3: Maisons Laffitte – Chars (46 km/ 29 mi.) | train from Chars to Gisors Your day will start in the shade of oaks and beeches as you will ride through the St. Germain-en-Laye Forest and into the Oise Valley. With its vibrant landscapes, this valley was a source of inspiration for many Impressionist painters, in particular for Vincent Van Gogh (don't forget to visit the Van Gogh Museum once you will be in Amsterdam), who painted here his Wheatfield with Crows. We will continue cycling across Vexin Français Regional Nature Park, an area rich in history, nature, and architecture. The ride will take you then on to Chars where you will board a train for a short (approximately 30 minutes) journey to Gisors, your destination for the day, an ancient medieval town wrapped in mystery of the legend of Templar Knights. Overnight at the hotel in Gisors. Day 4:  Gisors – Forges-les-Eaux (60 Km/ 37 mi.) In the morning you will continue the ride through the rich countryside and quaint villages of Normandy and the Epte Valley. See the beautiful Abbey in Saint-Germer-de-Fly, stop for lunch in a typical French village, cool off as you dip your toes in the crisp clean natural spring waters of Haussez. The historic Forges-les-Eaux is our destination today. Enjoy an evening stroll on the path around the lake or test your luck at the casino. Overnight at the hotel. Day 5: Forges-les-Eaux - Dieppe (50 Km/ 31 mi.) | ferry from Dieppe to Newhaven A converted rails-to-trails bike path is our stress-free route to Dieppe. The landscape along this 48 km stage is dotted with thriving farms and castles. These farms supply the modern-day markets of Normandy and Paris. The castles, such as Mesnières-en-Bray and Arques-la-Bataille, serve as a reminder of the France’s rich history. Along the way you will pass through the village of Neufchatel-en-Bray, famous for heart shaped soft cheese. Once in Dieppe, park your bike, relax on the beach, or savor local oysters before boarding the ferry to cross the Channel to Newhaven, England. Possibility to have dinner on the ferry and overnight at the hotel in Newhaven. Day 6: Newhaven – Crawley (62 km/ 39 mi.) First day in England begins with a ride along the Newhaven marina toward the stunning cliffs of South Downs. A bit of climbing will take you to breathtaking views as you ride along the top before riding down to a seaside path. For 10km you will enjoy the scenic pathway with immaculate cliffs on one side and the English Channel on the other. Soon you will reach Brighton, a lively destination popular for its pier attractions, cafes, and charming old town called The Lanes. Next the itinerary heads inland through the rolling hills of Devil's Dyke, a legendary valley in the County of Sussex that is said to have been dug by the Devil. You will continue to Crawley, belonging to what is called The Greater London. Overnight at the hotel in Crawley. Day 7: Crawley – London (67 km/ 42 mi.) The last cycling day marks the return to urban life, although our re-entry is gradual. You will start your day cycling across in English countryside, exploring the County of Surrey and into the outskirts of London. The route crosses city parks filled with runners, cyclists, and dog walkers as you will make your way to the city center. River Wandle will lead you to River Thames and to the heart of London. Westminster Abbey will appear like a vision; your first goal is reached! Overnight at the hotel in London. Day 8: day off in London | transfer to Greenwich in public transport (luggage and bike transport provided) You will have a full day to enjoy London and in the afternoon you can decide the best time for you to reach your hotel in Greenwich, ancient village overlooking the south bank River Thames, located only a few kilometers from the center of London. The Royal Observatory stands on the hill overlooking the village. The historic astronomical observatory is the location of Greenwich Prime Meridian for which the village is worldwide known. Overnight at the hotel in Greenwich. Day 9: Greenwich – Canterbury (42 Km/ 26 mi.) After breakfast, you will start cycling along the south bank of the River Thames up to Dartford (31 km). Here you will board a train and travel across the County of Kent to Whitstable (1h20 approximately). Kent is also known as the Garden of England for its green landscapes dotted with some of the most beautiful and famous gardens of the UK. Once in Whitstable, you will ride the last 10km to your day’s destination, Canterbury. This beautiful town is located between Dover and London and it is the starting point of Via Francigena, an ancient pilgrim route running from here to Rome. Despite its medieval past, the city is now lively with students arriving here from all over Europe to attend its important university. The city was the first capital of the Saxon Kingdom of Kent and the seat of the first Christian diocese of England, founded by St. Augustine. The magnificent Christ Church Cathedral dominates the narrow alleys and half-timbered houses of the old medieval city center. Today, after several renovations, the Cathedral is one of the best examples of English Gothic architecture. Overnight at the hotel in Canterbury. Day 10: Canterbury – Dover (50 km/ 32 mi.)| ferry to Dunkirk In the morning you will cycle the 34 km to Dover, famous for its white cliffs and one of the main ports of Great Britain. Here, you will board the ferry to Dunkirk, France (about 2 hours + 1 Time Zone). Once in France, you will ride the 18 km separating the port to the city center, where your hotel is located. Dunkirk is the third most important port in France. It is located in the Nord-Pas de Calais region, 10 km from the border with Belgium. Kite-surfing and the famous surf on the sand are popular activities here. The city center is characterized by low buildings, mainly of the last century, and Flemish influences. The Church of St. Eloi and the two bell towers are included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites and are well worth a visit. Overnight at the hotel in Dunkirk. Day 11: Dunkirk – Bruges (79 km/ 49 mi.) The main part of this stage occurs in Belgium. Several World War II battles took place here along the coast as French and British troops tried to block the German invasion. Once across the France-Belgium border, you will ride across the Flemish green countryside. Cycling along the coast of the North Sea, you will reach Ostend, a popular tourist destination on the Flemish coast characterized by its wide promenade bordered by shops, hotels and restaurants where you can taste excellent mussels, oysters and drink local beers. Your bike tour continues then through the Flanders  and towards the romantic city of Bruges, where time seems to have stopped and everything runs slowly. Thanks to its myriad of canals, it is often referred to as The Venice of the North. Overnight at the hotel in Bruges. Day 12: Bruges – Breskens (45 km/ 28 mi.) | ferry to Vlissingen After breakfast, take some time to visit Bruges. Walking the narrow streets along the canals of the city centre, you will discover historic buildings, pubs serving local craft beers, and chocolate shops. A boat tour through the waterway network could be also a unique and interesting way to discover the city. In the afternoon, you will continue our journey across the countryside Belgian-Dutch border. In Breskens a short ferry transfer will allow you to cross quickly (in about 15 minutes) Scheldt River and reach Vlissingen, your final destination for the day. The promenade on the seafront, called Boulevard, is a long and beautiful walkway where a monumental prison tower dating from the fifteenth century is located. Overnight in Vlissingen. Day 13: Vlissingen – Dordrecht by train | Dordrecht - Vianen (66 km/ 41 mi.) After breakfast, a train transfer (1h30 approximately) will take you to Dordrecht, an elegant river town rich in art, theater life and architecture that gave birth to several accomplished artists including some students Rembrandt's pupils. Your journey continues towards Kinderdijk, a Unesco World Heritage Site and probably the most famous polder of the Netherlands, thanks to the 19 monumental windmills dating back to the 18th  century. Some of the windmills are still functioning and it is possible to visit them. After the visit, you will keep cycling across Dutch countryside until you reach the city of Vianen, in the Province of Utrecht. Overnight at the hotel in Vianen. Day 14: Vianen – Amsterdam (65 km/ 40 mi.) The first break of the day will be in the picturesque and offbeat Utrecht, one of the oldest cities of the Netherlands hosting today a vibrant university life. The old city centre is full of historic mansions now turned into boutiques and cafes overlooking the canals. The last part of the ride will be the introduction to your arrival in Amsterdam, well known for its canals and lined tilting buildings, for the open-minded atmosphere and of course the bicycles! Riding a bike is surely the best way to explore the city and mix up with the locals, but also a canal cruise at sunset is highly recommended. While exploring the city, don't forget to visit Dam Square  and the many museums of art and history like the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum, or Anne Frank House. Overnight at the hotel in Amsterdam. 14291.post_title: G206 - Stockholm to Helsinki Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Stockholm to Helsinki Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: From Stockholm to Helsinki cycling across glorious Åland Archipelago in the company of a group of explorers like you and our expert Tour Leaders.
pods_fields.note: Guided Cycling Trip in International Group
pods_fields.desc:
• Wander supercharming medieval streets of Gamla Stan, in Stockholm.
  • Immerse in a dreamlike atmosphere while sailing Stockholm Archipelago.
  • Discover Åland Islands, un unusual corner of Finland.
  • Cycle across Finnish picturesque landscapes and unspoilt nature.
  • Have a swim in the Baltic Sea.
  • Ride along Helsinki's boulevards overflown with magnificent architecture.
pods_fields.prog: 360 km/224 m. Day 1: Stockholm Individual arrival at the hotel. At 18.00 meeting in the hall with your Tour Leader and the rest of the group for the initial briefing and bicycles delivery Overnight at the hotel in Stockholm. Day 2: Stockholm – Mariehamn (50 km/31 m.) Our trip will start cycling in the streets of Stockholm, across Gamla Stan, Stockholm Old Town, and on shady cycle lanes in Norra begravningsplantsen, Stockholm Père Lachaise. We will then cross Lidingö Bridge and continue for a circular itinerary inside Haga Park, one of the most popular parks of the city hosting some unusual historical buildings such as the Chinese Pavillion and the Turkish Kiosk.  In the afternoon, we will board the ferry to Mariehamn, where we should get late in the evening (at around 11.45 p.m.). Leaving Sweden sailing across dreamlike atmosphere of Stockholm Archipelago will be one of the most amazing parts of this trip. Overnight at the hotel in Mariehamn. Day 3: Mariehamn  - Circular Tour of Fasta Åland Island (60 km/37 m.) We will wake up in the lively capital of Fasta Åland, the biggest of the approximately 6500 islands composing the Archipelago. This is an autonomous territory under Finnish sovereignty whereas the official language is Swedish. During this stage we’ll go exploring part of the island, well-known for its white-sand beaches and flat scenic cycling routes. We will cycle across the countryside among typical wooden houses painted in bright colors, across coniferous forests and along the coast. This will be our chance to dive into Baltic Sea. In the afternoon, return to Mariehamn. Overnight at the hotel in Mariehamn. Day 4: Mariehamn – Turku (40 km/25 m.) In the morning we will explore another section of Fasta Åland. This time we will ride west crossing picturesque landscapes and beautiful forests. An itinerary along the granite coast and across bridges will take us to the extreme point of the island. In the afternoon we will take the ferry to Turku (arrival at about 19.50). Ancient capital of Finland, Turku is the oldest town of the country, but with a vibrant contemporary soul animating art galleries, museums, restaurants and music festivals. We suggest to have a stroll along the river, towards the Castle and majestic Cathedral. Overnight at the hotel in Turku. Day 5: Turku – Salo by train and Salo – Ekenäs (77 km/48 m.) Right after breakfast, a short train ride (approximately 30 mins) will bring us to Salo, vibrant small town. From here we will start cycling East across Finnish natural landscapes. Final destination of the day is Ekenäs (or Tammisaari, in Finnish), an ancient fishing village where the streets and some of the wooden houses have remained the same since 16th century. For lunch, we suggest to have a picnic on the seashore. Overnight at the hotel in Tammisaari. Day 6: Ekenäs – Västerby (64 km/40 m.) Approaching to Helsinki, we will be cycling both along the coast and inland, experiencing the Finnish unspoiled nature up to Västerby, located among lakes and coniferous or birch forests. Overnight at the hotel in Västerby. Day 7: Västerby – Helsinki (66 km/41 m.) Here we are, last pedal strokes before reaching Helsinki, capital of Finland, sitting between the Baltic Sea and the architectural wonders of the city. As soon as we will get there, we’ll spend some time exploring the city centre. Overnight at the hotel in Helsinki. Day 8: Helsinki After breakfast, end of services.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: Terrain: flat to hilly. Daily stages between 40 and 77 km. Expected cycling time: between 3,5 and 5,5 hours per day. A good physical condition and a minimum training is requested for this tour. Surface: 60% asphalt, 30% unpaved country roads. Luggage transport: yes, 1 piece per person - 20 kg max and Support Service Plus. Participants: minimum 12. Suitable for children: no. Pets: not allowed. Bicycles: 24 speeds aluminum unisex bikes (for up to 175 cm.) or diamond frame bikes (for 175 cm. and above), disc brakes, front suspension, anti-puncture tires, gel saddle, ergonomic handlebar grips, lateral pannier bag, handlebar bag. Possibility to hire helmets at the cost of €15 (to be booked in advance and paid locally). Rental contract to be signed on the spot. Possibility to request Bicycle Coverage for Damage and Theft. Starting point of this tour: Stockholm, on day 1 (no cycling itinerary for this day). Finishing point of this tour: Helsinki, on day 8.

14268.post_title: L109 - Cycling on the vintage Eroica backroads

pods_fields.titolo: Cycling on the vintage Eroica backroads
pods_fields.desc_min: Exploring the genuine essence of Tuscany while discovering Bartali and Coppi’s world. A legendary ride among gentle hills, towered villages and traditional gastronomy.
pods_fields.desc: The Permanent Route of L'Eroica is a unique experience allowing you to live the adventure of the vintage race “L'Eroica” all year round. The route measures a total of 205 km, crossing the very heart of  Siena, Chianti region, Crete Senesi and Val d'Orcia, and letting you discover the authentic Tuscany with its wines and gastronomy. It is a journey into the very essence of the legendary Tuscan landscape, characterized by challenging technical features making this route a great opportunity of ideal cycling. The route alternates paved and gravel roads, and has a total elevation gain of around 3500 meters. White roads cover around 112 km of the track and the length of each stage is between 40 and 50 km, so you will also have the chance to enjoy the trip, admiring the gentle Tuscan hills and immersing yourself into this landscape.
pods_fields.prog: Total  distance 207 km/ 129 mi 1° day: Siena Individual arrival and accommodation in hotel 3*close Siena city center. 2° day: Siena – Montalcino    49 km/30 mi,  +1030 m After breakfast you will receive road book, maps and all useful information for your daily stages. Immediately after leaving the city of Siena you’ll ride through a very typical segment of the route, located between “Colle Malamerenda” and Radi, deep in the gentle hills of Siena, studded of farm houses, medieval villages, merging your ride with the Via Francigena itinerary. The village of Murlo will be the background to the easiest segment of the whole permanent route. Climbing to Castiglion del Bosco, one of the most engaging segments of L’Eroica permanent route, you will reach Montalcino over the beautiful and panoramic lands of the Brunello of Montalcino wine. Also famous for olive oil and honey, the village of Montalcino is worth a visit, especially for admiring the incredible panorama on the Val d’Orcia region. Accommodation in 3* hotel. 3° day: Montalcino – Buonconvento   40 km/25 mi,  +490 m The descent from Montalcino will be a delicious dive into vineyards, bringing you through smooth, pristine hills until Lucignano d’Asso, where you can take a rest having a typical snack or just the time to refill your bottle. Pedaling through Val d'Orcia landscape is a joy for eyes and mind, it restores the fatigue caused by the ups and downs. With a diversion from the normal permanent route you can visit Pienza, located in the heart of Val d’Orcia, UNESCO site.  Accommodation in typical Tuscan agriturismo (country hotel) offering  Health & Beauty Centre, Horse Riding, Indoor and Outdoor Swimming Pools. The typical restaurant offers genuine, traditional Tuscan cuisine cooked using farm grown organic products. 4° day: Buonconvento – Castelnuovo Berardenga    42 km/26 mi, +700 m From the vineyards and rolling hills to the suggestion of the lunar landscape is a short step!  Left the villages along the Cassia to immerse you in the Crete Senesi with the characteristic gullies. The oak and cypress indicate isolated farms where cheese is produced and tables are enriched by the diamond of Crete Senesi: the white truffle. This part of the route includes the hard white road of Monte Sante Marie, a well known steep road that will take you back into the Chianti area. Accommodation in typical Tuscan agriturismo with pool and restaurant. 5° day: Castelnuovo Berardenga – Gaiole    44 km/27,5 mi,  +850 m A sort of summary of all you've seen and an anticipation of what you will get across can be found along  the road to Pianella, presenting different landscapes. The road to Radda in Chianti will be a sequence of vineyards and woods, passing through nice villages and farms offering a wide range of typical products and tastings; wine and olive oil will be temptations that will delight your itinerary and your senses. The village of Radda in Chianti deserves a stroll through its nice little alleys. After Radda you’ll be headed to Gaiole, the village where L’Eroica was born in 1997, going down through Vertine, a nice little pearl of the Chianti region. Accommodation in a typical Bed and Breakfast with swimming pool. 6° day: Gaiole – Siena   32 km/20 km, + 500 m The official route of L’Eroica starts in Gaiole in Chianti, winding among historical vineyards leading to Castello di Brolio with its cypress access road. The breath-taking panorama below the walls, over the vineyards, represents one of the most wonderful parts of the permanent route. After a few kilometers, near San Giovanni a Cerreto, Siena will be outlined on the horizon. The ordinates cultivation of vines is fading into a more various landscape, painted in terra di Siena color. The visit of this wonderful medieval city with the Dome, Piazza del Campo and the perfect medieval city center will make your trip special. Accommodation in 3* hotel located very close to Siena city center. 7° day : Siena Breakfast and Eroica graduation: you will receive your personal diploma of “Eroici”, souvenir of an incredible ride!
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: Terrain: hilly to mountainous terrain with climbs and descents, what requires good physical condition; travel time:  from 3h to 5h per day. Cycling experience  and a good training are required for this tour. Roads: Minor roads. 50%  dirty roads. Bike: hybrid trekking bikes ( in case you bring your own bike we suggest knobby tires for an efficient ride on unpaved roads). GPS rental possible (not included). 13516.post_title: L099 - Gastronomic experience and nature: from Bologna to Ferrara and Ravenna

pods_fields.titolo: Gastronomic experience and nature: from Bologna to Ferrara and Ravenna
pods_fields.part_sum: 2019: on Saturdays from 06/04 to 29/06/2019 and from 31/08/2019 to 26/10/2019
pods_fields.desc_min: Romagna is the land of hospitality, of good food and good life, of parties and colorful "riviera" beach resorts. This tour gives you the chance to pedal through it while discovering the masterpieces of its art cities and the rich diversity of its natural landscapes, between cultivated areas, wetlands and ancient woods.
pods_fields.desc:
Starting from Bologna, capital of the Emilia Romagna region and imaginary border between the two souls of this area, the tour focuses on the exploration of one of the two. Romagna is the land of hospitality, of good food, of parties and beach resorts along the “riviera romagnola” and their colorful  sun umbrellas. Here you have the chance to taste the typical piadina with squacquerone cheese, passatelli served with beef stock, maltagliati and strozzapreti pasta and all different kinds of cascione, a typical savory pastry, not to mention the range of DOP wines with which to pair these courses, such as Sangiovese, Albana  and Trebbiano. This land, reclaimed from the sea throughout the centuries, can offer nowadays a great abundance of naturalistic highlights. In the wetlands right behind the coastline, hundreds of different species of birds build their nests every year and pink flamingoes found their perfect settlement in the low waters of the marshes, becoming a well-known symbol of the area around Comacchio. Along this itinerary, art is an important asset, too. You will visit the Medieval center of Bologna, still intact and showcasing its famous many towers. Bologna is also known both as “the wise” and “the fat”: the first nickname comes from the fact that the first university of the Western world was founded here in 1088 and it has been in place ever since; the second one is due to its culinary tradition, so nourishing and rich as a generous dish of tagliatelle with the famous bolognaise sauce. Heading East from Bologna, you will arrive in Ferrara, where you follow the ancient walls of the city, still protecting from the dangers of the outer world the beautiful center and the imposing Este castle. Then, the unique mosaic works of Ravenna will simply leave you wordless. Moreover, this city hosts 8 monuments enlisted as UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

This tour is a pleasant cycling exploration of a hard-working, flourishing yet tranquil region of Italy, where everything reflects the good Italian living, both if  we look at how the historical and artistic heritage is cherished and maintained and at how gastronomy and food have a special place in everybody’s heart and agenda.
pods_fields.prog: Total km 326  Day 1: Bologna Independent arrival in Bologna. Welcome briefing. You are free for dinner; overnight in Bologna. Day 2 : Bologna – Ferrara (69 km) Right after breakfast, you start your exploration by pedaling through the most typical countryside of the Pianura Padana, the big flatland area characterizing a conspicuous portion of Emilia Romagna region. Fields of crops, ancient reclamation canals and long rows of poplars alternate each other while passing through many small historical towns. We enter the county of Ferrara and here the itinerary follows one of the many branches of the Po River, Po di Primaro, until this crosses with another branch, the Po di Volano, right beyond the walls of the ancient capital of the domain of the House of Este, Ferrara. Ferrara is also the “city of bicycles”: we suggest you to visit its old center with the imposing Castle, the beautiful Duomo  and the unique Palazzo dei Diamanti, where important art exhibitions are usually hosted. And do not forget to take an evening stroll through the Jewish Quarter, which inspired “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” book an subsequent movie. You are free for dinner, overnight in Ferrara.  Day 3: Ferrara – Comacchio (59 km) You leave Ferrara following the walls of the old city and you start penetrating the local countryside, which already starts to show the first signs of belonging to the Delta of the River Po area. Following the course of Po di Volano, you reach the Vallette di Ostellato natural oasis. The four meanders of the watercourse form a biotope that is one of a kind, mainly thanks to the big amount and variety of wildlife having found their habitat here, among which more than 150 species of waterfowl. You then pedal towards Comacchio, one of the most evocative towns of the Delta area, with its famous Trepponti three-branched bridge. Also visit Manifattura dei Marinati, the workshop where eels fished in the local water valleys are slowly cooked on huge skewers and then marinated. Do not forget to taste the local cuisine, with peculiar fish and eels courses, and Bosco Eliceo DOC wines. You are free for dinner, overnight in Comacchio. Day 4: Comacchio – Ravenna (44 km) In the morning light, the water valleys of Comacchio, with its large colony of pink flamingoes, offer a stunning mix of shades and colors over the shallow waters. You cycle around the vast basin of the valley and then reach the sea in Casalborsetti. The itinerary then starts following the coastline southward, crossing Porto Corsini and Marina di Ravenna, then heading again inland to reach the city of Ravenna, world-known for its mosaics. Eight are the UNESCO monuments you can visit here: the Basilica of San Vitale, the Mausoleo of Galla Placidia, the Battistero Neoniano, the Cappella of Sant’Andrea, the Battistero of the Ariani, the Basilica of Sant’Apollinare Nuovo, the Mausoleum of Theodoric and the Basilica of Sant’Apollinare in Classe. We also suggest you to visit the Domus dei Tappeti di Pietra (literally “the house of the stone carpets”), a mosaic flooring ensemble dating back to the VI century and brought to light only in 1994. Foodwise, you enter the land of “piadina romagnola” and “passateli”, always to be enjoyed with a glass of Sangiovese. You are free for dinner, overnight in Ravenna. Day 5: Ravenna – Forlimpopoli (55 km) The course of the tour heads again towards the sea, crossing part of the Regional Park of the Delta of the Po River and the beautiful pinewoods of Lido di Classe until you reach Milano Marittima, one of the most known seaside resorts of the Riviera romagnola coastline. Then, you follow the course of the Savio River to go back towards the countryside, with its endless fields of crops and sunflowers. The final destination of today’s stage is Forlimpopoli, a city founded by Romans on the ancient route Via Emilia and once accommodating pilgrims on their way to Rome. This is the birthplace of the Italian scholar and gastronome Pellegrino Artusi, undisputed father of the “Italian cuisine”. The monumental location of the Chiesa dei Servi houses today Casa Artusi, a research center focusing on gastronomy and home cooking traditions. Here you can taste traditional dishes or attend cooking classes in the prestigious school. You are free for dinner, overnight in agriturismo close to Forlimpopoli.  Day 6 : Forlimpopoli – Imola (51 km) Following the direction of the Roman Via Emilia, you soon reach the city of Forlì. Thanks to its artistic heritage, this location deservers a stop: visit the Romanic Basilica of San Mercuriale with its XII century bell tower, Palazzo del Podestà and Palazzo Albertini dating back to the fourteenth century and the museum area of San Domenico, hosting the Pinacoteca and important traveling art exhibitions.  Moving westward on the Via Emilia, you arrive in Faenza, the international capital of ceramics. As a matter of fact, “faience” is often used in many European languages to describe glazed earthenware or pottery, especially a fine variety with highly colored designs. Beside the Museum of Ceramics, here you can also find more than 60 workshops where craftsmen and artists give shape to certified local pottery. The final destination for today is Imola, the following city along the Via Emilia, where the fortress dating back to the XII century stands out in the very heart of the town. Imola is also famous around the world for its Formula One racing circuit. You are free for dinner, overnight in Imola. Day 7: Imola - Bologna (48 km) Pedaling on the backroads in between the ancient Via Emilia and the Appennino hills, we cross the towns of Castel San Pietro, Ozzano and San Lazzaro di Savena. We cycle along the border of the Regional Park of the Gessi Bolognesi and Calanchi dell’Abbadessa, characterized by some peculiar geological features and gypsum formations,  and we reach our departing and arrival destination of this circular tour: Bologna. Named by the Romans Bononia, during the Medieval Age the ancient walls surrounded the heart of the city, that used to count more than 100 towers. Nowadays only few towers are left, among which the two that are still the symbol of Bologna, Garisenda and Asinelli. The city center itself is still well preserved and it is one of the biggest you can visit in Europe. Enjoy a stroll through Piazza Maggiore and visit the Basilica of San Petronio and the Seven Churches complex. You are also in a place that is known all over Italy if not the world for its rich gastronomic traditions and culture. Bolognaise sauce (actually called “ragù”) takes its name from Bologna, so does mortadella, also known worldwide as “bologna”. Here you will have the chance to taste its original – gourmet – taste. Then, tortellini, lasagna and tagliatelle will fill in the rest of the room on the table, and in your stomach. If you plan to attend a cooking class on how to prepare hand-made pasta, you are certainly in the right place. Pair everything up with a glass of Pignoletto DOC wine produced on the hills right behind the city and enjoy the Italian good living style. You are free for dinner, overnight in Bologna. Day 8: Bologna After breakfast, the tour ends.

13468.post_title: L104 - Cycling from Verona to Florence along the Eurovelo 7

pods_fields.titolo: Cycling from Verona to Florence along Eurovelo 7
pods_fields.part_sum: 2019 on Saturdays, from 06/04 to 29/06/2019 and from 31/08 to 26/10/2019
pods_fields.desc_min: Along the Sun Route, from Verona to Mantua, Bologna and then Florence: each city will surprise you with the richness, the peculiarity and  the variety of its monuments and works of art. Cosy villages suspended between the present and the past and typical farms and courts animate the hard-working soul of the countryside.
pods_fields.desc: A new itinerary throughout some of the highlights of the regions Veneto, Lombardy, Emilia Romagna and Tuscany. From Verona to Florence, you cycle Southward along the Italian Boot plunging yourselves in suggestive landscapes and sceneries that have been the setting of countless masterpieces of literature and cinema. You start your tour from Verona, the city of Romeo and Juliet, where you can not only admire the iconic balcony where one of the most popular scenes of Shakespeare’s masterpiece took place but also the Roman Arena, famous worldwide for its agenda of lyrical events. The next stop is Mantua, beautifully built by the Gonzaga Family at the crossing of three lakes and setting of one of the marvellous operas of the composer Giuseppe Verdi, Rigoletto. Palazzo Ducale, Piazza delle Erbe e and Palazzo Te are definitely on the to-do list here. Then, you head to Modena, with its cathedral that is a masterpiece of the Romanesque architecture and the Ghirlandina bell tower. This is also the land of Pavarotti and Ferraris, not to mention good food. You might have seen glimpses of its suggestive town center on the many shows about Chef Massimo Bottura, who has its restaurant Osteria Francescana here. As the last step before leaving the flat countryside of the Pianura Padana and crossing over the Appennini mountains, you visit Bologna, home of the first university  of the Western world, founded in 1088 and still active today. The Two Towers Garisenda and Asinelli and Piazza Maggiore with the imposing Basilica of San Petronio are only some of the views you cannot miss. With a little help from the local train, you start your crossing from Emilia Romagna to Tuscany. Your final destination is Florence, quintessence of Italian art and culture and also cradle of the Renaissance. Palazzo Vecchio, the Duomo and Giottos’s bell tower, the goldsmith workshops on Ponte Vecchio, the refined statues of Piazza della Signoria and the collections at Uffizi Gallery: Firenze is enchanting. The itinerary you will go through follows a stretch of the Eurovelo 7 track, also known as the Sun Route. The Eurovelo 7 route runs from Cape North to the island of Malta and is part of the Eurovelo project created by the European Cyclists’ Federation with the aim to build a trans-European network of high-quality cycling routes. The itinerary of this tour from Verona to Florence appeals to everyone: you will be fascinated by historical and artistic attractions, cosy villages suspended between the present and the past, naturalistic assets, the traditional hospitality of these places and the local gastronomy, with simple and genuine tastes, so are the inhabitants of these regions.
pods_fields.prog: Total km 292 Day 1: Verona Individual arrival in Verona, a city known all over the world for the Arena, where every year important concerts and operas are held. Don’t miss a stroll through the small ways of the centre to discover the traces of Romeo and Juliet. Overnight in Verona. Day 2 : Verona – Mantua (61 or 74 km) In the first part of the day, you will reach Peschiera del Garda, a pentagonal city located in the northern part of Lake Garda. Its town centre is surrounded by Venetian high walls encircled by water. Heading out of the city, you will go South following Mincio River, through less known areas in the midst of the idyllic countryside. After crossing  Borghetto sul Mincio, a peculiar village, born as an islet between the loops of Mincio River, you will reach Mantua, an extremely fascinating city located at the crossing between three lakes and the river Mincio. Mantua has an important cultural centre rich in history and monuments, such as Palazzo Ducale and its Bridal Chamber painted by Mantegna and Palazzo Te. Day 3: Mantua – Mirandola (59 km) Heading out of Mantua, you will cross the plain to reach San Benedetto Po, one of the most beautiful villages in Italy, extending in the silence of the countryside, with oratories, abbeys, small chapels, cheese workshops and agricultural courts scattered around. Here you can also see the old drainage system used by monks to reclaim the lands from the water. After crossing to the opposite bank of Secchia River, you enter Emilia Romagna. Today’s destination is Mirandola, home town of the humanistic philosopher Pico. Day 4: Mirandola – Modena (54 km) Today you ride through the “bassa modenese”, the suggestive flatland countryside outside Modena and all around River Secchia. This area has been seriously damaged by the earthquake of 2012 and it is showing the strong will and hard-working mind-set of its inhabitants through a flourishing recovery. Reaching Modena, don’t miss a small tour in the city centre: the Cathedral and its famous bell tower Ghirlandina, enlisted as UNESCO Heritage,  are worth a visit. Be tempted by the local cuisine: “tortelli”, cold cuts and “gnocco fritto” is something you definitely want to try. Day 5: Modena – Bologna (55 km) Heading out of Modena, you will plunge into the countryside and the fruit orchards: this scenery surrounds you along the cycle path. Enjoy the ride at peace, away from the noise and the traffic, to reach Bologna, the capital of Emilia Romagna region. Here tradition and modernity are perfectly combined: you can stroll in Piazza Maggiore, admire the most ancient buildings dating back to Medieval times, and perceive the cultural atmosphere which animates this city, always ready to welcome new artistic and cultural hints. Day 6: Bologna – Vaiano (by train) – Florence (41 km) A small transfer by train (about 1 hour) brings you to the small town of Vaiano, on the Bisenzio River, crossing the Appennini mountains and the border between Emilia Romagna and Tuscany. From Vaiano, you start descending towards Florence, cycling through a landscape which seems to be projected by a nature and art lover. Here, country houses, castles, abbeys and even the tiniest church of the countryside expresses art in its purest form. You end your tour in Florence, international capital of arts, where you can visit museums, galleries or you can simply enjoy a stroll along the river Arno, at  sunset. Day 7: Florence After breakfast the tour ends.
