13309.post_title: L276 - Copenhagen to Oslo self-guided cycling trip

pods_fields.titolo: Copenhagen to Oslo self-guided cycling trip
pods_fields.part_sum: on request, for small groups of at least 12 people.
pods_fields.desc_min: A self-guided cycling trip connecting two European capitals and three Scandinavian countries. An inspiring ride through Nature, Art and endless sunsets.
pods_fields.desc:
• Enjoy unique beauty of Scandinavian Nature and Design.
  • Visit one of the best European Art Museums: Louisiana Museum of Modern Art where art, architecture and nature form a perfect unity.
  • Cycle the Kattegatleden, the cycle route connecting Helsingborg to Gothenburg and running across the unique setting of Swedish Halland Coast.
  • Enjoy endless sunsets offered in Summer by Northern light.
  • Explore some of the most bike friendly cities in Europe such as Copenhagen, Gothenburg and Oslo.
  • Rest in beautiful Scandinavian Design Hotels, carefully selected for you.
  • Try our Travel App MyEasyRoute and experience a no worries cycling trip across Northern Europe.
pods_fields.prog: 359 km/225 m. Day 1: Copenhagen Individual arrival at the hotel. At 18.00 meeting in the hall with a member of our staff for the initial briefing and bicycles delivery. Overnight at the hotel in Copenhagen. We suggest to spend some time visiting the city. Tivoli Gardens, Charlottenborg Palace, and Kogens Have (King's Gardens) are worth a visit. The perfect place to end your day in Copenhagen is the picturesque Nyhavn Harbour, where you can take pictures and enjoy a drink or dinner on the harbor. Day 2: Copenhagen – Helsingør + Ferry to Helsingborg (48 Km/30 m.) You'll start the trip cycling the streets of Copenhagen and right outside the city centre, you'll start following the the coast. The ride continues in sight of beautiful mansions (one is Karen Blixen's house) until Dyrehaven Park, once used by Danish Royals as hunting ground. In Humlebæk we warmly suggest to make a stop at the Louisiana Museum, one of the most important European Museums of Modern Art and architecture master chief where art and nature melt in the most harmonious way. In the afternoon, you’ll reach Helsingør and its Kronborg fortress, used by Shakespeare as setting for his tragedy Hamlet. A ferry will take you then quickly to Sweden. Overnight at the hotel in Helsigborg. Day 3: Helsingborg – Båstad (63 km/39,5 m.) Before leaving Helsingborg, you’ll ride along the city centre and pass by Kärnan tower, remains of the medieval castle that once stood on the harbor. The itinerary continues then for a while along Helsingborg seafront, crosses an agricultural area dotted with farms and lakes and reaches Ängelholm, in the middle of Skälderviken bay, renowned destination among wave and wind surfers. From here, you’ll keep riding along the coast and across beautiful landscapes, coves, fishing villages and forests. Final destination of this stage: Båstad, one of Sweden’s most popular Summer resorts. Overnight at the hotel in Båstad. Day 4: Båstad – Varberg by train and Varberg – Kungsbacka (63 km/39,5 m.) After breakfast, a train transfer will take you from Båstad to Varberg (approx. 1 hour). From the imposing Varberg fortress, you’ll take Kattegatleden, gorgeous 370 km cycle path connecting Helsingborg to Göteborg and running along Halland coast. Expect a relaxing ride along endless sandy beaches. In the afternoon you’ll move inland and cross the Nature Reserve at Fjärås Bräcka, a moraine hill covered with bushes and prairies, dotted with Iron Age menhirs and overviewing Lyngern Lake. A last ride across Swedish countryside, will take you to the coastal town of Kungsbacka, with Tjolöholm castle and landscaped gardens. Overnight at the hotel in Kungsbacka. Day 5: Kungsbacka – Gothenburg (44 km/27,50 m.) and Gothenburg – Halden by train After breakfast, you’ll start riding out of town and along a rocky and very jagged coast, dotted with multicolored beach huts. We suggest to have lunch break in Gothenburg, the second-largest city in Sweden, considered as a valid alternative to Stockholm. Go and buy food at Saluhallen, the biggest indoor market where you can find a good amount of typical delicacies and have coffee in Haga, the oldest neighborhood in Gothenburg. Train transfer from Gothenburg to Halden (approx. 2 hours), in Norway. Overnight at the hotel in Halden. Day 6: Halden – Moss (66 km/41 m.) After breakfast, you’ll start cycling across Norwegian countryside and coniferous forests, to reach the first fjord of this trip: Skjeberkilen. In the afternoon, you’ll reach Moss, final destination of the day. We warmly suggest you to have an extra ride up to Galerie F15, one of the oldest art institutions in Norway, located on Jeløy Island, a sort of Paradise on Earth, made of large green spaces, old farms, forests and blissful views of Oslofjord. Overnight at the hotel in Moss. Day 7: Moss – Oslo (75 km/47 m.) A last ride across Norwegian coniferous forests will take you to the old village of Son, while a beautiful plateau dotted with farms and raspberry fields will be the perfect introduction to the Oslo Fjord. When in Oslo, we recommend a stroll on the roof of the beautiful Opera House and a beer break: near the central station, they serve expensive, but excellent IPAs. In the evening, walk up to the Nobel Peace Center and Aker Brygge wharf, a modern pedestrian area along the waterfront with restaurants, shops and views on the Marina and the Oslo Fjord. Take a seat near the water and simply enjoy the eternal sunset of Norwegian Summer. Overnight at the hotel in Oslo. Day 8: Oslo After breakfast, end of services.

12955.post_title: L095 - Eurovelo 5: cycling along Via Romea Francigena from Milan to Parma

pods_fields.titolo: Eurovelo 5: cycling along Via Romea Francigena from Milan to Parma
pods_fields.desc_min: Retrace the steps of the pilgrims traveling from Canterbury to Rome following the stretch of route going from Milan to Parma and discover the richness of this land in art and food.
pods_fields.desc: The Eurovelo 5 – Via Romea Francigena follows one of the biggest pilgrimage routes of Europe. Via Romea Francigena travelled all the way to Rome from Northern Europe. The full itinerary starts from Canterbury and leads to Rome, the very heart of the Catholic church, and then Brindisi, where people used to set sail for Holy Land.Today’s cycle route is 3300 km long and connects 7 different European countries and 21 UNESCO world heritage sites. This new route is intended to cycle through the ancient pathway of the pilgrims. Along the way, there are many historical sites dating back to the Middle Age, as this tour sums up the rich cultural heritage pertaining to this road. In the stretch of route from Milan to Parma, you can encounter some of the milestones in the way of an ancient pilgrim: the Cathedrals of Milan and Fidenza, the Basilica of St. Anthony in Piacenza, the  Certosa of Pavia, the abbey of Chiaravalle della Colomba, the Cathedral ad Battistero di Parma and many more. The itinerary we suggest starts and ends in two important historical Italian cities, respectively Milan and Parma, and offers the chance to discover the lowlands characterizing this area. Agriculture and breeding have only been  thriving in this area, offering you a unique chance to taste some of the most known Italian specialties: Parmigiano cheese , Parma ham, Culatello, Gutturnio wine are only a few. The tour appeals to everyone; the terrain is gently hilly and flat and routes are not too long.
pods_fields.prog: Total km 170 Day 1: Individual arrival in Milan We suggest you to take the time to visit the magnificent gothic cathedral, the 3rd largest Cristian church in the world, Vittorio Emanuele Gallery, the Scala Theatre and the square, Sempione Park, Sforza Castle, Corso Vittorio Emanuele and one of the most famous shopping streets of the city: Via Monte Napoleone. Do not miss Navigli district, ideal for an aperitivo or dinner. Overnight at the hotel in Milan. Day 2: Milan - Pavia (37 km) Heading out of Milan, you’ll cycle through the countryside, along the Parco Agricolo Sud, a regional park focusing on the development and safeguard of local agriculture. You will see a delightful landscape divided between land and water. Along the path, you can stop and visit the Certosa of Pavia, a 14th century abbey a few kilometers out of the present city of Pavia. Once you arrive in the city itself, discover its rich history through the visit to the Visconti Castle and the Basilica. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Pavia. Day 3: Pavia – Orio Litta (52 km) After breakfast, you can further discover Pavia’s city center with the majestic castle built by Galeazzo Visconti in 1360 and the cathedral. Your itinerary then goes through the Basso Pavese lowlands and follows the River Ticino first and the River Po later, the longest river in Italy from which, thanks to the constant flow of debris from the Alps, the lowlands took shape. Arriving in Orio Litta, visit the Grangia Benedettina, an ancient abbey dating back to 1000 AD, and the beautiful Villa Litta. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Orio Litta. Day 4: Orio Litta - Fiorenzuola (57 Km) After breakfast, the itinerary, on a gravel path, leads to Guado of Corte Sant’Andrea, where pilgrims would ford the River Po. From here, you’ll go on cycling following the right bank of Po River, till San Rocco al Porto and then Piacenza. We suggest you visiting the roman Basilica of St. Savino and seeing the mosaics dating back to 12th century. Then, you’ll cycle through the countryside along the ancient Roman road Via Emilia; here you can visit Paderna castle. Minor roads will lead you to Fiorenzuola. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Fiorenzuola. Day 5: Fiorenzuola - Parma (54 Km) Following the cycle path leading out of Fiorenzuola, you’ll encounter the Cistercian Abbey of Chiaravalle della Colomba, and its suggestive cloister. The route goes then on cycling through minor roads up to Fidenza: the roman St. Donnino Cathedral is worth visiting. You’ll cross the Regional Park of the River Taro  and you will arrive in Parma. You can visit the Cathedral and the famous Badessa’s Room, painted by Correggio, the Baptistery, commissioned to Benedetto Antelami, the precious works by Parmigianino in the National Gallery and the Farnese Theatre. Dinner in a typical trattoria and overnight at the hotel in Parma. Day 6: Parma Tour ends after breakfast.

11388.post_title: G276 - Cycling from Copenhagen to Oslo

pods_fields.titolo: Cycling from Copenhagen to Oslo
pods_fields.desc_min: A cycling trip between two European capitals and across three Scandinavian countries. An inspiring ride through Nature, Art, Design and endless sunsets.
pods_fields.note: Guided cycling trip in International group
pods_fields.desc:
• Enjoy unique beauty of Scandinavian Nature and Design.
  • Visit one of the best European Art Museums: Louisiana Museum of Modern Art where art, architecture and nature form a perfect unity.
  • Cycle the Kattegatleden, the cycle route connecting Helsingborg to Gothenburg and running across the unique setting of Swedish Halland Coast.
  • Enjoy endless sunsets offered in Summer by Northern light.
  • Explore some of the most bike friendly cities in Europe such as Copenhagen, Gothenburg and Oslo.
  • Rest in beautiful Scandinavian Design Hotels, carefully selected for you.
pods_fields.prog: 359 km/225 m. Day 1: Copenhagen Individual arrival at the hotel. At 18.00 meeting in the hall with your Tour Leader and the rest of the group for the initial briefing and bicycles delivery. Overnight at the hotel in Copenhagen. We suggest to spend some time visiting the city. Tivoli Gardens, Charlottenborg Palace, and Kogens Have (King's Gardens) are worth a visit. The perfect place to end your day in Copenhagen is the picturesque Nyhavn Harbour, where you can take pictures and enjoy a drink or dinner on the harbor.  Day 2: Copenhagen – Helsingør + Ferry to Helsingborg (48 Km/30 m.) We'll start our trip cycling the streets of Copenhagen and right outside the city centre, we'll start following the coast. The ride continues in sight of beautiful mansions (one is Karen Blixen's house) until we enter Dyrehaven Park, once used by Danish Royals as hunting ground. In Humlebæk we’ll make a stop at the Louisiana Museum, one of the most important European Museums of Modern Art and architecture master chief, where art and nature melt in the most harmonious way. In the afternoon, we’ll reach Helsingør and its Kronborg fortress, used by Shakespeare as setting for his tragedy Hamlet. A ferry will take us then quickly to Sweden. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Helsigborg. Day 3: Helsingborg – Båstad (63 km/39,5 m.) Before leaving Helsingborg, we’ll ride along the city centre and pass by the Kärnan tower, remains of the medieval castle that once stood on the harbor. Our itinerary continues then for a while along Helsingborg seafront, crosses an agricultural area dotted with farms and lakes and reaches Ängelholm, in the middle of Skälderviken bay, renowned destination among wave and wind surfers. After a short break, we’ll keep riding along the coast and across beautiful landscapes, coves, fishing villages and forests. Final destination of this stage: Båstad, one of Sweden’s most popular Summer resorts. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Båstad. Day 4: Båstad – Varberg by train and Varberg – Kungsbacka (63 km/39,5 m.) After breakfast, we'll have a train transfer from Båstad to Varberg (approx. 1 hour). From the imposing Varberg fortress, we’ll take Kattegatleden, a gorgeous 370 km cycle path connecting Helsingborg to Gothenburg and running along the Halland coast. Expect a relaxing ride along endless sandy beaches and typical beach huts. In the afternoon we’ll move inland and cross the Nature Reserve at Fjärås Bräcka, a moraine hill covered with bushes and prairies, dotted with Iron Age menhirs and overviewing Lyngern Lake. A last ride across Swedish countryside, will take us to the coastal town of Kungsbacka, with Tjolöholm castle and landscaped gardens. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Kungsbacka. Day 5: Kungsbacka – Gothenburg (44 km/27,50 m.) and Gothenburg – Halden by train After breakfast, we’ll start riding out of town and along a rocky and very jagged coast, dotted with multicoloured beach huts. Lunch break will be in Gothenburg, the second-largest city in Sweden, considered as a valid alternative to Stockholm. We suggest to go and buy lunch at Saluhallen, the biggest indoor market where you can find a good amount of typical delicacies and to have coffee in Haga, the oldest neighborhood in Gothenburg. Train transfer from Gothenburg to Halden (approx. 2 hours), in Norway. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Halden. Day 6: Halden – Moss (66 km/41 m.) After breakfast, we’ll start cycling across Norwegian countryside and forests, to reach our first fjord: Skjeberkilen. In the afternoon, we’ll reach Moss, final destination of the day.  Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Moss. Day 7: Moss – Oslo (75 km/47 m.) A last ride across Norwegian coniferous forests will take us to the old village of Son, while a beautiful plateau dotted with farms and raspberry fields will be the perfect introduction to the Oslo Fjord. When in Oslo, we recommend a stroll on the roof of the beautiful Opera House and a beer break: near the central station, they serve expensive, but excellent IPAs. In the evening, walk up to the Nobel Peace Center and Aker Brygge wharf, a modern pedestrian area along the waterfront with restaurants, shops and views on the Marina and the Oslo Fjord. Take a seat near the water and simply enjoy the eternal sunset of Norwegian Summer. Dinner not included. Overnight at the hotel in Oslo. Day 8: Oslo After breakfast, end of services.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: Terrain: flat or undulated and slightly hilly in Norway. Daily stages between 44 and 75 km per day. Expected cycling time: 3,5 to 5,5 hours per day. Surface: 80% asphalt, 20% unpaved country roads. Bikes: city bikes. Participants: minimum 10. Luggage transport: yes. 1 piece per person - 20 kg max. This trip also includes Support Service Plus. Suitable for children: no.

10268.post_title: G300 - Bike and Boat in the Gulf of Naples and the Amalfi Coast

pods_fields.titolo: Bike and Boat in the Gulf of Naples and the Amalfi Coast
pods_fields.part_sum: all Saturdays from 27/04 to 22/06/2019 and from 31/08 to 12/10/2019 (included)
pods_fields.desc_min: Exploring the Amalfi Coast by land and sea is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Cycle, walk, swim, live this unique corner of Italy.
pods_fields.note: Guided Tour in International Group with English speaking Tour Leader
pods_fields.desc: This is a journey that will take place both on land and on water, investigating the natural treasures and cultural heritage of which the Amalfi Coast and the Gulf of Naples are dense. A cruise on board of a ship that has all the style of the ancient caique, a type of boat that is a legend itself, just as it is the sea under your feet. This tour is not just a matter of watching and observing, but a truly active journey intended to combine navigation and relaxing with cycling along the narrow streets of Capri, Pompeii, Procida, Ischia, and Sorrento. The tour takes place aboard two motor gulets, the Deriya Deniz and the Maria Giovanna, depending on the  date of departure. Both boats offer maximum comfort on the inside and large areas on the outside to enjoy  the cruise life, lying on mats and relaxing while lulled by the sea. On both caiques on-board catering is characterized by fresh fish, pasta, meat, cheeses paired with seasonal vegetables and the typical flavours of the Mediterranean Sea.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance (cycling): 93/103 km Day 1: Castellammare di Stabia (Naples) Individual arrive and embarkation at 18.00 at the Marina of Castellammare di Stabia (Naples), accommodation on board, welcome drink, dinner and presentation of the program. Overnight onboard at the harbor of Castellammare di Stabia. Day 2: Castellammare di Stabia - Pompeii - Castellammare di Stabia (14 km) Cycle trip to Pompeii and the visit of the archeological site that hosts the unique Villa dei Misteri, we'll cycle back to the Marina of Castellammare and start sailing to Sorrento. Walking visit of the town and return to the boat. Overnight onboard at the Marina of Cassano in roadstead or at the harbor according to the weather conditions. Dinner and overnight onboard. Day 3: Sorrento – Positano – Amalfi (34 km) After breakfast, departure by bike along the Sorrento Coast. We'll cycle up the Passo San Pietro (St. Peter’s Pass) and enter the area of the Amalfi Coast. Our journey continues along the wonderful road overlooking the sea up to Positano. After the visit of Positano, we'll continue towards Amalfi, which at the end of the 10th century was the most powerful Mariner Republic of the Western world. Return to our boat. Dinner and overnight onboard at the harbor in Amalfi. Day 4: Amalfi – Minori – Vietri – Cetara (27 km) + alternative option to Ravello (37 km) From Amalfi, we'll continue our cycling trip along the coast, pedaling on the coastal road overlooking the sea and crossing the small villages of Minori, Maiori and Cetara. It is possible to make a deviation and go up towards Ravello; located at 300 mt. above sea level, from this village dominating the sea,  you can enjoy a wonderful view on the Gulf of Salerno and over to the Cilento mountains. You return on the road along the coast to finally reach Vietri. You come back on board. Overnight onboard (dinner not included) in the small fishing harbor of Cetara. Day 5: Capri hiking tour Navigation to Capri and disembarkation in Marina Piccola (Capri). We'll hike on the island, reaching the village of Capri with its famous “piazzetta” and then continue to the Faraglioni. From above the cliff we'll enjoy a wonderful voew on the Gulf of Naples dominated by Mount Vesuvius. In the afternoon, embarkation and navigation to Ischia. Dinner and overnight onboard at the harbor in Ischia Casamicciola. Day 6: Ischia (18 km) Cycling from the port of Ischia Casamicciola, we will cross by bike the west part of the island among the scents and flavors of the Mediterranean Sea, crossing along the way all the little villages of which the island is scattered. Once we reach the thermal village of Sant’Angelo, embarkation and overnight at the harbor in Ischia Sant’Angelo. Day 7: Procida and Solfatara volcano We'll sail up to the island of Procida, where we'll enjoy a walking visit of the village La Corricella and the Abbey of San Michele. Return to the boat to continue to Pozzuoli, in the Bay of Naples. We visit on foot the historical city centre of Pozzuoli with a stop at the Roman Amphitheatre, the third biggest Amphitheatre of the roman empire. After the visit, we'll sail up to Marina di Castellammare di Stabia (in case of bad weather, it is possible to reach Castellammare with public transport). Overnight at the Marina of Castellammare di Stabia. Day 8: Castellammare di Stabia (Naples) Disembarkation in the morning at 09.00. End of services. The captain and the Tour Leader reserve the right to make alterations to the itinerary, depending on wind, sea and weather conditions or organizational requirements. We wish to specify that this is not a sailing trip. The ship is a motor vessel, it has sails but the navigation is powered by engines.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica:
Terrain: please expect several ups and downs; the daily stages are between 25 and 35 km; there is plenty of time to complete the bike tours, so you can cycle at your own pace all along the itinerary. However, this tour is recommended to people who have a good experience in biking tours. Not suitable for beginners. Difference in height is between 40 and 700 mt per day. Roads: country/secondary roads on day 2 (Pompeii); on day 3 and 4 (Amalfi Coast), you will ride on the Coastal road, open to vehicular traffic. There are no bike paths on the Amalfi Coast. On day 5 (Capri) you will walk on paths overlooking the sea. On day 6 (Ischia), the itinerary is on secondary roads or coastal road (open to traffic). On day 7 (Procida and Pozzuoli), you will walk on secondary roads or paths. Difference in heights:

Participants: minimum 4 Luggage transfer: not necessary Suitable for children: over 12 years old Beginning of the tour: Castellammare di Stabia Parking: you can park your car in the Marina of Castellammare di Stabia. Guarded parking €50 for the week. Reservation is not necessary. End of the tour: Castellammare di Stabia, after breakfast. Language spoken by the guide, program documents and assistance: English. We recommend to those who choose a tour with an English speaking guide to evaluate their familiarity with the language in order to interact with both the guide and the other participants. Dietary requirements: Vegetarian meals are available, but please indicate this at the reservation. An additional charge of €50 per person will be applied to provide lactose or gluten-free meals. In all other allaergy or intolerance cases we will check the possibility of catering for it. In some cases an additional charge may apply. Animals: not accepted Other payment service: transfers to be requested and paid in advance: from Naples Capodichino airport or from Central station to Marina di Castellammare di Stabia or vice versa €40 per person.

From here take the bus line Alibus to Naples central train station, then follow instructions in the section By train. Once you have passed the rail crossing, turn left in Corso de Gasperi, and after 200 mt. you arrive at the entrance of the Marina.

10214.post_title: G071 - Hiking the Ring of Kerry in search of Celtic traditions

pods_fields.titolo: Hiking the Ring of Kerry in search of Celtic traditions
pods_fields.desc_min: An easy and gentle walking program combined with the best of ancient and modern Ireland
pods_fields.note: Guided hiking  tour – English speaking guide
pods_fields.desc: This holiday is based in the “Kingdom” of County Kerry, in the vibrant scenic town of  Killarney and the traditional friendly market town of Caherciveen.  It offers you an easy and gentle walking program combined with the best of ancient and modern Ireland  and some very unique and memorable activities.  Imagine combining the stunning lake, mountain and Atlantic scenery of the South West of Ireland with Irish Music, ancient castles and manor houses, Irish farming traditions, learning to play the Bodhran, a magical evening walk to a prehistoric Ring Fort, an island walk and an Irish set dancing session!  All this, and more, is combined with traditional Irish hospitality, good food and friendly people to make this an unforgettable week, ideal for people seeking a real Irish experience.  This is a gentle walking program  combined with wonderful Celtic cultural  activities. Discover Killarney – a well-known, scenic, vibrant town in the heart of the Killarney National Park, enjoy a visit of 19th century Muckross House, Gardens, Traditional Farms and Abbey , make a boat trip through the three Lakes of Killarney and take pleasure in spectacular coastal and inland walks.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Killarney 19.00 hrs. Dinner and welcome briefing with guide at Dromhall hotel in Killarney.  Possibility to ask for an optional airport transfer from Shannon or Kerry airports (price on request). Day 2:  Killarney National Park    +0m , 10 km/6 mi An introductory gentle walk through Killarney National Park allows you to experience the stunning lake and mountain scenery as well as the historical aspect of the Park, with a visit of 19th century Muckross House, the Gardens, the Traditional Farms- where guests walk back in time to a working 1930’s farm. On our walk back to the hotel we also pass by the 15th century Muckross Abbey. After dinner you may like to head into Killarney town to one of its traditional Irish pubs for a celebration of Irish Music! Day 3: Ring of Kerry, Torc Waterfall After a short morning walk in Killarney National Park to Torc Waterfall we transfer along the famous Ring of Kerry route to the coastal village of Caherdaniel.  We visit Derrynane National Park and House, home of Daniel O’Connell The Liberator. Walk along the Mass Path with beautiful views of the beaches, visit a 12th Century abbey on Abbey Island. Walk the blue flag Derrynane beach or if you are brave enough, a swim in the Atlantic Ocean!  Picnic lunch on beach or Abbey Island before continuing onto Cahersiveen for the next couple of days. Day 4 Art and Music, Irish Chocolates and Skellig Experience & Boat cruise Today we have a leisurely day and start off on a musical note and learn how to play the ancient Irish drum - the Bodhran - in a friendly and informal session with our Master Bohdran player. Afterwards we make a welcome stop at the Skellig Chocolate factory to give into those ‘sweet tooth’ cravings before continuing to Valentia Island. In the afternoon we visit THE SKELLIG EXPERIENCE VISITOR CENTRE where we experience many aspects of those offshore Skellig islands while remaining on the dry land, in a custom built, stone clad, grass roofed, prize winning building located right on the waterfront beside the Valentia Island bridge at Valentia, County Kerry. Weather permitting after lunch we take a boat trip around the UNESCO World Heritage Site, the monastic island of Sceilg Mhichíl (Great Skellig Island) which was inhabited in the 6th – 12th centuries by Irish monks and more recently was a filming location for Star Wars ‘The Force Awakens’.  We will also pass the world’s largest Gannet colony on Little Skellig Island. Please note: For anyone who may like to land on and walk Great Skellig, it may be possible to negotiate. Extra charges will apply. Day 5: Treasure Island & evening walk to prehistoric Ring Fort   5 km/3 miles, +12m/370ft Today we tour Valentia Island giving superb views of the Atlantic Ocean. Dingle Bay and Peninsula as well as the Skellig Islands.  Valentia Island is rich in wild and marine life, standing stones, sub-tropical flora & also the location of the first transatlantic cable. Visits include Valentia Slate Quarry & Grott.Tetrapod Tracks (250m years old), landing site of the Transatlantic cable (1860s). We walk to Bray Head (Napoleonic signal Tower and WWII lookout post). A gentle but satisfying day. After dinner in your guesthouse, we invite you to a magical late evening visit to a prehistoric Ring Fort. The magical sounds of an Irish harp await you in the stillness of the Ring Fort (weather permitting). Simply unforgettable… Day 6: Atlantic Beach walk, Sheep Dog Trials and free time  3 km/2 miles (weather dependent) Today we set off and continue our journey along the Ring to Kerry returning to Killarney where we will stay for the last two nights.  See real live sheep dog trials in Kells en-route. Completely rejuvenate your spirit as you walk along the award winning blue flag beach of Rossbeigh.  Enjoy a free afternoon and evening discovering Killarney’s craft, book & coffee shops, visit a spa or walk in the National Park, adjacent to the town. Day 7: Boat Trip  Lakes of Killarney & Walk through the Gap of Dunloe   11km/7 miles, +215m/ 700 ft Saving the best walk for last, this morning we depart from Ross Castle to enjoy one of Ireland’s best day trips on an open top boat through the three Lakes of Killarney to Lord Brandons cottage. After lunch we undertake a wonderful walk through the Gap of Dunloe to Kate Kearneys Cottage where you may like to treat yourself to an Irish Coffee at the end. Non walkers have the option of hopping on a horse drawn jaunting car (supplement of €20-30 per person).  This evening we enjoy a farewell dinner & Irish night where you can celebrate and reflect on the wonderful walks, sights, sound and tastes of Ireland you have experienced throughout the week. Day 8     Departure Departure after a hot cooked Irish breakfast.  Check below if the Go Visit Ireland Airport transfers to Kerry (closest airport) or Shannon airport suit.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: Terrain:  easy and short hiking stages  on mostly flat terrain (only few little ascent), paths, beach paths; Guide: local guide English speaking Participants: min.  6 pax Luggage transport: yes Sugegsted for children: from 16 yo

7832.post_title: G307 - Bike and Boat in Sicily among the Aeolian Islands

pods_fields.titolo: Bike and Boat in Sicily among the Aeolian Islands
pods_fields.desc_min: Let yourself be enchanted by this spectacular cruise in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. You will discover the pearls of Sicily, the extraordinary Aeolian Islands, in a new and different way.
pods_fields.note: Guided tour in International Group with English speaking Tour Leader
pods_fields.desc:
• Discover unique landscapes of Aeolian Islands.
  • Jump into cobalt-blue sea and explore a piece of paradise.
  • Enjoy comfort onboard of the typical wooden gulet Sundial.
  • Let yourself be enchanted by Stromboli's eruptions seen from the sea.
  • Walk up to the crater of Vulcano.
  • Taste delicious Aeolian cuisine.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 79 km Day 1: Catania Meeting at 15.30 at Catania airport. Collective transfer to Milazzo harbour. Embarkation at 18.00 at the Marina di Nettuno in Milazzo. Accommodation on board, welcome drink, dinner and presentation of the program. Overnight inboard in the port of Milazzo. Day 2: Milazzo (14 km) Departure by bike to reach Capo Milazzo. Possibility of bathing in the wonderful Venus Pool, a protected natural sea pool at the very end of the cape. Return to Milazzo and possibility of visiting the Castle and its ancient bourg. Return to the Marina of Milazzo. Dinner and overnight inboard in harbor. Day 3: Island of Vulcano (18 Km) Breakfast and navigation towards the island of Vulcano, the Sulphur Island. During the day, you will discover by bike the hinterland of the island towards Piano Grillo, ideal place to admire an amazing panorama. Free time in the afternoon. We suggest one of the following activities to discover the volcanic activity of the island: you can walk up to the crater of the volcano (400 mt), you can have a mud bath in the sulphur beach of the island, or swim among underwater fumaroles. Dinner and overnight onboard at the harbor in Vulcano. Day 4: Panarea and Stromboli (3h30 walking) After breakfast, navigation towards the Island of Panarea. We will stop for a swim close to the little islands of Lisca Bianca, Bottara and Dattilo, where the volcanic activity is still clearly visible and vapours rise up through the cracks between the rocks. Once arrived in Panarea, the smallest of the Aeolian Islands, lunch break at anchor in a nice bay. Navigation towards Stromboli with a superb view on the Sciara del Fuoco. In the late afternoon, walking itinerary to reach 400 meters above sea level, to admire the volcanic explosions at dusk. Picnic dinner in a nice panoramic spot. Return on board, overnight in roadstead in Stromboli. Day 5: Stromboli – Panarea (2h30 walking) - Salina Breakfast on board and navigation towards Panarea. We will stop at anchor in the bay of Porto San Pietro. Nice relaxed walking itinerary in the morning to visit the little village of Panarea, the Drautto beach and the prehistoric village. Picnic lunch at Cala Junco and return on board. Navigation to the island of Salina with a break for a swim. Disembarkation in Salina and visit to a local shop, with a chance to taste several local products. Return on board. Dinner and overnight onboard at the harbor in Salina. Day 6: Salina (22 km) – Lipari Departure from the port of Salina by bike. Great cycling itinerary on the biggest island of the Aeolian Archipelago. From Santa Marina, on the east coast, you will reach Pollara, a panoramic point on the western coast. Visit of the Lake of Lingua and Pollara, with the possibility to taste the amazing granita at Alfredo’s. Return on board and navigation to Lipari. Here, you can stroll around the charming village of Lipari, with several shops and good restaurants. You are free for dinner. Overnight onboard at the harbor in Lipari. Day 7: Lipari (25 km) After breakfast we will leave for a fantastic coast to coast cycling journey. Starting from the village of Lipari, we will pass along the beautiful village and beach of Canneto. We will reach the pumice quarries and the nice beach of Acquacalda (a swim is possible). Picnic lunch at the panoramic point of Quattrocchi and return back to the historical centre rich in shops and restaurants. Return to the boat and navigation to Milazzo. Dinner and overnight onboard at the harbor. Day 8: Catania Disembarkation at 9.00 a.m. and collective transfer to Catania airport. Expected arrival in Catania airport around 12 o'clock. End of the services. The captain and the guide reserve the right to make alterations to the itinerary, depending on wind, sea and weather conditions or organizational requirements. We wish to specify that this is not a sailing trip. The ship is a motor vessel, it has sails but the navigation is powered by engines.

NOTE: during tour the boat will be docked in the port for 6 nights. The remaining nights the ship will be anchored in roadstead. The roadstead is a place outside the harbor where the ship can lie at anchor. It is an enclosed area with an opening to the sea. Natural roadsteads offer shelter from storms, winds and currents, and are frequently used for naval bases. Exclusively in exceptional cases (unfavorable meteorological and/or sea conditions), for safety reasons, the ship will return to the harbor during the nights normally scheduled in roadstead. Only and exclusively in this case, the clients will be asked to pay for the stay in the port. This amount, variable from port to port, will be divided among all the participants of the tour and will be paid directly on site (approximately from 20 to 50€ per person per night, subject to changes). The price includes: Collective transfer to and from Catania airport on day 1 at 3 p.m. and day 8 at 9 a.m., accommodation in double cabin with private facilities, on full board from the dinner of day 1 to the breakfast of day 8 (picnic lunches or lunch on board included) except one dinner in Lipari, water during meals (1/2 lt bottled water per person for picnic lunches and water jars on the table at dinner), Italian/English speaking Thur Leader, sheets and towels (1 change per week), 6 nights in port and 1 night in roadstead. Health/luggage insurance Europ Assistance 24/24. The price does not include: Bike rental, drinks, 1 dinner in Lipari, entrance fees (museums, parks, monuments…), tips, extras, anything not stated at in the section The price includes. Possibility to charter the whole boat for bike and boat, or trekking tours: infos on request.

pods_fields.titolo: From Sarajevo to Belgrade
pods_fields.desc_min: If you are looking for a travel with an extra pinch of adventure, this tour will suit you just fine. Discover this stretch of the Balkans together with us.
pods_fields.note: Cycling exploration trip with English-speaking Italian guide
pods_fields.desc: All along the season, our guides leave for reconnaissance trips to investigate and test the latest itineraries we are planning to add to our catalogue. Last year, we pedaled from Dubrovnik to Sarajevo; in 2017, we head back to the Balkans, and precisely to Sarajevo, to explore the road to Belgrade. So, if the word adaptability is part of your vocabulary and you already have a little bit of training with the two-wheeler, why not joining this adventure? Hotels are already booked and everything is set up to offer you a great travel experience, but be ready for unscheduled changes to the program, as the itinerary is carefully designed on the maps, but still needs to be tested in person by our guides. During the tour, our support van will always travel together with the group, thus offering assistance if needed and carrying your luggage from one destination to the following one. Starting from the charming old town of Sarajevo, we will arrive at the very heart of Belgrade, at the crossing of Rivers Sava and Danube. We will be cycling for approximately 400km, passing through the Bosnian mountains and then reaching the border with Serbia. On our way, we will encounter Srebrenica, a small mountain town that sadly became the symbol of the wars raging in this area during the Nineties. Riding along the River Drina and starting our descent towards the flatland, we will cross the border and enter Serbia. We will follow the flow of the Sava, until the skyline of Belgrade, capital of the country, opens up in front of us.
pods_fields.prog: Total km: 408 km / 253 mi Day 1 : Sarajevo Individual arrival in Sarajevo and check-in at the hotel. Free time to visit the city.  At 6 pm, directly at the hotel, welcome meeting with your tour guide and delivery of the bikes. Accommodation in 3-star hotel, double en-suite rooms. Day 2 : Sarajevo – Sokolac, 50 km/31 mi, +800 m Leaving the Bosnian capital behind us, we mostly pedal across minor roads, abandoning the main road every time it is possible, thus reaching the rural town of Sokolac. We are now in the Republika Srpska, one of the two constitutional and legal entities of Bosnia Erzegovina. Accommodation in guesthouse, multi-bed rooms with shared restroom. Day 3 : Sokolac – Vlasenica, 50 km/31 mi, +700 m Passing over the Romanja Massif, through woods and pastures, we arrive in Vlasenica, a small town 500 meters above sea level, still belonging to the area of the Serb Republic. Accommodation in 3-star hotel, double en-suite rooms. Day 4 : Vlasenica – Srebrenica, 62 km/38 mi, + 1000 m From the point of view of daily difference in height, this is the most challenging stage of the tour. We reach Srebrenica, a town that became the symbol of the wars of the Nineties. Here, many locations still carry the memory of the massacre of the Muslim citizens of July 1995 Accommodation in guesthouse, double and quadruple rooms, shared restroom. Day 5 : Srebrenica – Banja Koviljača, 74 km/46 mi, + 400 m Following the flow of the Drina River that marks the border between Bosnia and Erzegovina and Serbia, we get to the watering place of Banja Koviljača. Accommodation in bed&breakfast, double or triple rooms, en-suite restroom. Day 6 : Banja Koviljača – Platičevo, 87 km/54 mi, + 600 m Pedaling up and down the hills, we reach the flatland of Vojvodina and the village of Platicevo, north of the Sava River. Accommodation in 2-star hotel, en-suite double rooms. Day 7: Platičevo – Belgrado, 85 km/52 mi, + 200 m Although this is quite a long stage, the route is entirely flat. We cycle to Belgrade. The capital of Serbia is a 2 million inhabitants city with a lively nightlife, where big electro music clubs coexist together with the rafts anchored to the shore of the river and transformed into tiny pubs. Accommodation in 3-star hotel, double en-suite rooms. Day 8 – Belgrade Free day to the city. Accommodation in 3-star hotel, double en-suite rooms. Day 9 – Belgrade The tour ends after breakfast.

In addition to the classic luggage transport and emergency telephone number, we provide roadside assistance and/or recovery in case of emergency (illness, mechanical problem that cannot be repaired with the repair-kit). Simply notify us and within a short time our team member will reach you to solve the problem.  If necessary you will be transported to your hotel. 7830.post_title: G277 - London to Amsterdam by bike

pods_fields.titolo: London to Amsterdam by bike
pods_fields.desc_min: Four countries, two cosmopolitan capital cities, one tour. The colors green and blue as a common thread, a quiet passage along rivers and sandy beaches and through colorful and pleasant towns.
pods_fields.note: Guided cycling trip in international group with English-speaking Tour Leader
pods_fields.desc: The intense green of the English countryside, the vibrant green of the Flemish pastures, the lush green of the Dutch orchards. And blue, synonymous with water, from the River Thames to the North Sea to the canals of Holland. The itinerary of this tour runs through four different countries, with the colors green and blue as a common thread throughout the days. You will have the chance to discover how two European cosmopolitan capital cities can be connected by peace and tranquility as you ride through meadows, along rivers and sandy beaches. Departing from Greenwich, a charming London neighborhood, this tour takes us first through the beautiful county of Kent, the Garden of England. Crossing by ferry from Dover, England to Dunkirk,France, we continue for a short distance on French soil and then into Flanders, in Belgium, a land rich in fields and meadows mingled with waterways, sandy beaches and seaside promenades. We discover firsthand why Belgium is known for chocolate, waffles, lace and beer. We explore the unforgettable sites of elegant Ostend and romantic Bruges. We experience the Netherlands, a land reclaimed from the water, a combination of land, rivers and canals. This is also the home of wooden shoes, windmills and the birthplace of renowned artists such as Rembrandt and Van Gogh. Then, as our last step, we enter Amsterdam, with its old history and contemporary open-minded, bike-oriented feel. Ride with us on this unique itinerary and rediscover the pleasure of exploration.
pods_fields.prog: Total km  347 Day 1: London/Greenwich Individual arrival in Greenwich and check-in at the hotel.  At 6 pm, welcome meeting with your guide; you receive your bike directly at the hotel. Dinner is on your own. Greenwich - a UNESCO World Heritage Site - is an ancient village overlooking the south bank of the River Thames. It is located just a few kilometers from the center of London. The Royal Observatory stands on the hill overlooking the village. From here, you can admire the Thames and St. Paul's Cathedral. The historic astronomical observatory is the location of Greenwich Prime Meridian, for which the village is known worldwide. When telling the time, GMT acronym stands for ‘Greenwich Mean Time’: every day at 1 pm, the red globe atop the observatory is dropped to mark the time. In the evening, a laser travels through the skies from the exact spot that marks the Prime Meridian. Greenwich is also a place rich in history, the birthplace of King Henry VIII, and hosts one of the most popular markets of the London area. This, together with the tranquility pervading the village, makes Greenwich one of the most fascinating areas of the capital. Day 2 : Greenwich – Canterbury  42 Km / 26 mi. After breakfast we begin the tour by cycling along the south bank of the river Thames to Dartford (31 km). Here we board a train and travel across the County of Kent to Whitstable (1h20). Kent is known as the ‘Garden of England’ for its green landscape dotted with some of the most beautiful and famous gardens of the UK. Once in Whitstable, we ride the last 10km by bike to the day’s destination, Canterbury. This beautiful town is located on the main road between Dover and London. It is the starting point of the ‘Via Francigena’, a centuries-old pilgrim route reaching Rome, and, in spite of its medieval past, is now lively with students who come here from all over Europe to attend its important university. The city was the first capital of the Saxon Kingdom of Kent and the seat of the first Christian diocese of England, founded by St. Augustine. The magnificent Christ Church Cathedral dominates the narrow alleys and half-timbered houses of the old medieval city center. Today, after several renovations, the Cathedral is one of the best examples of English Gothic architecture. Day 3 : Canterbury – Dover + ferry to Dunkirk  50 km / 32 mi. We depart by bike early in the morning to cycle 34 km to Dover, famous for its white cliffs and one of the most important ports of Great Britain. Here, we board the ferry to Dunkirk, France (about 2 hours + 1 Time Zone). Once in France, we ride 18 km from the port to the center of the city. Dunkirk is the third most important port in France. It is located in the Nord-Pas de Calais region, 10 km from the border with Belgium. At first glance, Dunkirk is an industrial town focused on maritime trade; however, when you look deeper, the unusual beauty of this place sets in with its dunes and tens of kilometers of sandy beaches flourishing in flora and fauna. Kite-surfing and the famous surf on the sand are popular activities here. The city center is characterized by low buildings, mainly of the last century, and Flemish influences. The church of St. Eloi and the two bell towers are included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites and are well worth a visit. Day 4 :  Dunkirk – Bruges 79 km / 49 mi. The majority of this stage occurs in Belgium. Several World War II battles took place here as French and British troops tried to block the German invasion. Once across the France-Belgium border, we ride through the Flemish green countryside. Cycling along the coast of the North Sea, we reach Ostend, a popular tourist destination on the Flemish coast characterized by its wide promenade bordered by shops, hotels and restaurants where you can taste excellent mussels, oysters and drink local beers. Our bike tour continues through the Flanders region towards the romantic city of Bruges, where time seems to have stopped and everything runs slowly. Thanks to its myriad of canals, it is often referred to as The Venice of the North. Day 5 :  Bruges – Breskens 45 km  +  ferry to Vlissingen / 28 mi. After breakfast, take time to visit Bruges. As you walk through the city center, you will discover historic buildings, lace shops, pubs serving local beers, and an intricate network of canals. A boat tour through the waterway network is a unique and interesting way to discover the city. We continue our ride through the countryside along the Dutch border in the direction of Breskens. Here, we board a ferry for a short ride (about 15 minutes) to Vlissingen, the day’s destination. This fishing town is home to shipyards and a naval academy. The promenade, called Boulevard, is a long and beautiful walkway where a monumental prison tower dating from the fifteenth century is located. Day 6 : Vlissingen – Kinderdijk  - Dordrecht – Vianen   66 km / 41 mi. After breakfast, we transfer by train from Vlissingen to Dordrecht (1h30). Dordrecht is an elegant river town rich in art, theater life and architecture. This cultural center gave birth to several accomplished artists including students of Rembrandt. From here, we cycle through the Dutch countryside crossing flower gardens, walled cities, canals and dams. We continue northwards through pastures, orchards and meadows dotted with windmills until we reach the village of Vianen. Day 7 :  Vianen – Amsterdam   65 km / 40 mi. During the last cycling day, we travel first to Utrecht, an old city now vibrant with culture and university life. The historic center is characterized by medieval palaces and ancient buildings, proof of its deeply rooted history as rich trade port. Picturesque canals are fringed by wine cellars transformed into trendy clubs, pubs and coffee shops surrounding the docks. From Utrecht, we continue through charming towns and along canals on the way to Amsterdam, the cosmopolitan capital of the Netherlands. Amsterdam is famous for its waterways and canals, for its architecture, and especially for its open-minded society. In the world capital of bikes, cycling is definitely the most suitable way to visit the center. However, a tour of the canals by boat is highly recommended. Dam Square, many museums of art and history, and the Anne Frank house await you. Day 8 : The tour ends after breakfast. The length of every stage and the overnights stops are indicative and may vary according with the date. Customers will receive the details with hotel list before the departure.

7829.post_title: L275 - Greenway: from Paris to London Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Greenway: from Paris to London Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: Cycling from one cosmopolitan metropolis to the other, discover at your own pace the very essence of the green French and English countryside, each with their peculiarities and distinctive scenery.
pods_fields.desc:
• Live a unique cycling experience that will take you from Notre-Dame de Paris to Westminster Abbey.
  • Mix an on the road trip to comfort, sleeping in accurately selected hotels.
  • Explore two of the most charming European Capitals: Paris and London, but also Normandy countryside, which inspired Impressiont painters, Sussex's white cliffs and green hills.
  • Wander Brighton Lanes.
  • Relax and let our Travel App MyEasyRoute guide you along the route and across stories and secrets of the places you will cycle through.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 338/366 km or 212/228 mi. Day 1: Paris Individual arrival in Paris and hotel check in. At 6 pm meet our staff at the hotel for the initial briefing and bikes delivery. Night at the hotel in Bercy District, historical centre of French wine market.            Day 2: Paris – Maisons Laffitte (50 km/31 mi.) Begin your tour with a short ride to Notre Dame Cathedral. Then follow Parisian bike lanes taking you to the beautiful and historical city sites; ride across Bastille Square, along Canal St. Martin and Villette Park, the largest park in Paris and home to Cité des Sciences et de la Musique.  Continue along canals leading to the banks of the Seine and to the stunning Parc des Impressionistes in Rueil-Malmaison. The day ends in Maisons Laffitte at a few steps from the castle, a fine example of French Baroque style built  to host King Louis XIV. Night at the hotel in Maisons Laffitte. Day 3: Maisons Laffitte– Gisors (75 km/47 mi.) Your day will start in the shade of oaks and beeches of St. Germain-en-Laye Forest and of the Oise Valley. With its vibrant landscapes, this valley was a source of inspiration for many Impressionist painters including  Daumier, Pissarro, Cézanne and Van Gogh (you will have the chance to cycle across one of his most famous paintings, Wheatfield with Crows). You will then continue into the Vexin Français Regional Nature Park, an area rich in history, nature, and architecture to connect with the River Epte, marking the border with Normandy. Final destination of today's itinerary is the small town of Gisors, with its ancient medieval city centre wrapt in the mystery and legend of Templar Knights. Possibility to shorten this stage taking a train from Chars, in the Veni Français Regional Park, or cycle all the way long up to Gisors. Night at the hotel in Gisors. Day 4: Gisors – Forges-les-Eaux (60 km/37 mi.) In the morning you will ride through the rich countryside and quaint villages of the Epte Valley. See the beautiful Abbey of Saint-Germer-de-fly, stop for lunch in a typical French village, cool off as you dip your toes in the crisp clean natural spring waters of Haussez. The ancient thermal centre of Forges-les-Eaux is today's destination. Night at the hotel in Forges-les-Eaux. Day 5: Forges-les-Eaux - Dieppe (50 Km/31 mi.) + ferry to Newhaven A converted rails-to-trails bike path will be your stress-free route to Dieppe. The landscape along this 56 km stage is dotted with thriving farms and castles. The castles, such as Mesnières-en-Bray and Arques-la-Bataille, serve as a reminder of France’s rich history. Along the way, you will pass by the village of Neufchatel-en-Bray, famous for its heart shaped soft cheese similar to Camambert. Try a sample and hear the romantic legend about its origins. Once in Dieppe, park your bike, relax on the beach, or savor local oysters before boarding the ferry to cross the Channel to Newhaven, England. Night at the hotel in Newhaven. Day 6: Newhaven – Crawley (62 km/39 mi.) Your first day in England will start with a ride along Newhaven Marina and toward the stunning cliffs of South Downs. A bit of climbing will take you to breathtaking views as you ride along the top, before riding down to a beautiful (and flat) seaside path along the beach. For 10 km enjoy a scenic path with immaculate cliffs on one side and the English Channel, La Manche, on the other. Soon you will arrive in Brighton, a lively destination, popular for its pier attractions, cafes, and charming old town known as the Lanes. After Brighton, you will head inland through the rolling hills of Devil's Dyke, a legendary valley in the County of Sussex that is said to have been dug by the Devil in person. You will reach Crawley cycling in the shade of Tilgate Forest. Spend the evening strolling the cobblestone streets, visiting the cathedral or mixing with locals at the pub. Night at the hotel in Crawley. Day 7: Crawley – London (67 km/42 mi.) The last cycling day marks the return to urban life, although re-entry will be gradual. You will start the day cycling across the English countryside of the County of Surrey and into the suburbs of London. The route traverses city parks filled with runners, cyclists, and dog walkers as you will make your way to the city center. River Wandle will lead you to River Thames and on to the heart of London. You will first reach Westminster Abbey, final destination of the Avenue Verte, and then an amazing itinerary across Trafalgar Square, Piccadilly Circus and Soho will take you to your hotel. Please, remember to return rented bikes by 6pm. Night at the hotel in London. Day 8: London After breakfast, end of services.

4100.post_title: G275 - Greenway: cycle tour from Paris to London

pods_fields.titolo: Greenway: cycle tour from Paris to London
pods_fields.part_sum: 21/7; 04/8/2019   Additional departure dates available on request for private groups
pods_fields.desc_min: Cycling from one cosmopolitan metropolis to the other, discover the very essence of the green French and English countryside, each with their peculiarities and distinctive scenery.
pods_fields.note: Guided cycle trip in international group with English-speaking Tour Leader
pods_fields.desc:
• Live a unique cycling experience that will take you from Notre-Dame de Paris to Westminster Abbey.
  • Mix an on the road trip to comfort, sleeping in accurately selected hotels.
  • Explore two of the most charming European Capitals: Paris and London, but also Normandy countryside, which inspired Impressiont painters, Sussex's white cliffs and green hills.
  • Wander Brighton Lanes.
  • Cycle up to the very heart of London and experience something that you will hardly forget.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 338 km/210 mi. Day 1: Paris Individual arrival in Paris and hotel check in. At 6 pm meet your Tour Leader and the rest of the group at the hotel for the initial briefing and bikes delivery. Night at the hotel in Bercy District, historical centre of French wine market. Day 2: Paris – Maisons Laffitte (52 km/32 mi.) We will start our trip with an exciting ride to Notre Dame Cathedral. Then, following Parisian bike lanes, we will ride across Bastille Square, along Canal St. Martin and Villette Park, the largest park in Paris and home to Cité des Sciences et de la Musique. We will leave Paris cycling along canals leading to the banks of the Seine and to the stunning Parc des Impressionistes in Rueil-Malmaison. The day will end in Maisons Laffitte at a few steps from the castle, a fine example of French Baroque style built  to host King Louis XIV. Dinner at the restaurant and overnight at the hotel in Maisons Laffitte. Day 3: Maisons Laffitte – Chars (47 km/29 mi.) + Chars – Gisors by train Our day will start in the shade of oaks and beeches of St. Germain-en-Laye Forest and of the Oise Valley. With its vibrant landscapes, this valley was a source of inspiration for many Impressionist painters including Daumier, Pissarro, Cézanne and Van Gogh (we will have the chance to cycle across one of his most famous paintings, Wheatfield with Crows). We will then continue into the Vexin Français Regional Nature Park, an area rich in history, nature, and architecture. After a picnic break in the park of the Castle of Théméricourt, we will reach Chars and take the train to Gisors, in Normandy. Its ancient medieval city centre is wrapt in the mystery and legend of Templar Knights. Dinner at the restaurant and overnight at the hotel in Gisors. Day 4: Gisors – Forges-les-Eaux (60 Km/37 mi.) In the morning we will ride through the rich countryside and quaint villages of the Epte Valley. See the beautiful Abbey of Saint-Germer-de-fly, stop for lunch in a typical French village, cool off as you dip your toes in the crisp clean natural spring waters of Haussez. The ancient thermal centre of Forges-les-Eaux is today's destination. Dinner at a typical restaurant and overnight at the hotel in Forges-les-Eaux. Day 5: Forges-les-Eaux - Dieppe (50 Km/31 mi.) + ferry across the Channer and to Newhaven A converted rails-to-trails bike path will be our stress-free route to Dieppe. The landscape along this 56 km stage is dotted with thriving farms and castles. The castles, such as Mesnières-en-Bray and Arques-la-Bataille, serve as a reminder of France’s rich history. Along the way, we will pass by the village of Neufchatel-en-Bray, famous for its heart shaped soft cheese similar to Camambert. During a short break you will have the chance to try a sample and hear the romantic legend about its origins. Once in Dieppe, park your bike, relax on the beach, or savor local oysters before boarding the ferry to cross the Channel to Newhaven, England. Dinner on the ferry and overnight at the hotel in Newhaven. Day 6: Newhaven – Crawley (62 km/39 mi.) Our first day in England will start with a ride along Newhaven Marina and toward the stunning cliffs of South Downs. A bit of climbing will take us to breathtaking views as we will ride along the top, before riding down to a beautiful (and flat) seaside path along the beach. For 10 km enjoy a scenic path with immaculate cliffs on one side and the English Channel, La Manche, on the other. Soon we will arrive in Brighton, a lively destination, popular for its pier attractions, cafes, and charming old town known as the Lanes. After a break in Brighton, we will head inland through the rolling hills of Devil's Dyke, a legendary valley in the County of Sussex that is said to have been dug by the Devil in person. We will reach Crawley cycling in the shade of Tilgate Forest. Dinner and overnight at the hotel in Crawley. Day 7: Crawley – London (67 km/42 mi.) The last cycling day marks the return to urban life, although re-entry will be gradual. We will start the day cycling across the English countryside of the County of Surrey and into the suburbs of London. The route traverses city parks filled with runners, cyclists, and dog walkers as you will make your way to the city center. River Wandle will lead us to River Thames and on to the heart of London. We will first reach Westminster Abbey, final destination of the Avenue Verte, and then an amazing itinerary across Trafalgar Square, Piccadilly Circus and Soho will take us to our hotel. Please, remember to return rented bikes by 6pm. Overnight at the hotel in London. Day 8: London After breakfast, end of services.

3722.post_title: L118 - The Castles of the Loire Valley cycling from Blois to Saumur

pods_fields.titolo: Castles of the Loire Valley from Blois to Saumur
pods_fields.part_sum: on Sundays from 14/07 to 18/08; every day from 15/05 to 13/07 and from 19/08 to 30/09/2019
pods_fields.desc_min: Here is a real chance to jump into history and immerse yourself in the thriving nature all at once. The Loire Valley offers some unique encounters: châteaux, abbeys, white tufa cliffs, slate roofs, sunflower fields and endless vineyards.
pods_fields.desc: ‘Douce France‘ or 'Jardin de France': this is how the region is known by the people of the Loire. If you are seeking a  unique experience to rediscover the outdoors, take a bike tour through this vibrant cultural landscape and enjoy the harmonious way of life where man has found his rightful place in nature. As you travel to the heart of the Loire region, you will pass châteaux and abbeys, historic cities, classic small villages and vineyards as far as the eye can see. All around you, white tufa stone and black slate color the landscape of the region. Let the royal river lead you to the grand gates of the famous châteaux: Chenonceau, a sumptuous bridge on the river Cher; Chaumont, a delicate fortress in the forest; Blois, where French history unfolded; Amboise, home to the tomb of Leonardo da Vinci;  Chambord, with its 380 chimneys and 406 rooms, representing the apotheosis of the Loire Castles. Discover this enchanted territory as you cycle an easy, relaxing route on secondary roads, through forests, and along the river Loire and its tributaries. This is a 'linear' tour: this means that you change hotels each day (except the first 2 nights), starting your adventure in Blois and then, after a small circular stage to discover Chambord, advancing towards Saumur, the final destination of the tour. From the first minute of this extensive bike itinerary throughout the Loire Valley up to the very last, your eyes will not stop taking in all the beauty and magic of this extraordinary corner of Europe.
pods_fields.prog: Tot. 232/243 km - 145/152 mi. Day 1: Blois Individual arrival in Blois. Hotel check-in and free time to visit the town. Day 2: Blois – Chambord – Blois  (38-42 km / 24-27 mi.)  After crossing the Loire and the Sologne countryside, you enter the park of the Chambord Chateau, 4500 hectares of forest inhabited by deer and wild boars. Visit of the magnificent castle which was built by François I and designed by Leonardo da Vinci. Return to the hotel through the forest of Boulogne. Day 3: Blois – Chaumont – Amboise  (43 km / 27 mi.)  Following the river Loire you arrive at the castle of Chaumont. Built by Pierre d’Amboise on a cliff overlooking the Loire, it was subsequently purchased by Catherine de Medici. She sent Diana of Poitiers here for revenge and kept Chenonceau for herself. Pedaling along the river Loire you arrive in Amboise, a picturesque town on the left bank. Visit the royal castle located on a rocky outcrop overlooking the city and the smaller Château du Clos Lucé, the home of Leonardo da Vinci. The museum here exhibits models of da Vinci’s inventions. Full scale models are setup in the park allowing you to interact and directly experience these fabulous machines. Day  4: Amboise – Chenonceaux – Tours  (57 km / 36 mi.)  From the valley of the river Loire to the valley of the river Cher, through the Forest of Amboise, you will reach the castle of Chenonceau, so-called "of the two queens", Diana and Catherine. This is certainly the most beautiful and the most visited castle in the region with its magnificent arches over the river. From Chenonceau, continue along the Cher through the famous vineyards of Vouvray and between the tufa cliffs that overlook the river. You will arrive in Tours, the most important city in the region. Visit of the old town, the cathedral and Place Plumereau. Day 5: Tours – Villandry –  Azay-le-Rideau  (39 km / 25 mi.) From Tours continue along the river Cher to the castle of Villandry, famous for its "jardin potager". The famous gardens of Villandry, built under the influence of Italian gardeners, are a beautiful example of French Renaissance architecture. Continuing through the countryside you arrive at today's destination, Azay-le-Rideau. Here, too, you find a gem of the Renaissance: the castle of Azay built on a small island of the Indre river under the direction of the Francois I’s treasurer. French Novelist Balzac described this building as a "faceted diamond, set in Indre”, an island of flowers. Day 6: Azay-le-Rideau – Chinon – Saumur  (55-62km / 35-39 mi.) The last stage takes you to Saumur, pedaling along the Loire and mostly on a  cycle path until you reach Saumur. This fortified town has its origins in the castle and the monastery of the tenth century. Now only traces of the original walls are detectable but the castle still stands on a hill. Today the land of Saumur has 6 AOC wines and is the home of the prestigious French National Riding School’ Cadre Noir’. Day 7: Saumur The tour ends after breakfast.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS This cycling tour includes our SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS, an exclusive service that only Verde Natura offers to ensure you are at ease during your bike tour, especially if this is your first bike tour experience. In addition to the classic luggage transport and emergency telephone number, we provide roadside assistance and/or recovery in case of emergency (illness, mechanical problem that cannot be repaired with the repair-kit). Simply notify us and within a short time our team member will reach you to solve the problem.  If necessary you will be transported to your hotel.  Service is  running from 14/07 to 18/08. Terrain characteristics: mostly flat, only a couple of very short ascents (which can be taken on foot). This tour is suitable for everyone, recommended as first bike tour. The daily stages are from 40 to 58 km per day, which means 3h/5h of cycling each day. Roads: 70% asphalted roads, 30% white country roads Participants: minimum 2 pax Luggage transport: yes Suitable for children: yes, of all ages if used to cycling Bikes: aluminum city bikes 21 or 24 speeds with free wheel. Unisex model from 150 cm to 174 cm; gent bike for heights over 175 cm. The bikes are equipped with a waterproof side bag and handlebar bag, reparation kit, a lock every 2 bikes and a mobile handlebar support for each room. E-bikes for adults. For children:  20' and 24' children's bikes, 3rd wheel, child trailer and child seat. In the travel documents the pick-up point of the rented bikes will be indicated and at the time of delivery is required the signing of the rental contract. Helmets available upon reservation at € 15 each to be paid locally. Bicycle warranty: with this guarantee, Verde Natura, assumes the risk of accidental damage and accidentally caused by the customer or theft, if the bicycle has been closed with the lock provided. To be required with the bike rental. Starting point: Blois. Day 1 is expected to arrive in Blois recommended around 4:00 pm. The bike tour starts on day 2. Parking: some hotels have free parking for the duration of the tour; alternatively, there are city car parks that offer flat-rate costs for 7 days. At the end of the tour from Saumur you can take the train to return to Blois or a taxi. End of the tour: the morning of the 7th in Saumur, after breakfast. Service hotline: available in English and Assistance Plus on place from 14/07 to 19/08/2019 Travel documents: the description of the route is available, with a supplement, in English Special meals / diets: the tour includes breakfast and in category A it is possible to add half board which includes 6 dinners. If you have allergies / intolerance's or other food problems, please let us know at the booking time. In these cases, we do not recommend booking half-board so as to have more choices on the spot. Pets: pets allowed on request, to be reported at the booking time. Possible daily surcharges to be paid locally. Notes: the family rooms are often composed of a double bed and a sofa bed or extra beds and rooms from 1 to 4 people are available max. Some hotels are wonderfully positioned high up on the hill and overlooking the valley. You can push the bike walking along the climb. Twin rooms with separate beds are available only sporadically. We handle requests for twin rooms as non-binding requests. In case twin rooms are booking condition, it must be clearly communicated as such when booking! Category B includes 2 * hotels. These are small hotels often in historic buildings where there is no lift and often the rooms are not air conditioned. However, they are very welcoming, characteristic and comfortable hotels in a central position. Category A includes big 3 * or 4 * hotels, often of a chain and in some cases not in central position. They have a lift and air conditioning, offer good comfort and some have a swimming pool.

3721.post_title: G114 - Avignon and Provence across Easter

pods_fields.titolo: Avignon and Provence across Easter
pods_fields.desc_min: Avignon and Provence across Easter: a great classic to experience at least once in a lifetime!
pods_fields.note: Cycling exploration trip with English-speaking Italian guide
pods_fields.desc: All along the season, our guides leave for reconnaissance trips to investigate and test the latest itineraries we are planning to add to our catalogue. Here we are in Provence, France, with the first exploration itinerary for the 2017 season: if the word adaptability is part of your vocabulary and you already have a little bit of training with the two-wheeler, then why not joining this adventure? Hotels are already booked and everything is set up to offer you a great travel experience, but be ready for unscheduled changes to the program, as the itinerary is carefully designed on the maps, but still needs to be tested in person by our guides. During the tour, our support van will always travel together with the group, thus offering assistance if needed and carrying your luggage from one destination to the following one. The region we selected for this trip is certainly not new to us, as we have a deep knowledge of the territory and we have been proposing tours in this area for many years.  Plus, is there really somebody who has never heard of the beauty of Provence? This region needs no great presentation. Thanks to this new itinerary, we will travel far and wide across its land, discovering beautiful locations and interesting facts, taking in new colors, tastes and scents every day. The tour of Avignone and Provence in springtime is a great classic and this is a great occasion to thick it off from your “once in a lifetime experiences” list!
pods_fields.prog: Total km 265 – mi 165 Day 1: Aix-en-Provence Individual arrival in Aix-en Provence and hotel check-in. At 6 pm, directly at the hotel, welcome meeting with your tour guide and delivery of the bikes. Immersed in the light that is also source of its mild weather, Aix-en-Provence stands out for its elegance, abounding in the lively streets and plazas. History and everyday life blend together in a continuum of small boutiques, buoyant déhors, heritage buildings, Baroque treasures, architectural landmarks. Here every fountain has a secret to hide, every palace has a story to be told. Dinner in restaurant and overnight stay. Day 2:  Aix-en-Provence - Mouriès  62 km / 38 mi Leaving Aix-en-Provence behind, we cycle towards the inland of the region, pedaling the countryside through vineyards and olive groves. By tackling a few short climbs, we arrive in Éguilles, an actual terrace over the gorgeous Provencal landscape. We reach Salon-de-Provence, long home to Nostradamus and world-known for the craftsmanship of soap. We then enter the perimeter of the Alpilles Regional Natural Park, created to preserve the specificity of the area and the bond between man and Nature deeply rooted in this territory. We cycle though the villages of Eyguières and Aureille, finally arriving in Mouriès.  Dinner at the hotel and overnight stay. Day 3: Mouriès - Avignon  43 km / 27 mi Soon after breakfast we will head to Les Baux, where we visit the castle and the ‘Cathedral of Images’, a one-of-a-kind art exhibition inside a tufa cave. We then start to descent towards Saint Remy across the centuries-old olive trees. This town is the epitome of Provençal style, with its tiny lively squares with their typical public fountain, the varied boutiques and ateliers of the many local craftsmen and the boulevards lined with plane trees. Pedaling across the landscapes that inspired Van Gogh’s masterpieces, we get to the shores of the river Rhone and to the entrance to the City of the Popes. Thanks to the monumental ensemble formed by the Saint Bénézet bridge, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame des Doms and the Papal Palace, the city center is listed among the Unesco World Heritage Sites. However, this city will ultimately conquer your heart for its energy and liveliness. You are free for dinner. Overnight stay. Day 4: Avignon – Cabrières d’Avignon  40 km / 25 mi Today’s exploration runs through hilltop villages, solitary farmhouses and flocks of sheep grazing peacefully among fields of lavender, olive groves and vineyards. We stop in Isle-sur-la-Sorgue, a place famous for its antique shops and the ‘brochante’ market. Bordering the Sorgue River, we arrive in Fontaine de Vaucluse. Here the view of crystalline waters flowing directly out of the rocks inspired the mighty Italian poet Francesco Petrarca to write his ‘Clear, sweet fresh water’ verses. We descent towards Cabrières d’Avignon, a small village where we can still see the remains of the Plague Wall that was constructed in 1721 to protect the inland population from the terrible deadly epidemic raging in Marseille. Dinner at the hotel and overnight stay. Day 5: Cabrières d’Avignon  – Cavaillon 56 km / 35 mi We will head straight to Gordes, one of the most stunning towns in the entire Provence. The local stones with which the houses are built change color according to the light, thus covering all possible shades of yellow you can imagine. From the many terraces of the town we will enjoy a unique view over the valley and the Luberon mountains. We then roll down towards another symbol of this region, which is the Cistercian Sénanque Abbey, immersed in its memorable sea of lavender. This daily stage never runs low in surprise and awe, as we move forward to Roussillon. The colors of the scene change completely and reds, oranges and yellows take over the landscape. This is due to the ochre caves thus earning to the area the name of ‘Colorado Provencal’. We will visit the area on foot. Back on our bikes, we will reach Cavaillon by riding the cyclepath at the foot of the Luberon mountains. Dinner in restaurant and overnight stay. Day 6: Cavaillon – Aix-en-Provence   64 km / 40 mi The last stage of the tour brings us back to Aix-en-Provence. Firstly, we follow the course of the Rhone River riding along the Luberon, then continuing through a valley covered in vineyards. We will encounter the towns of Mallemort and Lambesc, where we will have the chance to taste the refined local wines for which this region is famous. Dinner in restaurant and overnight stay. Day 7: The tour ends right after breakfast.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS This cycling tour includes our SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS, an exclusive service that only Verde Natura offers to ensure you are at ease during your bike tour, especially if this is your first bike tour experience. In addition to the classic luggage transport and emergency telephone number, we provide roadside assistance and/or recovery in case of emergency (illness, mechanical problem that cannot be repaired with the repair-kit). Simply notify us and within a short time our team member will reach you to solve the problem.  If necessary you will be transported to your hotel. Terrain: from slightly hilly to hilly in the last 2 days; daily stage distances between 40 and 64 km, with an average pace of 13km/h, thus meaning from 3 to 5 hours of cycling per day. Surface: 80% asphalt, 20% unpaved country roads Bikes: city bike Partecipants: min. 6 persons Luggage transfer: yes + Support Service plus Suggested for children: 13 years old and over, with own bike.
