3720.post_title: LW110 - The Castles of the Loire Valley by bike in 5 days

pods_fields.titolo: The Castles of the Loire Valley by bike in 5 days
pods_fields.part_sum: on Sundays from 14/07 to 18/08; every day from 15/05 to 13/07 and from 19/08 to 30/09/2019
pods_fields.desc_min: Châteaux, abbeys, white tufa cliffs, black slate roofs, fields of sunflowers and endless vineyards. Discover the very essence of the Loire Valley in this 5-days cycling tour.
pods_fields.desc: ‘Douce France‘ or ’Jardin de France‘: this is how this region is called by the people of the Loire. If you are seeking a  unique experience to rediscover the outdoors but you don’t have much time, this is the tour for you. In only 5 days, you will have the chance to ride through this vibrant cultural landscape and enjoy the harmonious way of life where man has found his rightful place in nature Tangled forests, vineyards, fields of sunflowers, black slate roofs, white tufa cliffs and magnificent fairy castles, these are the ingredients of this itinerary. Along the way, you will have the chance to visit many of the castles of the Loire Valley: Chenonceau, a sumptuous bridge on the river Cher; Chaumont, a delicate fortress in the forest; Blois, where French history took place; Amboise, treasuring the tomb of Leonardo da Vinci; Chambord, with its 380 chimneys and 406 rooms, representing the apotheosis of the Loire Castles. This proposal to discover this region is  a comfortable cycling tour, suitable also for all those who are facing their first experience with a cycling holiday and for families even with very young children.  You will be cycling on a flat itinerary, following secondary roads in the forests or along the river Loire and its tributaries.
pods_fields.prog: Tot. 138/142 km – 87/90 mi. Day 1: Blois Individual arrival in Blois. Hotel check-in and free time to visit the town. Day 2: Blois – Chambord – Blois  (38-42 km / 24-27 mi.) After crossing the Loire and the Sologne countryside, you enter the park of the Chambord Chateau, 4,500 hectares of forest inhabited by deer and wild boars. Visit of the magnificent castle which was built by François I and designed by Leonardo da Vinci. Return to the hotel through the forest of Boulogne. Day 3: Blois – Chaumont – Amboise (43 km / 27 mi.) Following the river Loire, you arrive at the castle of Chaumont. Built by Pierre d’Amboise on a cliff overlooking the Loire, it was subsequently purchased by Catherine de Medici. She sent Diana of Poitiers here for revenge and kept Chenonceau for herself. Pedaling along the river Loire, you arrive in Amboise, a picturesque town on the left bank. Visit the royal castle located on a rocky outcrop overlooking the city and and the smaller Château du Clos Lucé, the home of Leonardo da Vinci in his latest years. The museum here exhibits models of da Vinci’s inventions. Full scale models are setup in the park allowing you to interact and directly experience these fabulous machines. Day 4: Amboise – Chenonceaux – Tours  (57 km / 36 mi.)  From the valley of the river Loire to the valley of the river Cher, through the Forest of Amboise, you will reach the castle of Chenonceau, so-called "of the two queens", Diana and Catherine. This is certainly the most beautiful and the most visited castle in the region with its magnificent arches over the river. From Chenonceaux, continue along the Cher through the famous vineyards of Vouvray and between the tufa cliffs that overlook the river. You will arrive in Tours, the most important city in the region. Visit of the old town, the cathedral and Place Plumereau. Day 5: Tours The tour ends after breakfast.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS This cycling tour includes our SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS, an exclusive service that only Verde Natura offers to ensure you are at ease during your bike tour, especially if this is your first bike tour experience. In addition to the classic luggage transport and emergency telephone number, we provide roadside assistance and/or recovery in case of emergency (illness, mechanical problem that cannot be repaired with the repair-kit). Simply notify us and within a short time our team member will reach you to solve the problem.  If necessary you will be transported to your hotel . Assistance plus from 14/07 to 18/08/2019. Terrain: Mostly plain, only a couple of very short ascents (you can always afford them on foot). This tour is suitable for everyone, suggested as first bike tour. The daily stages are from 40 to 57 km per day, that means 3h/4h of cycling each day. Roads: 80% asphalted roads, 20% white country roads Participants: minimum 2 pax Luggage transport: yes, one luggage per person max 20 kg Suitable for children: yes, of all ages if used to cycling Bikes: aluminum city bikes 21 or 24 speeds with free wheel. Unisex model from 150 cm to 174 cm; gent bike for heights over 175 cm. The bikes are equipped with a waterproof side bag and handlebar bag, reparation kit, a lock every 2 bikes and a mobile handlebar support for each room. E-bikes for adults. For children:  20' and 24' children's bikes, 3rd wheel, child trailer and child seat. In the travel documents the pick-up point of the rented bikes will be indicated and at the time of delivery is required the signing of the rental contract. Helmets available upon reservation at € 15 each to be paid locally. Bicycle warranty: with this guarantee, Verde Natura, assumes the risk of accidental damage and accidentally caused by the customer or theft, if the bicycle has been closed with the lock provided. To be required with the bike rental. Starting point: Blois. Day 1 is expected to arrive in Blois recommended around 4:00 pm. The bike tour starts on day 2. Parking: some hotels have free parking for the duration of the tour; alternatively, there are city car parks that offer flat-rate costs for more days. At the end of the tour from Tours you can take the train to return to Blois or a taxi. End of the tour: the morning of the 5th in Tours, after breakfast. Service hotline: available in English and Assistance Plus on place from 14/07 to 19/08/2019 Travel documents: the description of the route is available in English Special meals / diets: the tour includes breakfast only. If you have allergies / intolerances or other food problems, please let us know at the booking time. Pets: pets allowed on request, to be reported at the booking time. Possible daily surcharges to be paid locally. Notes: the family rooms are often composed of a double bed and a sofa bed or extra beds and rooms from 1 to 4 people are available max. Some hotels are wonderfully positioned high up on the hill and overlooking the valley. You can push the bike walking along the climb. Twin rooms with separate beds are available only sporadically. We handle requests for twin rooms as non-binding requests. In case twin rooms are booking condition, it must be clearly communicated as such when booking! Category B includes 2 * hotels. These are small hotels often in historic buildings where there is no lift and often the rooms are not air conditioned. However, they are very welcoming, characteristic and comfortable hotels in a central position. Category A includes big 3 * or 4 * hotels, often of a chain and in some cases not in central position. They have a lift and air conditioning, offer good comfort and some have a swimming pool.

3719.post_title: L101 - Puglia: from Matera to Lecce Cycling Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Puglia: from Matera to Lecce Cycling Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: A cycling trip along Italy's sun-bleached heel, from the spectacular Sassi of Matera to Puglia's most beautiful Baroque city, Lecce.
pods_fields.desc:
• Spend a night in a typical Trullo in the Unesco World Heritage Site of Alberobello.
  • Cycle among secular olive groves and prickly pear cactuses and along the amazing Salento Coast.
  • Walk among the Sassi of Matera, Basilicata's jewel and EU Capital of Culture 2019.
  • Taste the many and excellent specialties of Puglia: Taralli, Friselle, Orecchiette, Puccia and sweet Pasticciotto, to pair with local wines such as Primitivo and Negramaro.
  • Experience well-known Southern Italy's hospitality that will immediately make you feel at home.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 328 km Day 1: Matera Individual arrival in Matera (possibility to book a private transfer from Bari or Brindisi airport). Overnight at the hotel in Matera. Recognized by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site, the Sassi of Matera represent a unique urban settlement; the village is built on a limestone plateau, showing a magnificent landscape: a 70-80 meters high canyon, crossed by the Gravina creek. The area of Matera was continuously inhabited since the Paleolithic Era. The specific districts of the Sassi were built in the late 5th century and the alternation of populations over time has left an intricate urban system, where the buildings overlap the natural caves. The uniqueness of this scenery led Mel Gibson to choose to film his movie The Passion of Jesus Christ here, as the old town seems frozen in time. However, Matera is also a lively city, and has also been awarded of the title of European Capital of Culture 2019. Day 2: Matera – Alberobello (69 km) After breakfast, briefing, presentation of the itinerary and delivery of rented bikes. The first stage is a gentle cycling across the countryside between the two regions of Basilicata and Puglia. Our final destination is Alberobello, universally-known as the capital of Trulli, fairy-tale houses of different shape and size, made of dry stone, with a cone roof covered with stone tiles platforms. There are about 1500 trulli scattered in Monti and Aia Piccola districts, both listed as World Heritage Site by UNESCO. Overnight in a typical Trullo converted into hotel, in Alberobello. Day 3: Alberobello – Locorotondo – Ostuni (45 km) Today you will cycle across the Itria Valley, immersed in a bright landscape of vineyards, olive groves and vast gentle slopes. We recommend you a stop in Locorotondo where you can taste the excellent and well-known white wines produced in this area. Your cycling day will end in Ostuni which will appear as a white mirage, standing splendidly on a hillside rising from a green plateau covered with olive trees and diving into the Adriatic Sea. Take a stroll down the narrow streets and admire the beautiful courtyards and piazzas surrounded by small white houses, artisans' workshops and restaurants. Overnight at the hotel in Ostuni. Day 4: Ostuni – Lecce (by train); Lecce – Gallipoli (50 km) This morning you will reach Lecce by train (approximately 50 minutes). We suggest a walk in the city centre before starting to cycle. In case you prefer leaving immediately, remember that you will have time to make a second visit to the city at the end of the tour. You are in the land of Baroque, as you will see by the dazzling architectural surprises around every corner in Lecce, Galatina and Galatone. Today's itinerary will end in Gallipoli, meaning the beautiful city in Greek, an old fishing port and nowadays a very charming and lively holiday destination. Overnight at the hotel in Gallipoli. Day 5: Gallipoli – Ugento – Santa Maria di Leuca (59 km) Today’s cycling itinerary runs along the coast of Salento. Along the way, near Ugento, you will have the chance to stop in some of the most beautiful beaches of Southern Italy. Today’s destination is Santa Maria di Leuca where the two sea, the Ionian and the Adriatic, meet. This is the southernmost stretch of Puglia, whose lighthouse and sanctuary will welcome you at your arrival. Overnight in Santa Maria di Leuca. Day 6: Santa Maria di Leuca – Castro – Santa Cesarea Terme – Otranto (55 km) Today you will cycle northward, along the beautiful coastline of the Adriatic Sea and up to Castro, well-known for its cliffs falling into a clear blue sea. Here you can admire the medieval village and Grotta Zinzulusa, one of the largest natural caves in the world, inhabited by Neanderthals about 60,000 years ago. After the visit, do not miss a short stop to taste good and expressly fried fish, sitting in front of a breathtaking view. Continuing your journey, you will follow the rocky coast through Santa Cesarea Terme in a blaze of light and color. The stage ends in Otranto, lying on a rocky outcrop overlooking the sea. The city has been the meeting point of different cultures and crossroads between the Mediterranean and the East for centuries. Don't miss the Aragonese Castle and the beautiful cathedral, enriched by a magnificent rose window. Overnight at the hotel in Otranto. Day 7: Otranto – Torre dell’Orso – Acaya – Lecce (50 km) The final stage will take you up to Torre dell'Orso, offering a crystal clear blue sea and a golden sand beach. Halfway, you will meet Acaya, a charming little town characterized by massive and impressive walls, towers and walls built in the first half of '500 in order to protect the coast and the hinterland against the incursions of the Ottoman Empire. Eventually, you will get back to Lecce, where you can enjoy Baroque masterpieces of the city centre and its lively nightlife. Overnight in Lecce. Day 8: Lecce After breakfast, end of services. Possibility to book a transfer to the airport of Bari or Brindisi.

3718.post_title: L100 - Cycling Tuscany: from Florence to Siena and Pisa

pods_fields.titolo: Cycling Tuscany: from Florence to Siena and Pisa
pods_fields.desc_min: A stunning itinerary through one of the most famous and enchanting regions of Italy: Tuscany. Gentle hills, Chianti vineyards, Medieval towers and world-famous monuments are only some of the magic ingredients of this journey.
pods_fields.desc:
• Discover Tuscany's huge heritage of art, history and culture.
  • Cycle among vineyards, rolling hills and hilltop medieval villages.
  • Choose between Standard or Deluxe hotels.
  • Enjoy local cuisine surrounded by vineyards and olive groves.
  • Relax and let our Travel App MyEasyRoute guide you along the route and across stories and secrets of the places you will bike through.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 243 km Day 1: Florence Individual arrival in Florence, a gem of Medieval and Renaissance art, one of the most important historic cities all over the world. Overnight at the hotel in Florence.  Day 2: Florence – Greve in Chianti (44 km) Briefing at 09.30 a.m. with delivery of road-book (if booked), practical information on the tour and bikes (if rented). Departure by bike from Florence to Impruneta, a landmark for Italian terracotta art, where you can visit the ancient villas and the Basilica. After approximately 10 km, you will reach Mercatale, a small town surrounded by Chianti hills. Here, you will have the chance to taste some local wines and typical products of the area at the wine cellar of the Castle Il Palagio. Overnight at the hotel in Greve in Chianti (Standard)/in Greve countryside (Deluxe). Day 3: Greve in Chianti – Radda in Chianti (31 km) Riding your bike, you will discover one of the best-known Tuscan areas: La Strada dei vini (the Wine Road). Departure from Greve in Chianti and across the fortified medieval village of Montefioralle. Then, after the beautiful village of Panzano, you will finally reach Radda in Chianti. The Chianti Classico area, located between Florence and Siena, appears like a hilly landscape varied and colourful. It is here that the famous wine was born during the Etruscan Age. In Radda in Chianti, it is possible to visit the Palazzo Pretorio dating back to the 15th century, the remains of the ancient city walls and medieval towers. Overnight ate the hotel in Radda in Chianti countryside (Standard)/Radda city center (Deluxe). Day 4: Radda in Chianti – Siena (41 km) Today the tour will lead you from Radda in Chianti to Siena. The first stop will be at the Meleto Castle, an ancient fortification transformed into a magnificent typical villa immersed in the Tuscan countryside. Cycling over the fortified village of Castagnoli, you will continue towards the famous Castle of Brolio. Here you will have the chance to enjoy a wine tasting an the Ricasoli wine cellar. In the afternoon, pedalling through the colourful hilly surroundings, you will reach Siena, famous for its Palio. Visiting the city, you will discover some of the most remarkable monuments of Italy: Piazza del Campo, Palazzo Pubblico, and the Duomo, dating back to the the 12th century and fully covered in white and dark-green precious marbles. Overnight at the hotel in Siena. Day 5: Siena – Colle Val d’Elsa (27 km) Leaving Siena and cycling among the rolling hills of the surroundings, you will come across charming small villages such as Sovicille. You will continue then until reaching Colle Val d' Elsa, the so-called Bohemia of Italy. Colle Val d’Elsa is an ancient Etruscan city allied, since 1100 to Florence against Siena. From the 15th century onwards, the town started to flourish, thanks to the development of the glass craftsmanship and trade, strictly connected wit the presence of the Elsa river. Possible visit to a handicraft laboratory of crystal manufacturer. Overnight at the hotel in Colle Val d'Elsa. Day 6: Colle Val D’elsa – Volterra (46 km) From Colle Val d’Elsa you will cycle to San Gimignano. From the hilltop where the village was founded, it dominates the Elsa Valley and stands as a splendid example of a well-preserved Medieval city. Its fame is mostly due to  the numerous towers still adorning it. Thanks to its uniqueness, in 1990, it was awarded the title of World Heritage Site by Unesco. The village, rising behind its high walls, is split by two main axis forming a cross: the east-west axis stretches from the Hill of the Tower to the Hill of Montestaffoli, while the north-south axis goes from the Gate of San Giovanni to the Gate of San Matteo, another pass-through point of the Via Francigena. In the late afternoon, you will reach Volterra. This city can boast about 3000 years of history and is known all over the world for its workshops specialized in the sculpting of alabaster. Do not miss the Acropoli, the roman theatre and the walls enclosing the historical centre. Overnight at the hotel in Volterra. Day 7: Volterra - Pisa (54 km) Departure from Volterra to Ghizzano, a village immersed in a landscape full of vineyards. After approximately 2 hours cycling, you will reach Calcinaia and finally Pontedera. From here, transfer by train to Pisa, the city of the Leaning Tower. Overnight at the hotel in Pisa. Day 8: Pisa After breakfast, end of services. Free time to visit the city, the Cathedral, the Baptistery and the famous Leaning Tower all dominating the unique Piazza dei Miracoli. The length of daily stages could vary of a few kilometers depending on the chosen hotel category.

3717.post_title: L100S - Cycling Tuscany by Road Bike: from Florence to Siena and Pisa

pods_fields.titolo: Cycling Tuscany by Road Bike: from Florence to Siena and Pisa
pods_fields.desc_min: A memorable experience on your road bike throughout the most beautiful and renowned Tuscan landscapes. Pedal from Florence to Pisa through San Giminiano, Volterra and Siena immersed in the quiet hilly countryside.
pods_fields.desc: If you are eager to embark in the venture to explore one of the most famous regions of Italy, this itinerary across Tuscany is what you are looking for. The region is famous for its wines, its cities of art and the warm welcome you get from its inhabitants, that is to say the best combination of emotions, scents and traditions  perfectly combined and ready to be discovered by bike. From Piazza della Signoria in Florence to Piazza dei Miracoli in Pisa, you will pass through Siena, San Gimignano and then Volterra. Starting with a short visit of Florence, the first part of the tour brings you to the very heart of Tuscany, along the "road of wines", where the famous Chianti is produced. Here take a bit of time off the pedals and enjoy a wine tasting in one of the numerous local wine cellars. Passing through Siena, the tour then continues towards Colle Val d'Elsa, the "Bohemia of Italy", then heads to San Gimignano, famous for its towers enriching the landscape , and Volterra, the city of alabaster. Finally, you reach Pisa, where the Leading Tower dominates over Piazza dei Miracoli.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance km 331 or 377 Day 1: Florence Individual arrival in Florence, a gem of Medieval and Renaissance art, one of the most important historic cities all over the world.Overnight in Florence. Day 2: Florence – Radda in Chianti (69 km) Briefing at 09:30 am: customers get route book (if booked), practical information on the tour and bikes (if rented). Today your adventure leads you through the heart of Tuscany, rich in art, scents and traditions. Departure by bike from Florence to Impruneta, a landmark for Italian terracotta art, where you can visit its ancient villas and the Basilica. After approximately 10 km, you reach Mercatale, a small town surrounded by the Chianti hills; here, you will have the chance to taste some local wines and products inside the wine cellar of the Palagio Castle. You are cycling along "the road of wines". You can’t miss a visit to Greve in Chianti: the main public square with its original irregular triangle shape is still at the centre of the city life. You continue towards the fortified medieval village of Montefioralle dominating Greve, and then, after riding through the splendid village of Panzano, you reach Radda in Chianti. The Chianti area, situated between Florence and Siena, appears like a hilly landscape varied and colourful. It is here that the famous wine was born during the Etruscan Age. In Radda in Chianti, it is possible to admire the Palazzo Pretorio dating back to 1400 and the remains of the city walls and medieval towers. Overnight in Radda in Chianti. Day 3: Radda in Chianti - Siena (43 km) Today’s itinerary leads you from Radda in Chianti to Siena. The first stop will be at the Meleto Castle, an ancient fortification transformed into a magnificent typical villa immersed in the Tuscan countryside. Cycling over the fortified village of Castagnoli, you will continue towards the famous Castle of Brolio which  is rich in  suggestions  coming from  ancient times. Here you can enjoy a wine tasting in the Ricasoli wine cellar. In the afternoon, pedalling through the colourful hilly surroundings, you will reach Siena, famous for its Palio. Visiting the city, you will discover some of the most remarkable monuments of Italy: Piazza del Campo, Palazzo Pubblico, and the Duomo di Siena, built  in the 12th century and fully covered in white and dark-green precious marble. Overnight in Siena. Day 4: Siena – Montalcino –  Siena (70 km or 116 km) Leaving Siena and cycling through the rolling downs of the surroundings, you will come cross small villages such as Murlo. From here on, you will be surrounded by the famous Brunello vineyards and it is pedalling through vineyards that you reach the town of Montalcino.  After stopping for a glass of local wine, you continue  towards Asciano and Monte Oliveto Abbey, a spot that is ideal for a peaceful pause. You are now in the area known as  “Crete Senesi”, the Siena clays. This  territory includes in itself everything we have come to associate with the idea of Tuscany: a landscape of gently undulating hills, lined with cypress trees and covered by a patchwork of fields, olive groves and vineyards, tiny rural villages, fascinating hilltop towns and great art cities. This is the landscape you cross  while cycling to Siena (116 km). You can shorten the stage  by cycling up to Montalcino: from here take a train directly to Siena (70 km). Day 5: Siena  - Volterra (73 km) Leaving Siena behind, you continue cycling along the Francigena Way,  crossing some little villages like Sovicille until reaching Abbadia a Isola. Little known fact: the church of this town is known for being similar to the entrance to the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem.  Along the way, you have the chance to see the Castle of Monteriggioni. You then continue for Castel Petraio  and then Colle Val d' Elsa, the so-called "Bohemia of Italy". Colle Val d’Elsa is an ancient Etruscan city; since 1100 it had been allied to Florence against Siena. From the 15th century onwards, the town started to flourish, mainly thanks to the development of the glass craftsmanship and trade and the related exploitation of the river Elsa. Possible visit to an handicraft laboratory of crystal manufactures. From Colle Val d’Elsa you cycle to San Gimignano. From the hilltop where it was founded, this town dominates the Elsa Valley and stands as a splendid example of a well-preserved Medieval city. Its fame is mostly due to  the numerous towers still adorning it. Thanks to its uniqueness, in 1990, it was awarded the title of World Heritage Site by Unesco. The village, rising behind its high walls, is split by two main axis forming a cross: the east-west axis stretches from the Hill of the Tower to the Hill of Montestaffoli, while the north-south axis goes from the Gate of San Giovanni to the Gate of San Matteo, another pass-through point of the Via Francigena. In the late afternoon, you arrive in Volterra. This city can boast about 3000 years of history and is known all over the world for its workshops specialized in the sculpting of alabaster. You can visit the Acropoli, the roman theatre and the walls enclosing the historical centre. Overnight in Volterra. Day 6: Volterra - Pisa (76 km) Departure from Volterra to Ghizzano, a village immersed in a landscape of vineyards. After approximately 2 hours cycling, you reach Calcinaia, then continuing towards Pontedera. From here, transfer by train to Pisa, the city of the Leaning Tower. Overnight in Pisa. Day 7: Pisa The tour ends after breakfast.  Free time to visit the city, with its Cathedral, the Baptistery and the famous Leaning Tower dominating Piazza dei Miracoli.

3716.post_title: L097 -  Emilia Romagna for Foodies: cycling from Parma to Bologna

pods_fields.titolo: Emilia Romagna for Foodies: cycling from Parma to Bologna
pods_fields.desc_min: A tasting and cycling trip for real foodies across Emilia Romagna, the queen of Italian gastronomy and the Po Valley, from the elegant Parma to the erudite and charming Bologna.
pods_fields.desc:
• Cycling across Emilia Romagna's flatlands.
  • Learning how precious Traditional Balsamic Vinegar of Modena has been produced for centuries directly in a typical and beautiful Acetaia.
  • Walking under Bologna colonnaded medieval grid and attend a cooking class where you will learn the secrets of local dishes.
  • Enjoy dinners in typical Trattorias.
  • Choose the hotel category you prefer.
  • Leave all your worries at home and simply enjoy your trip thanks to our Support Service Plus, included the price.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance: 313 km Day 1: Parma Individual arrival. Take some time to visit the city center, rich of art masterpieces, elegant parks and treasures from across the centuries. The city will welcome you with a refined atmosphere of a small capital. Overnight at the hotel in Parma. Day 2: Parma – Fontanellato  – Parma (57 km) After breakfast, welcome briefing and bike delivery (if rented). You can now start your cycling adventure through the countryside on partially paved lanes. The first jewel you will meet is the village of San Secondo, where you will have the opportunity to visit a caseificio (cheese factory) where Parmigiano Reggiano is produced. The strict production regulations, the close connection to its land of origin, the use of raw milk and other natural ingredients (16 liters of milk are required to make 1 kg of Parmesan cheese) are the key features that make this cheese different from all imitations. Don’t miss a tasting! The itinerary continues towards Fontanellato where you will find the mighty fortress of San Vitale, a castle dating back to the 14th century and home to a great Parmigianino painting. Dinner in a typical Trattoria and overnight at the hotel in Parma. Day 3: Parma – Reggio Emilia (59 km) After having discovered the secrets of the making of Parmigiano Reggiano, now it's Parma Ham's turn. The delicate flavor, the slightly salty and fragrant aroma, are the results of the peculiar climate conditions in which this ham is dried and aged. The air of the region, scented by pinewoods and Versilia chestnuts growing on the hills surrounding the city of Parma, ensures the essential features of real Parma Ham. Continue on this pleasant route cycling through cultivated fields until you reach the ancient fortress of Montechiarugolo, overlooking the Enza river and the Castle of Montecchio, which was part of Matilda di Canossa Duchy's defense system. End this wonderful day with a ride across the city of Reggio Emilia. Enjoy the beautiful buildings and churches of the old town. Overnight at the hotel in Reggio Emilia. Day 4: Reggio Emilia  – Carpi – Modena (57 km) Today’s route across the lowlands of the Po Valley will offer you many possibilities of visits and tastings. You will first reach the little town of Correggio, a prestigious small Renaissance court bearing the name of the famous painter born here. The itinerary continues across Lambrusco vineyards on the way to Carpi, a pearl of the Renaissance and home to the ancient Pio family. Experience the significant artistic heritage dating back to the Middle Ages. Visit the beautiful Romanesque church known as La Sagra, the historic Deportation Museum and Piazza Martiri (the city square), the third largest in Italy with the theatre and the castle. The last 18 km will take you to Modena's city centre, with its monumental treasures: the Cathedral, Piazza Grande (the main square) and the Ghirlandina Tower, all belonging to UNESCO World Heritage. Dinner in a local Trattoria to taste the typical Gnocco e Tigelle and overnight at the hotel in Modena. Day 5: Modena  –  Vignola – Castelvetro – Modena (65 km) After breakfast, you will leave Modena riding on a cycle path tracing an historic railway route and taking to Spilamberto. Here you will have the possibility to visit an Acetaia, where the authentic Traditional Balsamic Vinegar of Modena is produced, unlike any other vinegar, directly from the grapes juice. The route will take you then to Vignola, the city of cherries and Torta Barozzi, a local chocolate cake made with a secret recipe, closely guarded at the Caffè-Pasticceria Gollini, a traditional pastry shop located in the city center After a short visit to Vignola castle, offering a breathtaking view from its walkways and towers, you will then continue cycling on secondary roads up to the beautiful castle-village of Castelvetro, home to the renowned Lambrusco Grasparossa wine. In Castelvetro you will also have the possibility to stop at a local winery for some wine tasting. On the way back to Modena, possible stop at the Casa Museo of Luciano Pavarotti for a visit. Dinner is on your own. Overnight at the hotel in Modena. Day 6: Modena – Nonantola - Bologna (55 km) Before leaving Modena, take your time to visit the Enzo Ferrari Museum, then start following the cycle path leading out of Modena and along the banks of the Secchia river, between the countryside and the vineyards. The first possible stop of the day will be in Nonantola to visit the beautiful Abbey, an important masterpiece of Romanesque style, founded in 752 by Saint Anselmo, and recently restored. The Abbey is located along the Via Romea Nonantolana, the route followed by pilgrims around the year 1000 to reach Rome. You will finally enter Bologna via the Navile cycle path. Once in Bologna, don't miss a stroll under the the wonderful colonnaded medieval grid and a visit to the beautiful historic centre with its towers, the Duomo and the market. In the evening, possibility to attend a cooking class (not included) and learn how to prepare traditional local dishes. Dinner in a typical Trattoria or at the Cooking School and overnight at the hotel in Bologna. Day 7: Bologna (20 km) After breakfast, a half-day cycling will provide a tour of Bologna. In the afternoon, enjoy a stroll in the beautiful city center famous for its nearly 40 km of arcades, the longest in the world. Don't miss Piazza Maggiore, where medieval palaces and towers overlook the energetic daily life and commercial activities. When you will be ready to relax, indulge yourself with a slice of mortadella and a glass of Pignoletto wine in one one the bars in the narrow lanes of the historic centre. Definitely the best way to end your trip! In the evening, possibility to attend a cooking class (not included) and learn how to prepare traditional local dishes. Dinner in a typical Trattoria or at the Cooking School and overnight at the hotel in Bologna. Day 8: Bologna After breakfast, end of services.

3591.post_title: G097 - Emilia-Romagna for Foodies: guided cycling tour from Parma to Bologna

pods_fields.titolo: Emilia-Romagna for Foodies: guided cycling tour from Parma to Bologna
pods_fields.desc_min: If Italy were a house, then Emilia Romagna would definitely be the kitchen. Cycling across Parma, Modena and Bologna in this guided tour, you will have the chance to taste some of the finest Italian delicacies and discover the great artistic masterpieces of this incredible region.
pods_fields.desc: Emilia Romagna, known to be the Italian region with the best food, offers many of Italy’s finest Protected Denomination of Origin (PDO) products: Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, traditional Balsamic Vinegar from Modena, Parma ham, DOCG classified wines, hand-made stuffed pasta such as ravioli, tortellini and lasagna. An easy cycling journey through this area will let you enjoy these specialties onsite directly from the producers, while the dinners of the tour will include extraordinary local dishes prepared according to the tradition. At the same time, during the tour you can experience the art and history of the area and explore its castles and heritage villages dating back to the Ducal period when this region flourished in extraordinary art. The fil rouge of this trip is the Via Emilia, the road built by the Romans in 187 B.C. and crossing the region from east to west, which gave rise to important cities such as Bologna, Modena and Parma at a time when the greatest Italian artists and architects worked in this area. You will firstly discover Parma, with the Cathedral and Abbess Room displaying Correggio’s frescoes. Then Modena with its preserved medieval center and Romanesque Cathedral, a Unesco World Heritage Site. And finally Bologna, the capital of the region, rich in palaces and medieval towers. This city will charm you with its unique atmosphere and its 40 km of Medieval and Renaissance porticoes. On this tour you will encounter a hard-working region where everything reflects the Italian savoir vivre: the preservation of historical and artistic heritage, the taste for good food and the love for refined music, from Verdi’s Opera to Pavarotti.
pods_fields.prog: Total distance 296 km Day 1: Parma Individual arrive in Parma. Take the time to visit the city center, where you will find masterpieces of art, open green spaces, and treasures from across the ages. Welcome meeting at 6pm: initial briefing for the group and bike delivery. Typical dinner in a trattoria and overnight in Parma. Day 2: Parma – Parmigiano tasting – Fontanellato  – Parma (57 km) After breakfast we'll cycle through the countryside along partially paved lanes and past the Charterhouse of Paradigna, a Cistercian Abbey which was celebrated by Stendhal through his novel The Charterhouse of Parma. In San Secondo Parmense, we'll have the chance to visit a caseificio (cheese factory), where authentic Parmesan cheese is produced. Parmigiano Reggiano, one of the most ancient cheeses, is still produced with the same traditional process of eight centuries ago. Don’t miss the tasting! After having learned how "the King of cheeses" is produced, we'll continue towards Fontanellato and the mighty fortified house of Rocca San Vitale. In the afternoon, we'll cycle back to Parma and have dinner in a typical trattoria. Overnight at the hotel in Parma. Day 3: Parma – Torrechiara – Parma ham tasting – Reggio Emilia (62 km) Are you ready to learn how Prosciutto di Parma (Parma Ham) is produced? Parma’s delicate flavor, slightly salty with a fragrant aroma, is the result of the specific climate conditions in which this ham is dried and aged. The afternoon will be dedicated to castle hopping: a cycling journey across the countryside will take us first to the superb and very well-preserved Castle of Torrechiara, then to Montechiarugolo Castle, which was part of the Estense Family’s feud until the beginning of the 18th century. The fitting end to such a day will be a ride in the heart of Reggio Emilia, enjoying the beautiful buildings and churches of the old town. Dinner in a typical trattoria, overnight at the hotel in Reggio Emilia. Day 4: Reggio  Emilia  – Carpi – Modena (57 km) The first stop of the day will be in Correggio, a small Renaissance court bearing the name of the famous painter born here. During the rest of the morning, we’ll ride through the vineyards of Lambrusco di Santa Croce DOP on our way to Carpi, pearl of the Renaissance and ancient home to the Pio family. Final destination of this stage: Modena. This city offers extraordinary beauty concentrated in the graceful historic center. UNESCO has acknowledged the universal value of the city's monumental treasures by designating the Cathedral (Duomo), Piazza Grande, and the Ghirlandina Tower a World Heritage Site. You are free for dinner. Overnight at the hotel in Modena. Day 5: Modena – Balsamic Vinegar tasting –  Vignola – Castelvetro – wine tasting – Modena – gnocco e tigelle dinner (65 km) After breakfast, we’ll cycle from Modena to Spilamberto following a cycle path built on the old railway line. We’ll stop along the way to visit an ancient Acetaia where authentic Traditional Balsamic Vinegar is produced. This vinegar, protected under the European PDO system, can only be produced in the provinces of Modena and Reggio Emilia, where local grapes and semi-continental climate create the right and unique conditions necessary to the creation of such a noble product. After the visit, we’ll continue to Vignola, the city of cherries and Torta Barozzi (a local chocolate cake made out of a secret recipe); we’ll savor a slice of it at the Caffè-Pasticceria Gollini and take a stroll to the mighty castle offering an amazing view of the surrounding landscape from the towers. We’ll then continue cycling on secondary country roads up to the town of Castelvetro renowned for PDO Lambrusco Grasparossa wine. We’ll enjoy a tasting at a local winery. After passing the small town of Formigine, we’ll get back to Modena. The last stop of this rich day will be at Luciano Pavarotti’s House Museum. Dinner will be at a local trattoria to experience the typical dish gnocco e tigelle. Overnight at the hotel in Modena.   Day  6: Modena – Nonantola – Bologna – cooking lesson (55 km) After breakfast, we’ll start riding on the cycle path leading us out of the city of Modena and to the river Secchia; we’ll continue our journey along the quiet river banks, through countryside and vineyards. The first stop will be in Nonantola to visit the Territorial Abbey of Nonantola dating back to the 12th century. This Romanesque masterpiece lies along the Via Romea Nonantolana, a pilgrims route to Rome since the year 1000. Before heading to Bologna, we will stop for a tasting at local wine cellar and private museum, with a motor section including some F1 cars. During our farewell evening we will all partecipate to a cooking lesson, during which you’ll learn how to prepare some Bolognese typical dishes. At the end of the lesson, we’ll eat together what we’ll have prepared! Overnight at the hotel in Bologna. Day 7: Bologna After breakfast, end of services. Individual departure from Bologna. If you have time, we suggest you to take a walk in the beautiful city center, famous for the network of nearly 40 km of arcades, the longest in the world. Nicknamed The Learned one, because of the old University tradition and The Fat one for its rich food legacy, the city of Bologna is also a UNESCO Creative City of Music. It has one of the largest and most well-preserved medieval historical centers filled with restaurants, taverns, theaters and shops. If you are in for a treat, indulge yourself with a slice of mortadella and a glass of Pignoletto wine, the best way to end your trip.

3589.post_title: G059 - Brittany and the Pink Granite Coastline

pods_fields.titolo: Brittany and the Pink Granite Coastline Hiking Tour
pods_fields.desc_min: Along one of the most beautiful stretches of the French coastline, you will discover a bizarre yet ravishing landscape. Wild cliffs, peaceful beaches, small fishing harbors immersed in a pink and blue lunar scenery you won't forget soon.
pods_fields.note: Guided hiking tour with French-speaking guide
pods_fields.desc: Considered one of the most beautiful stretches of the French coastline, the Pink Granite Coast welcomes its visitors in an unusual yet ravishing landscape. The coast, dotted here and there with small white houses with their black slate roofs, blends gently into the sea, with the ocean and the majestic pink granite formation hugging each other in a myriad of shapes. The water and the wind have been carving the enormous rocks of Ploumanach and Ile Renote for over 300 million years and today these massive stones defy all laws of gravity, featuring all possible shades of orange and pink and resembling such things as turtles, witches and even Napoleon’s hat. Our itinerary follows the old Sentier des Douaniers, literally the ‘trail of customs officers’, unwinding from Lannion to Perros-Guirec and then across the wild archipelagos of the Sept-Iles, now home for a huge number of maritime bird species. The pink granite, together with the endless nuances of blue given by the hydrangeas, the Atlantic Ocean and the sky, give back a combination of suggestive sceneries that will leave you breathless and the memories of the wild cliffs, peaceful beaches, small fishermen’s harbors and renowned seaside resorts will stay with you forever.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Lannion Individual arrival in Lannion; meeting at the hotel, right across the street from the train station. Hotel check-in and, at 6 pm, meeting with the guide. Possibility to visit the old town of Lannion on your own. The half-timbered houses, in French “maison à pans de bois”, are typical of Britanny. Also visit Sainte-Anne monastery and chapel and Quais d’Aiguillon. Dinner and overnight stay in Lannion. Day 2: Île-Grande – St Samson  6h30,  +/- 150m, 17 km Tour of the island of Île-Grande: we walk inland and pass through the old space telecommunication station and the Chapel of Saint Samson. The wild, varied island is circled by a set of smaller islands, topping it like a crown and making this corner of the world beautifully unique. Day 3: Trégastel - Ploumanac’h  6 h, +/- 100m, 15 km Transfer to La Clarté. Excursion along the peninsula of Trégastel and Ploumanac’h: we admire the stunning “chaos” of the pink granite rock formation. Rocks seem to have been thrown from above, creating their weird shapes and arrangements. The formation has volcanic origins and the color of the stone is due to the specific mix of minerals in its composition. It was then eroded over millions of years by water and wind, which shaped the stunning landscape we can see today. We walk back passing through the valley of Traouïero, where rocks and houses coexist in a peculiar way. Day 4: the Seven Islands 3h, +/-150m, 12 km Following the old ‘customs trail’ from Polumanac’h to the beach of Trestraou, we find ourselves right in the middle of the pink granite formation. We pass through the oratory of St- Guirec. Excursion (*) to the archipelagus of the Sept Iles, literally the seven islands. Seven kilometers away from the coast, the pink chaos gives shape to Rouzic, Costans, Malban, Bono, Ile aux Moines, Ile Plate, and Le Cerfs, for a total of 40 hectares of pure splendor overhanging the mighty Atlantic abysses. Humans left these barren lands years ago, with the only exception of the two guardians of the lighthouse, coming here every 2 weeks. Today the archipelagos is home to many species of maritime birds, among which the famous puffins. When weather conditions allow it, the excursion also stops at the Ile-aux-Moines, the ‘isle of monks’. *Today’s program will be modified according to the boarding point and the tide tables for that specific day. According to weather conditions, the excursion might or might not include a stop. Under severe weather conditions, the excursion might be entirely canceled and substituted instead with a coastal trip. Day 5: Port Blanc – Paimpol   4h30,  +/- 200 m, 16 km Transfer to Port Blanc, a small picturesque village where we start our trek across the fine sandy beaches of the area around Château. We also reach the famous house located between two huge granite rocks. Transfer to Paimpol, a town with a long history in the maritime field and from where it is possible to enjoy a marvelous view of the Island of Bréhat. Day 6: Ile de Bréhat   4h30,  +/-150m, 12 km Excursion to the Island of Bréhat, which became known as ‘the isle of flowers’ thanks to its natural floral diversity and the beauty of its landscape. We are not exaggerating when we call this spot a ‘corner of paradise’, as the Gulf Stream let this area benefit from a remarkably mild and gentle climate. From here, we can enjoy the wonderful sight of ocean and land hugging each other in multiple ways. While the microclimate is constantly mild all year long, the landscape deeply varies throughout the day according to the tide. At high tide, the island is divided into two parts, the Ile Nord and the Ile Sud, connected only by the small bridge of Vauban. At low tide, an endless number of islets emerge from the water and adorn the view. In the afternoon, transfer to Lannion, where our tour ends. End of the tour at approximately 4 pm.

A basic physical preparation and a small experience with trekking are enough. Guide: local guide speaking French Participants: 14 persons max Luggage transfer: yes Suitable for children: no

3588.post_title: L020 - From Modena to Marina di Massa on the Dukes Road

pods_fields.titolo: From Modena to Marina di Massa on the Dukes Road
pods_fields.part_sum: every day from 20/05 to 16/09/2018 (not possible from 03/08 up to 10/08)
pods_fields.desc_min: The Vandelli Road has its origins in the request of the Duke of Modena to have a safe access to the seashore inside the territory of its duchy. After its construction, the project fell through but what we have today is a wonderful hiking path across the mountains and reaching the sea.
pods_fields.desc: The Vandelli road was built following the desire of the Duke of Modena Francesco III d’Este who wanted to have a safe access to the sea in the territory of its dukedom. The mathematician Domenico Vandelli was asked to draw the layout of a road enabling carriages to cross the Apennines and the Apuane Alps. After 10 years of works, the road was completed in 1751. Unfortunately, the itinerary turned out to be too insidious due to the presence of bandits and unfit for use in case of bad weather. For example, in winter it was too often inaccessible because of the snow so the project (and the road) was soon abandoned after its launch. Nowadays, the Vandelli road is a wonderful hiking path. After having visited the historic city center of Modena and its wonderful Roman Cathedral, which is part of the Unesco World Heritage Sites, you will reach La Santona, the highest spot in the itinerary. Walking through the ancient forest of Fignola, plunged in a wild and silent panorama, you will reach a splendid glacial basin to climb again up to 1700 m, arriving in San Pellegrino in Alpe. Afterwards you will go down the Garfagnana woods, coming across little hamlets, medieval villages and Roman parish churches. Finally you will cross the Apuane Alps, with their white peaks and the precious marble quarries: the wonderful panorama over the Tyrrhenian sea will finally open up in front of you. The last stretch of hiking will take you directly to the seashore of Marina di Massa.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Modena Individual arrival in Modena and accommodation in hotel. Free time to visit the city. The historical centre of Modena let you dive straight into Middle Age: the main square ‘Piazza Grande’, the Duomo and the Ghirlandina tower form a beautiful ensemble which led in 1997 to the recognition of this area as UNESCO World Heritage Site. Another important building is the Ducal Palace, now hosting one of the most famous Italian Military Academies. Modena is also well-known all over the world for the Ferrari industry, whose seat is located in Maranello (about 20 km from Modena). In Modena you can visit the Museum Casa Enzo Ferrari, the  creator of the brand Ferrari. The town is also rich in typical restaurants where you can taste traditional delicacies and dishes: from local gourmet ingredients such as famous  Balsamic Vinegar of Modena and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, to homemade stuffed pasta ‘tortellini’ and delicious cold cuts to be served together with ‘gnocco fritto’ and ‘tigelle’. Day 2 : Pavullo – La Santona   6h40, +770/-300m,  25 km/15.5 mi Transfer by public bus from Modena to Pavullo with your own luggage. When arriving, you will meet our driver at the bus stop: he will take care of delivering your luggage to your hotel. You can now start the first walking stage and discover some important monuments and villages on the Vandelli road. The first stop is the Castle of Montecuccoli,  main hub of the ancient system of defence of the Frignano area. Its existence was first documented in 1027, when the building was occupied by a German family of feudal overlords known as “da Montecuccoli” from the name of the place where the tower stood. Once arrived in Monzone, do not miss its important castle, dating from approximately  the XII Century and later destroyed. Arrival in La Santona and dinner in Hotel. Day 3 : La Santona – S. Annapelago    4h15, +175/-280m,  18 km/ 11 mi This trek will lead you to Sasso Tignoso. This is a rock formation whose history can be traced back to 80 million years ago, when this region was covered with water and was part of the sea. Magma flowing out of the seabed immediately solidified, thus explaining the distinctive ‘pillow’ shape which gives to Sasso Tignoso its unmistakable appearance. Then, passing by the Giovannoni chapel with its portico topped by a single arch, you will enter in the Frignano Regional Park. This park, established in 1988, is a protected area covering 16 thousand hectares. Arrival in San Annapelago and dinner in Hotel. Day 4: San Annapelago – San Pellegrino in Alpe   3h45,  +600/-150m,  10 km/6.50mi Leaving San Annapelago you will then reach San Pellegrino in Alpe, a beautiful hamlet whose first mention dates back from 1110. The city states of Modena and Lucca fought for years over the possession of this hamlet, where the mummified bodies of San Pellegrino and San Bianco are preserved. Arrival in San Pellegrino in Alpe and dinner in hotel. Day 5: San Pellegrino in Alpe - Castelnuovo Garfagnana  4h45,  +50/-1300m,  14 km /9 mi From San Pellegrino to Castiglione Garfagnana, the Via Vandelli is now an asphalted road. To avoid it, you will take an even older route which drops down towards the valley of Castiglione. Passing by some “metati”, traditional ovens to dry chestnuts, you will reach Castiglione Garfagnana, which was an important defensive stronghold for the Duchy of Lucca in the Este territory. The town stands within its XIV century walls, which form an irregular geometrical shape and have strong towers on their corners and besides the gateways. Leaving Castiglione we continue towards the Mulino di Sotto mill  and towards the town of Pieve Fosciana, with its ancient Church and the Baroque façade. Finally, you will reach Castelnuovo Garfagnana. Dinner in Hotel. Day 6: Castelnuovo Garfagnana – Vagli  5h45, +690/-310m,  16 km/10 mi Castelnuovo, the capital of Garfagnana, stands in a valley separating the Apuanes Alps from the Apennines. Its castle was probably built in the XIII century, with the square central tower serving both as lookout post and prison. Italian poet Ludovico Ariosto lived here as Governor of the Garfagnana from 1522 to 1525. The first part of today’s stage will lead you to the,fortress of Mount Alfonso, built by the Duke Alfonso II of the Este family in the second half of the XVI century. You will then continue towards Vagli di Sotto and its important reservoir. The village of Vagli was an important iron-working centre, and its churches are definitely worth a visit. Arrival in Vagli and dinner in hotel. Day 7: Vagli - Apuan Alps – Resceto, transfer to Marina di Massa  5h40, +1030/-1150m, 13 km/8 mi Departing from Vagli you will enter in the Apuan Alps Regional Park. This park is managed by the Lipu (the Italian society for the Protection of birds). Its visitors centre, the starting point for paths leading into the reserve, is close to the old shepherds’ village of Campocatino. The Apuan Alps Park is also famous for its marble quarries: in fact, whenever the sculptor Michelangelo received a new commission, he climbed here to choose the perfect marble block for his work. As a final step, you will reach the town of Resceto: from here you will be transferred  to Marina di Massa. Day 8: Marina di Massa and the Tyrrhenian Sea After breakfast end of services or extension of your stay in Marina di Massa, seaside resort on the Tyrrhenian coast.

Positive difference in height between 50 and 1030 mt per day. Roads: mountain terrain, paths and white roads Participants: minimum 2 Lugagge transport: yes

3587.post_title: L009 - Cinque Terre and Portofino Hiking Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Cinque Terre and Portofino Hiking Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: A tour to discover an enchanted corner of the Riviera di Levante, Liguria. Immersed in rich nature and mild weather, contemplation and calm will take the place of haste and frenzy.
pods_fields.desc: As if it was a little paradise, in this corner of the Liguria region located at the far end of the Riviera di Levante, contemplation and calm take the place of haste and frenzy. Here, about sixty miles east from Genoa, several generations of farmers have shaped the mountain to feet their needs, building stonewalls to retain the land and creating terraces where to grow vegetables, vines and olive trees. The name Cinque Terre literally means ‘Five lands’, from the five small villages of Monterosso, Vernazza, Corniglia, Manarola and Riomaggiore, nestled above cliffs or into deep, hardly accessible coves, all facing the seafront with their colorful houses. Typical products of this area are extra virgin olive oil, anchovies and liqueurs. Having explored Cinque Terre, we move on to the peninsulas of Portofino and Sestri Levante: posh marinas, millionaires ‘ yachts, lonely pines overlooking green water coves. On the terrace of a local trattoria, facing the sun sinking into the Mediterranean Sea, you will have the time to enjoy the typical focaccia and a glass of white wine after a pleasant hiking day. In the evening, head back from where you started and finish off your trip by enjoying a stroll down the streets of the peaceful small town of Sestri Levante.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Sestri Levante Individual arrival in Sestri Levante. Check-in at the hotel and dinner at the restaurant. Day 2: Cinque Terre park: Monterosso, Vernazza and Corniglia Today’s walk bring you in the heart of the National Park of Cinque Terre. Starting  from Monterosso the first stop is in Vernazza, an important and historical village being the only natural harbor of the Cinque Terre. Out of Vernazza you walk along the olive groves and with views on the sea. Your paths continues gently towards Corniglia, today’s destination. Return by train. Overnight in Sestri Levante. Day 3: Palmaria Island and  Portovenere After breakfast, train transfer to La Spezia (40 min.). By boat (vaporetto) you  go to the Palmaria Island for a circular tour of this little island rich in Mediterranean vegetation. Depending on the period you can see the bloom of cistus and nice rare orchids and admire the colorful wood. Along the way spectacular sceneries on the sea and the coastline. In the first afternoon you will reach by boat Portovenere where you will visit the medial town, the Churches of San Pietro and San Lorenzo and the Byron Grotto. Return to La Spezia by boat or bus and then to Sestri Levante by train. Dinner and overnight. Day 4: Cinque Terre park: Corniglia, Manarola and Riomaggiore Train ride to Corniglia, to begin your second full day in the heart of the Cinque Terre region. From the train station you walk up to the village of Corniglia, one of the most beautiful and well preserved villages of the park. After the visit you continue walking towards Volastra, first in ascent and then in plain, on a scenic path overlooking the sea, among the vineyards. Then it’s time to walk down to Manarola. After the visit of the village you can reach Riomaggiore either by train or with an hour walk climbing and descending a path made of stairs, up to the sea. After a swim, you go back by train to Sestri Levante. Overnight in Sestri Levante.  Day 5: Riomaggiore - Portovenere After a transfer to Riomaggiore you start your  trek to Portovenere along the panoramic path from which it is possible to admire little and picturesque burgs on the sea. From Portovenere return by boat to Monterosso or by bus to La Spezia and then by train. Dinner and overnight in hotel. Day 6 : Portofino After breakfast first train transfer to Rapallo and then by bus to Ruta di Camogli where the  trek starts across the Park of Portofino: Paradiso – Pietre Strette – San Fruttuoso. The path is surrounded by Holm oaks, mixed wood and the Mediterranean brush. The burg of San Fruttuoso is really nice and characterized by the ancient  Abbey of the VIII century. After the visit of the Abbey, boat to Portofino. A short stop here to visit the nice village to continue then  to Santa Margherita Ligure. From here train to Sestri Levante. Overnight in hotel. Day 7:  Sestri Levante After breakfast end of the tour.

3585.post_title: L005D - Naples and the Amalfi Coast Hiking Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Naples and the Amalfi Coast Hiking Trip
pods_fields.part_sum: on Saturdays, all year long. Departure possible on any other day with a little supplement.
pods_fields.desc_min: From the times of the old Néa Polis founded by Greeks and the highest glory of the Baroque Age, the city of Naples has always been charming to every traveller with its artistic treasures, as well as the lovely climate and the beauty of nature of the Amalfi Coast.
pods_fields.desc: Naples and its surroundings is one of the most important cradles of Italian culture and history: Romans and Greeks were here long before the flourishing of the Baroque palaces and churches of Spaccanapoli. From ancient age to the Romantic period, all major artists felt at some point attracted by the charm of this region. Travellers visiting this area are no exception to this feeling of awe and fascination, being captured by the richness of the artistic treasures, the mildness of the climate and the beauty of the nature and landscape. In contrast with this ‘Dolce Vita’, the eruptions of the Vesuvius, the volcanic phenomena of the Phlegrean Fields and the frequent earthquakes pushed the population towards a perceived proximity to the world of the dead and to Gods themselves. It is also thanks to the rage of the volcano if we can visit Pompeii today, as this unique example of ancient times was buried in ashes in 79 AD. Heading southward, we discover Amalfi, the first Maritime Republic of Italy, a city that played a great role in the trade with the Orient and then in the transport of Crusaders. Enchanted by the lovely climate and the beauty of nature, many artists and princes commissioned the construction of their sumptuous villas along this stretch of coast, especially in Ravello. Towards the end of our hiking, as an extension of the peninsula, we encounter Capri, always delighting us with its beauty. This is a tour not to be missed: in a week time, you will discover not only Naples and Pompeii, but also the routes of the Amalfi Coast, from Ravello to Positano, and two of the most beautiful Mediterranean islands in the Bay of Naples, Procida and Capri.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1 :  Napoli Individual arrival in Napoli. You leave the luggage at the hotel and have a stroll to discover Spaccanapoli, the very heart of Naples, characterised by narrow streets, the laundry hanging outside the windows, the rich Baroque churches and palaces, the San Carlo Theatre, the Galleria Umberto I, the Plebiscito Square. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 2 : Napoli  – Ercolano  – Napoli Transfer with the “Circumvesuviana” train to Ercolano. Here you begin your climbing of Mount Vesuvius, first by bus and then on foot, enjoying the wonderful view over the Gulf of Naples. In the afternoon, you visit the archaeological site of Ercolano, which was buried in ashes together with Pompeii in the eruption of the volcano in 79 AD. Return to Naples with the “Circumvesuviana” train. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 3 : Naples  – Capri  – Napoli Boat to Capri. From the tiny port of Marina Grande, the hike leads you to the Hermitage of the Holy Mother of Cetrella through the so-called Passetiello path, a narrow passage between rock faces overlooking the town of Capri and the sea. From the top, you can enjoy a stunning panoramic view on the island and the Gulf of Naples, dominated by Mount Vesuvius. The descent is along the stone steps built by Phoenicians in ancient times. Possibility of bathing. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 4 : Napoli – Pompei – Minori Visit of Pompeii and the Villa of the Mysteries. In the afternoon, private transfer to the Peninsula of Amalfi to reach Minori, a scenic yet authentic village on this stunning stretch of coast, located only 4 km away from Amalfi. Dinner at the hotel. Day 5 : Minori – Valle dei Mulini – Minori Today’s stage takes you hiking along the Valle dei Mulini, literally the Valley of the Mills. Return with public bus from Amalfi to Minori.  Dinner at the hotel. Day 6 : Minori – Ravello – Minori Circular stage. First, hike to Ravello, where it is possible to visit the dome dedicated to Saint Pantaleone. From this village overhanging the sea, the view goes across the Gulf of Salerno and over the Cilento mountains. Optional visit to Villa Cimbrone and Villa Rufolo, characterised by a melange of Arabic, Sicilian and Norman styles. Return, on foot, through Atrani (chance for a swim) and Amalfi. Dinner at the hotel. Day 7 : Minori – Sentiero degli Dei – Minori After breakfast, transfer with public bus to Agerola (private transfer possible with supplement). From here, you start a panoramic hike along Sentiero degli Dei, the Path of Gods. Return to Minori by boat or by public bus. Dinner at the hotel. Day 8 : Minori – Napoli After breakfast, at 9 a.m. transfer to Naples airport, Naples central train station or your hotel in case of extra nights (on request and with supplement, transfer at other times).

To all those who love hiking, this area is never short of exciting itineraries facing the sea and suggestive walks across stone stairs and olive groves.

This is a tour not to be missed: in a week time, you will discover not only Naples and Pompeii, but also the routes of the Amalfi Coast, from Ravello to Positano, and two of the most beautiful Mediterranean islands in the Bay of Naples, Procida and Capri.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1 :  Napoli Individual arrival in Napoli. You leave the luggage at the hotel and have a stroll to discover Spaccanapoli, the very heart of Naples, characterised by narrow streets, the laundry hanging outside the windows, the rich Baroque churches and palaces, the San Carlo Theatre, the Galleria Umberto I, the Plebiscito Square. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 2 : Napoli  – Ercolano  – Napoli Transfer with the “Circumvesuviana” train to Ercolano. Here you begin your climbing of Mount Vesuvius, first by bus and then on foot, enjoying the wonderful view over the Gulf of Naples. In the afternoon, you visit the archaeological site of Ercolano, which was buried in ashes together with Pompeii in the eruption of the volcano in 79 AD. Return to Naples with the “Circumvesuviana” train. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 3: Naples  – Capri  – Napoli Boat to Capri. From the tiny port of Marina Grande, the hike leads you to the Hermitage of the Holy Mother of Cetrella through the so-called Passetiello path, a narrow passage between rock faces overlooking the town of Capri and the sea. From the top, you can enjoy a stunning panoramic view on the island and the Gulf of Naples, dominated by Mount Vesuvius. The descent is along the stone steps built by Phoenicians in ancient times. Possibility of bathing. Overnight stay in Naples hotel 4*. Day 4: Napoli  – Pompei  – Agerola Transfer with the “Circumvesuviana” train to Pompeii. Visit to the buried town and the Villa of the Mysteries, the biggest open-air archaeological site of the world. The area bears remarkable testimony of human life in ancient times, as the huge eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD fixed forever under ash and lava the inhabitants in their daily activities. In the afternoon, private transfer to Amalfi Peninsula to reach the plateau of Agerola and your hotel. Dinner at the hotel. Day 5:  Agerola  – Amalfi  – Agerola Nice walking day from the town of Bomerano di Agerola down to the small fishing harbour of Marina di Praiano. You will follow the Path of the Bloomed Agaves, descending while always enjoying a splendid view over the turquoise sea. From Marina di Praiano, public bus to Amalfi, the most powerful Maritime Republic in the Mediterranean Sea at the end of X century (possible visit to the Cloister of Paradise and church, and to the Paper Museum; possible bath). Back to Agerola by public bus. Dinner at the hotel. Day 6 : Agerola  – Valle dei Mulini  – Agerola After breakfast public bus to Amalfi. Today, following the path still in use by locals and their mules to transport wood, you discover the ‘Valle dei Mulini’. The valley takes its name from the mills (‘mulini’) scattered in the area and used for the production of pasta. The trek continues to Ravello where the cathedral dedicated to Saint Pantaleone stands out. From the village overhanging the sea, at an altitude of 300 meters above sea level, the view goes across the Gulf of Salerno and over to the Cilento Mountains. Optional visit to Villa Cimbrone and to Villa Rufolo, with its melange of Arabic, Sicilian and Norman styles. Return to Amalfi on foot through Atrani (chance for a swim). Back by public bus to Agerola.  Dinner at the hotel. Day 7 : Agerola  – Path  of Gods –  Agerola Departure from Agerola along the panoramic hike known as Sentiero degli Dei, the Path of Gods. Up until the 19th century,  this coastal trail was the only way to get from the small isolated villages to the many tiny terraced fields and vineyards. As you descend, on one side you see over the entire peninsula and Capri;  on the other side, you enjoy the view of the Gulf of Salerno. All along, you can admire the ancient work made by old men on these impervious terrains to create a safe area where people could take shelter during the Barbarian invasions following  the fall of Roman Empire. Once passed Montepertuso, overhung by the rock-face of the mountain, you descend to Positano. The colourful houses of Positano have been built in the shape of an amphitheatre overlooking the sea, giving its unique and picturesque touch to the village. Free time to visit Positano (chance for a swim). Return to Amalfi by boat (or bus) and then public bus to Agerola. Dinner at the  hotel. Day 8 : Agerola – Napoli After breakfast, at 09.00 am transfer to Naples airport/train station/city (on request and with supplement, transfer at other times).

3578.post_title: L004 - The Chianti from Florence to Siena

pods_fields.titolo: The Chianti from Florence to Siena
pods_fields.part_sum: 2019 on Saturdays from 06/04 to 19/10/2019. Departure is possible everyday with a supplement. Pay attention: trips including July 1st + 2nd and August 15th + 16th (Palio in Siena) are not possible.
pods_fields.desc_min: From Piazza della Signoria in Florence to Piazza del Campo in Siena, a trek to join and enjoy two of the most important Tuscan cities, discovering this area from an historical and artistic point of view.
pods_fields.desc: The typical Chianti countryside is a hilly, varied and colourful landscape: here is where the famous wine  was born and has been produced for centuries. Nevertheless, this area does not consist exclusively of vineyards and olive groves. Depending on the season, the nature offers to the visitors stunning, colourful sceneries: from fields of red poppies, violet irises and yellow brooms to the green firs and cypresses dotting the hillsides. Moreover, golden stone villages and castles are scattered around the gentle slopes: among many, Brolio Castle is rich in suggestions from ancient times and is certainly a perfect location where to enjoy a tasting of some excellent local wines. You can further enrich your stay in Tuscany with a visit to Florence - the city of Leonardo, Giotto, Dante and Brunelleschi - and to Siena, native land of the ‘Palio’, a city where the medieval atmosphere is still vibrant. These architectural jewels are landmarks of one of the most famous areas of Tuscany: ‘the Wine Road’, the one you will follow walking along silent paths and backroads surrounded by hills, vineyards and olive groves.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Florence Individual arrival in Florence, free time to visit this magnificent city of art, a real open-air museum. You are free for dinner. Overnight in the city centre. Day 2: Florence – Fiesole Hike to Fiesole: a walk through olive groves and cypress-lined roads, coming across the sumptuous villas dominating the Val d’Arno. The beauty of the landscape is impressive: once reached the hilltop, a wonderful view over Florence will open up right in front of you. Return to Florence. You are free for dinner. Overnight in the city centre. Day 3: Florence – Panzano – Radda in Chianti After breakfast, transfer by bus to Panzano: you leave your luggage to the coach driver and you start your day in the woods, hiking through the typical oak woods of the region. Along the path, you reach Volpaia, a wonderful little village built as a fortified quarter in the 11th century. After lunch you will continue through the vineyards of Montevertine, a very beautiful village dating back to the same period. The itinerary ends in Radda in Chianti. Day 4: Radda in Chianti – Castellina  in Chianti – Radda in Chianti After breakfast, public bus to Castellina in Chianti. Today’s route explores one of the most celebrated stretches of Tuscan land: ‘the Road of Wines’. Start from Castellina in Chianti and rumble on paths and country roads, crossing vineyards and olive groves, to return to the medieval village of Radda in Chianti. This area is where the renowned Chianti Classico wine is produced, and where wine has always been produced, from Etruscan times up until today. Overnight stay in Radda. Day 5: Radda – Gaiole – Brolio castle - Siena Private transfer from Radda to Gaiole in Chianti (you leave your luggage at the hotel in Radda). From Gaiole, you walk up to the famous Brolio Castle, property of the Baron Ricasoli and his family since 1141. Enter the castle and walk on the ancient walls and, if you like, take the chance for a wine tasting. In the afternoon private transfer from Brolio to Siena. Overnight stay in Siena. Day 6: Colle Val d’Elsa – San Gimignano Transfer by public bus to Colle Val d’Elsa. Hike to Quartaia, a small rural village of medieval origins. You continue through the hills to get to Coneo Abbey, founded by the Benedictines, then, walking on the historic Via Francigena, you arrive at Molino d'Aiano. At this point, the peaceful scenery is already dominated by the distinctive shape of San Gimignano towers. Return to Siena by public bus (16 km). You are free for dinner. Overnight in hotel. Day  7: Siena After breakfast end of the tour. You are free to visit Siena, the famous town of Palio. If can enjoy a stroll around Piazza del Campo and down the narrow streets, stopping for a taste of local specialties like Panforte and Ricciarelli in one of the several delicatessens.

3577.post_title: L002 - Southern Tuscany and Val d’Orcia Hiking Trip

pods_fields.titolo: Southern Tuscany and Val d’Orcia Hiking Trip
pods_fields.desc_min: The famous ‘Crete Senesi’, abbeys, castles and hills of vineyards are only some of the enticing ingredients of this tour.
pods_fields.desc: The famous area of ‘Crete Senesi’ and its abbeys, castles and hills of vineyards are only some of the enticing ingredients of this tour. We are in the south east of Tuscany, where the scenery changes according to the season, ranging from the green meadows of spring, to the gold wheat fields of summer, and then again to the sea of red leaves of autumn. After a day spent in the charming city of Siena, you will start your walking experience from the small village of Buonconvento. Along the road, you will reach many places and villages of historical importance: the Abbey of Monte Oliveto; the Medieval town of Montalcino  ̶  where you can also taste a glass of its excellent red wine; Sant'Antimo, the most beautiful Benedictine Abbey of Tuscany; Bagno Vignoni, a thermal resort since the Middle Age; the fascinating villages of San Quirico d'Orcia and Pienza among others. In the second part of the tour, you will reach Montepulciano, the most important settlement in the Val di Chiana area. This town is an architectural jewel dating back from the 3rd century BC, still showing today its majestic palaces, narrow alleys and colourful buildings of subsequent ages. No lesser important, here you will have the opportunity to taste its world-renown ‘Noble wine’ in one of the 16th century wine cellars located in the old city centre.
pods_fields.prog: Day 1: Siena Individual arrival in Siena. Visit of the city with its medieval charm and historical city centre.  Overnight stay in Siena. Day 2: Siena – Buonconvento  – Monte Oliveto Short train ride with your luggage to Buonconvento. Accommodation in your hotel and start of the walking itinerary. Trekking among the famous Crete Senesi (literally ‘Siena Clays’) to reach the Abbey of Monte Oliveto, where you can visit the cloister and its renowned frescos. During the day, you also reach the castle of Monterongriffoli and the tiny village of Chiusure. From the Abbey of Monte Oliveto private transfer back to your hotel. Dinner in Buonconvento. Day 3: Buonconvento  – Montalcino Hiking through the wonderful hills covered with the famous Brunello’s vineyards, you pass along some beautiful private villas and cellars. When in Montalcino, after tasting a glass of excellent wine, you can visit the Priori Palace, the Loggia, The Church of Sant’Egidio and the Rocca, a pentagonal defence fortress built in 1361 and forerunner of the Tuscan fortresses typical of the Medicean Age. Return transfer to Buonconvento with public bus. Dinner in Buonconvento. Day 4: Sant’Antimo  – San Quirico  d’Orcia Private transfer to Sant’Antimo. From Sant’Antimo, the most suggestive Benedictine Abbey of Tuscany, you cross the Crete area on foot, thus enjoying a unique and stunning view over the whole area, and finally reach the castle of Ripa d’Orcia. From this viewpoint, you have the time to enjoy the panorama above the Orcia river and the towns of Castiglione and Rocca d’Orcia. You then head towards Bagno Vignoni, a thermal resort since the Middle Age, with a stunning thermal bath right in the middle of the square of the village, and then pass over Vignoni, a little settlement with a medieval atmosphere, to finally reach San Quirico d’Orcia. Public bus to Montepulciano. Day 5 : Montepulciano  – Pienza Itinerary:  Montepulciano – Monticchiello – Pienza and back to Montepulciano by public bus. Pienza, chosen by Pope Pio II as his temporary residence, is the quintessential Renaissance town. From there, we hike to the charming medieval village of Monticchiello. There is no better way to discover it than wandering along its streets, with the houses made of stones and tiny squares suddenly opening up at the end of a narrow alley. The itinerary ends in Montepulciano, the biggest town in the Val di Chiana area and  well known for its famous ‘Vino Nobile’. You should not miss the possibility to taste this delicacy in one of the 16th century cellars in the ancient city centre. The town is an architectural jewel with its magnificent Renaissance palaces, narrow streets and brick buildings. Day 6: Pienza – San Quirico  d’Orcia  Transfer to Pienza by public bus. From Pienza you will walk across the typical ‘Crete Senesi’ landscape, and after a couple of hilly ups and downs  you will reach San Quirico d’Orcia. This town is located on the Via Francigena the pilgrim road heading to Rome, which contributed to the considerable economic growth of the town. Return to Montepulciano by public bus. Day 7: Montepulciano Urban trekking in Montepulciano, the biggest town centre of the Val di Chiana, with its famous locally produce wine that you can taste in one of the Sixteenth century cellars. Individual departure in the early afternoon; from Montepulciano bus station you can go to Siena, Florence (connection in Siena) or Chiusi by public bus. Private transfer possible.
