1666.post_title: L277 - From London to Amsterdam by bike

pods_fields.titolo: From London to Amsterdam by bike
pods_fields.desc_min: Four countries, two cosmopolitan capital cities, one tour. The colors green and blue as a common thread, a quiet passage along rivers and sandy beaches and through colorful and pleasant towns.
pods_fields.desc: The intense green of the English countryside, the vibrant green of the Flemish pastures, the lush green of the Dutch orchards. And blue, synonymous with water, from the River Thames to the North Sea to the canals of Holland. The itinerary of this tour runs through four different countries, with the colors green and blue as a common thread throughout the days. You will have the chance to discover how two European cosmopolitan capital cities can be connected by peace and tranquility as you ride at your own pace through meadows, along rivers and sandy beaches. Departing from Greenwich, a charming London neighborhood, this tour takes you first through the beautiful county of Kent, the Garden of England. Crossing by ferry from Dover, England to Dunkirk, France, you continue for a short distance on French soil and then into Flanders, in Belgium, a land rich in fields and meadows mingled with waterways, sandy beaches and seaside promenades. Here you have the chance to discover firsthand why Belgium is known for chocolate, waffles, lace and beer. Explore the unforgettable sites of elegant Ostend and romantic Bruges. Then, experience the Netherlands, a land reclaimed from the water, a combination of land, rivers and canals. This is also the home of wooden shoes, windmills and the birthplace of renowned artists such as Rembrandt and Van Gogh. Then, as your last step, you enter Amsterdam, with its old history and contemporary open-minded, bike-oriented feel. Embark on this unique journey and rediscover the pleasure of exploration.
pods_fields.prog:
PROGRAM LONDON TO AMSTERDAM Total km  347 / 216 mi. Day 1: London/Greenwich Individual arrival in Greenwich and hotel check in.  At 6 pm attend a welcome meeting with your guide and receive your bike. Dinner is on your own in the charming village of Greenwich. Greenwich - an UNESCO World Heritage Site - is an ancient village overlooking the south bank of the River Thames. The Royal Observatory stands on the hill overlooking the village. From here you can admire the Thames and St. Paul's Cathedral. The historic astronomical observatory is the location of Greenwich Prime Meridian for which the village is known worldwide. Every day at 1 pm the red globe atop the observatory is dropped to mark the time (GMT). In the evening a laser travels through the skies of Greenwich marking the Prime Meridien. Greenwich is also a place rich in history. It was the site of a royal palace, the birthplace of King Henry VIII, including the most ancient royal park of city. Extraordinary architecture such as the Charlton House and the Queen's House, many village parks, and one of the most popular markets of London are here to see and explore. All that, along with the tranquility pervading the village, makes Greenwich one of the most fascinating areas of the capital. Day 2 : Greenwich – Canterbury  42 Km / 26 mi. After breakfast starts the tour by cycling along the southern bank of the river Thames to Dartford (31 km).  From Dartford you will travel by train (not included) across the County of Kent to Whitstable (1h20). Kent is known as “garden of England” for its green landscape dotted with some of the most beautiful and famous gardens of the UK. Once in Whitstable  you will ride the last 10 km by bike to the day’s destination, Canterbury. This beautiful town is located on the main road between Dover and London. It is the starting point of the Francigena Way and, in spite of its medieval past, is now lively with students who come here from all over Europe to attend its important University. The city was the first capital of the Saxon kingdom of Kent and the seat of the first Christian diocese of England founded by St. Augustine. The magnificent Christ Church Cathedral dominates the narrow alleys and half-timbered houses of the old medieval city center. Today, after several renovations, the Cathedral is one of the best examples of English Gothic architecture. Day 3 : Canterbury – Dover + ferry to Dunkirk  50 km / 32 mi. Early start in the morning to cycle 34 km to Dover, famous for its white cliffs and one of the most important ports of Great Britain. Here you board the ferry to Dunkirk France (about 2 hours + 1 Time Zone). Once in France you will ride 18 km from the port to the center of the city. Dunkirk is the third most important port in France. It is located in the Nord- Pas de Calais, 10 km from the border with Belgium. At first glance Dunkirk is an industrial town focused on maritime trade. But then the unusual beauty of this place sets in with its dunes and tens of kilometers of sandy beaches flourishing in flora and fauna. Kite-surfing and the famous surf on the sand are popular activities here. The city center is characterized by low buildings, mainly of the last century, and Flemish influences. The church of St. Eloi and the two bell towers are included in the UNESCO World Heritage Site and are well worth a visit. Day 4 :  Dunkirk – Bruges 79 km / 49 mi. The majority of this stage occurs in Belgium. Once across the France-Belgium border you will ride through the Flemish green countryside. Several World War II battles took place here as French and British troops tried to block the German invasion. Cycling along the coast of the North Sea you will reach Ostend, a popular tourist destination on the Flemish coast characterized by its wide promenade bordered by shops, hotels and restaurants where you can taste excellent mussels, oysters and drink local beers. The bike tour continues through the Flanders region towards the romantic city of Bruges where time seems to have stopped and everything runs slowly. Day 5 :  Bruges – Breskens 45 km  +  ferry to Vlissingen / 28 mi. After breakfast take time to visit Bruges. As you walk through the city center you will discover historic buildings, lace shops, pubs serving local beers, and a network of canals. A canal tour is an unique and interesting way to discover the city. You then continue the tour through the countryside along the Dutch border in the direction of Breskens. Here a short ferry ride (about 15 minutes - not included) will take you to Vlissingen, the day’s destination. This fishing town is home to shipyards and a naval academy. The promenade, called Boulevard, is a long and beautiful walkway where a prison tower dating from the fifteenth century is located. Day 6 : Vlissingen – Kinderdijk  - Dordrecht – Vianen   66 km / 41 mi. After breakfast, transfer by train from Vlissingen to Dordrecht (1h30 - not included). Dordrecht is a elegant river town rich in art, theater and architecture. This cultural center gave birth to several accomplished artists including students of Rembrandt. From here you will cycle through the Dutch countryside crossing flower gardens, walled cities, canals and dams. You then continue northwards through pastures, orchards and meadows  dotted with windmills to the village of Vianen. Day 7 :  Vianen – Amsterdam   65 km / 40 mi. During the last cycling day you will travel first to Utrecht. Utrecht is an old city vibrant with culture and university life. The historic center is characterized by medieval palaces and ancient buildings, evidence of its rich commercial past. Picturesque canals are fringed by wine cellars transformed into trendy clubs, pubs and coffee shops surround the docks. From Utrecht  continue through charming towns and along canals on the way to Amsterdam, the cosmopolitan capital of the Netherlands. Amsterdam is famous for streets that weave with canals, for its architecture, and especially for its open-minded society. Cycling is definitely the most suitable way to visit the center. But a tour of the canals by boat is highly recommended. Dam Square, museums of art and history, and the Anne Frank house await you. Day 8 : After breakfast end of the tour.
PROGRAM  AMSTERDAM – LONDON Total km about 349 / 218 mi. Day 1: individual arrival in Amsterdam Individual arrival in Amsterdam and hotel check in.  At 6 pm attend a welcome meeting and receive your bike.  Dinner is on your own in this unique city. Amsterdam, the cosmopolitan capital of the Netherlands, is famous for streets that weave with canals, for its architecture, and especially for the open-minded society. Cycling is definitely the most suitable way to visit the city center. But a tour of the canals by boat is highly recommended. Dam Square, museums of art and history, and the Anne Frank house await you. Day 2 : Amsterdam –  Vianen about  66 km / 41 mi. Depart Amsterdam cycling south through charming towns and along canals on the way to Utrecht. Utrecht is an old city vibrant with culture and university life. This historic city is characterized by medieval palaces and ancient buildings, evidence of its rich commercial past. Picturesque canals are fringed by wine cellars transformed into trendy clubs. Pubs and coffee shops surround the docks. From Utrecht continue the ride to the day’s destination, the village of Vianen. Day 3 : Vianen – Dordrecht + Dordrecht –Vlissingen by train about 67 km  /  42 mi. Your tour continues through the Dutch countryside surrounded by pastures and meadows dotted with windmills. Along the way we cross flower gardens, walled cities, canals and dams. Dordrecht is a elegant river town rich in art, theater and architecture. This cultural center gave birth to several accomplished artists including students of Rembrandt. From Dordrecht transfer by train to Vlissingen (1h30 – not included). This fishing town is home to shipyards and a naval academy. The promenade, called Boulevard, is a long and beautiful walkway where a prison tower dating from the fifteenth century is located. Day 4 :  ferry Vlissingen – Breskens and  Breskens – Bruges 44 km  / 28 mi. After breakfast start the day with a short ferry ride (about 15 minutes - not included) from Vlissingen to Breskens Belgium. From here cycle along canals and fields towards the romantic city of Bruges where time seems to have stopped and everything runs more slowly. Explore the city center and discover the pleasures of Belgian chocolate, lace, and beer. A tour through the network of canals is an unique and interesting way to discover the city. Day 5 :  Bruges – Dunkirk   80 km / 50 mi. Your ride continues northward through the Flanders region rich in pastures, historic sites and charming towns. The first stop will be in Ostend, a popular tourist destination on the Flemish coast. Enjoy the wide promenade bordered by shops, hotels and restaurants, savor the fresh mussels, oysters, and local beers. Then continue on your way to the French border. Several World War II battles took place here as French and British troops fought to block the German invasion. Once across the French border, ride through rich farmland and along the coast of the North Sea to arrive in Dunkirk. Dunkirk is the third most important port in France. It is located in the Nord- Pas de Calais. At first glance Dunkirk is an industrial town focused on maritime trade. But then the unusual beauty of this place sets in with its dunes and tens of kilometers of sandy beaches flourishing in flora and fauna. Kite-surfing and the famous surf on the sand are popular activities here. The city center is characterized by low buildings, mainly of the last century, and Flemish influences. The church of St. Eloi and the two bell towers are included in the UNESCO World Heritage Site and are well worth a visit. Day 6 : ferry to Dover + Dover – Canterbury  50 km / 31 mi. Depart early to cycle 16 km to the port of Dunkirk. Here board the ferry to Dover (about 2 hours - 1 Time Zone). Dover, famous for its white cliffs, is one of the most important ports of Great Britain. Once in Dover cycle 34 km to Canterbury. This beautiful town, located on the main road between Dover and London, is the starting point of the Francigena Way and, in spite of its medieval past, is now lively with students who come here from all over Europe to attend its important University. The city was the first capital of the Saxon kingdom of Kent and the seat of the first Christian diocese of England founded by St. Augustine. The magnificent Christ Church Cathedral, one of the best examples of English Gothic architecture, dominates the narrow alleys and half-timbered houses of the old medieval city center. Day 7 :  Canterbury  –  Greenwich  42 Km / 26 mi. Your last cycling day begins with a 10 km ride to Whitstable. In Whitstable you board a train and travel across the County of Kent to Dartford (not included -  1h20). Kent is known as “garden of England” for its green landscape dotted with some of the most beautiful and famous gardens of the UK. Once in Dartford you cycle the last 31 km traveling along the southern bank of the river Thames to Greenwich. Greenwich - an UNESCO World Heritage Site - is an ancient village overlooking the south bank of the River Thames. It is located just a few kilometers from the center of London. The Royal Observatory stands on the hill overlooking the village. From here you can admire the Thames and St. Paul's Cathedral. The historic astronomical observatory is the location of Greenwich Prime Meridian for which the village is known worldwide. Every day at 1 pm the red globe atop the observatory is dropped to mark the time (GMT). Day 8 : The tour ends after breakfast.   The length of every stage and the overnights stops are indicative and may vary according with the date. Customers will receive the details with hotel list before the departure.

1455.post_title: L110 - The Castles of the Loire Valley by bike

pods_fields.titolo: The Castles of the Loire Valley by bike
pods_fields.part_sum: on Sundays from 14/07 to 18/08; every day from 15/05 to 13/07 and from 19/08 to 30/09/2019
pods_fields.desc_min: Châteaux, abbeys, white tufa cliffs, black slate roofs, fields of sunflowers and endless vineyards are the ingredients of this tour. Plus, if you are new to bike holidays or you are travelling with kids, this itinerary will suit you perfectly.
pods_fields.desc: ‘Douce France‘ or ’Jardin de France‘: this . If you are seeking a  unique experience to rediscover the outdoors, take a bike tour through this vibrant cultural landscape and enjoy the harmonious way of life where man has found his rightful place in nature. . As you travel to the heart of the Loire region, you will pass châteaux and abbeys, historic cities, classic small villages, and vineyards as far as the eye can see. All around you, white tufa stone and black slate color the landscape of the region. Let the royal river lead you to the grand gates of the famous châteaux: Chenonceau, a sumptuous bridge on the river Cher; Chaumont, a delicate fortress in the forest; Blois, where French history unfolded; Amboise, home to the tomb of Leonardo da Vinci;  Chambord, with its 380 chimneys and 406 rooms, representing the apotheosis of the Loire Castles. Discover this enchanted territory as you cycle an easy, relaxing route on secondary roads, through forests, and along the river Loire and its tributaries. This self-guided tour is suitable also for all those who are facing their first experience with a cycling holiday and for families with children. During the tour you will stay in three hotels (in Blois, Amboise and Tours) and you will alternate  circular and  itinerant stages. This represents a very flexible solution: you won’t have to worry  in case of bad weather, or if you get too tired, or even  if you want to skip a bike day and visit a different  castle.  Blois, Amboise and Tours are connected by frequent trains, so you can always opt for an alternative to the bike tour. This is especially suitable for families, as you can choose what to do every day, following your kids’ needs and times.
pods_fields.prog: Total km 186/200 – 117/120 mi. Day 1: Blois Individual arrival in Blois.  Hotel check-in and free time to visit the town. Day 2: Blois – Chambord – Blois  (38-42 km / 24-27 mi.) After crossing the Loire and the Sologne countryside, you enter the park of the chateau of Chambord, 4,500 hectares of forest inhabited by deer and wild boars. Visit of the magnificent castle which was built by François I on a project by Leonardo da Vinci. Return to the hotel through the forest of Boulogne. Day 3: Blois – Chaumont – Amboise  (53 km /  33 mi.) Following the river Loire you arrive at the castle of Chaumont, that was built on a cliff overlooking the Loire by Pierre d'Amboise. It was then purchased by Catherine de Medici: she sent there Diana of Poitiers for revenge and kept for herself the magnificent Chenonceau. Always following the river Loire you reach Amboise, a picturesque town on the left bank of the river.  Here, you can visit the royal castle, which stands on a rocky outcrop overlooking the city. Day 4: Amboise – Chenonceau – Amboise  (34 km / 22 mi.) From the valley of the river Loire to the valley of the river Cher, through the Forest of Amboise, you will reach the castle of Chenonceau, so-called "of the two queens", Diana and Catherine. This is certainly the most beautiful and the most visited castle, with its magnificent arches over the river. After another nice ride along the Cher river, you come back to Amboise. Visit to the Château du Clos Lucé, home of Leonardo da Vinci in his late years. The museum hosted inside the house exhibits models of da Vinci’s inventions. Full scale models are setup in the park allowing you to interact and directly experience these fabulous machines. Day 5: Amboise  – Tours  (29 km / 18 mi.) From Amboise, along the river Loire, you  cycle through the famous vineyards of Vouvray, between the tufa cliffs that overlook the river. You will arrive in Tours, the most important city in the region. Visit of the old town, of the cathedral and of place Plumereau. Day 6: Tours – Villandry – Tours  (42 km / 26 mi.) From Tours, following the river Cher you reach the castle of Villandry, famous for its "jardin potager". The famous gardens of Villandry are the most beautiful example of French Renaissance architecture, built under the influence of Italian gardeners.  You go back to Tours on a nice cycle path. Day 7: Tours The tour ends after breakfast.
pods_fields.scheda_tecnica: SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS This cycling tour includes our SUPPORT SERVICE PLUS, an exclusive service that only Verde Natura offers to ensure you are at ease during your bike tour, especially if this is your first bike tour experience. In addition to the classic luggage transport and emergency telephone number, we provide roadside assistance and/or recovery in case of emergency (illness, mechanical problem that cannot be repaired with the repair-kit). Simply notify us and within a short time our team member will reach you to solve the problem. If necessary you will be transported to your hotel. Service is  running from 14/07 to 18/08. Terrain: Mostly plain, only a couple of very short ascents (you can always afford them on foot). This tour is suitable for everyone, suggested as first bike tour. The daily stages are from 30 to 52 km per day, that means 3h/4h of cycling each day. Roads: 80% asphalted roads, 20% white country roads Participants: minimum 2 pax Luggage transport: yes, one luggage per person max 20 kg Suitable for children: yes, of all ages if used to cycling Bikes: aluminum city bikes 21 or 24 speeds with free wheel. Unisex model from 150 cm to 174 cm; gent bike for heights over 175 cm. The bikes are equipped with a waterproof side bag and handlebar bag, reparation kit, a lock every 2 bikes and a mobile handlebar support for each room. E-bikes for adults. For children:  20' and 24' children's bikes, 3rd wheel, child trailer and child seat. In the travel documents the pick-up point of the rented bikes will be indicated and at the time of delivery is required the signing of the rental contract. Helmets available upon reservation at € 15 each to be paid locally. Bicycle warranty: with this guarantee, Verde Natura, assumes the risk of accidental damage and accidentally caused by the customer or theft, if the bicycle has been closed with the lock provided. To be required with the bike rental. Starting point: Blois. Day 1 is expected to arrive in Blois recommended around 4:00 pm. The bike tour starts on day 2. Parking: some hotels have free parking for the duration of the tour; alternatively, there are city car parks that offer flat-rate costs for 7 days. At the end of the tour from Tours you can take the train to return to Blois or a taxi. End of the tour: the morning of the 7th in Tours, after breakfast. Service hotline: available in English and Assistance Plus on place from 14/07 to 19/08/2019 Travel documents: the description of the route is available in English Special meals / diets: the tour includes breakfast and in category A it is possible to add half board which includes 6 dinners. If you have allergies / intolerances or other food problems, please let us know at the booking time. In these cases, we do not recommend booking half-board so as to have more choices on the spot. Pets: pets allowed on request, to be reported at the booking time. Possible daily surcharges to be paid locally. Notes: the family rooms are often composed of a double bed and a sofa bed or extra beds and rooms from 1 to 4 people are available max. Some hotels are wonderfully positioned high up on the hill and overlooking the valley. You can push the bike walking along the climb. Twin rooms with separate beds are available only sporadically. We handle requests for twin rooms as non-binding requests. In case twin rooms are booking condition it must be clearly communicated as such when booking! Category B includes 2 * hotels. These are small hotels often in historic buildings where there is no lift and often the rooms are not air conditioned. However, they are very welcoming, characteristic and comfortable hotels in a central position. Category A includes big 3 * or 4 * hotels, often of a chain and in some cases not in central position. They have a lift and air conditioning, offer good comfort and some have a swimming pool.
